Added 2017)

name: The Yarborough Hunt
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.6
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
description: Brigg is a typical Lincolnshire market town, crowded with more pubs than you could imagine would possibly be viable for a place of its side. A 5 minute walk through the centre will take you past a dozen pubs, each of which remain open for business.
My favourite by some distance is the Yarbrough Hunt, based on a small back street over the river which implausibly has three pubs within a stone’s throw of each other.
The pub building is one of those typical venerable townhouses you find across the East of England with weathered brickwork and an architectural style calling up stereotypes of genteel English country life.
The Yarbrough manages to do a country pub in a slightly different way to some, with some specific rustic touches, and eschewing most newer pub features. It isn’t an ‘Inn’ by any stretch, as there is no food, it isn’t large or homely enough for that. It’s a workmanlike barn type pub, and I mean that in a very good way.
You will notice the exposed beams and tiled floor instantly when you walk in. Take a few steps to your left to enter the bar area where the ceiling has been removed to expose barn style rafters which gives it a characterful feel. The central area of the pub is mainly tiled but there are comfortable carpeted areas in the ante rooms to your left and right with huge sturdy wooden bench seats.
Almost a pre-requisite, the fire is going nearly 8 months a year which adds a warm cosy feel to the otherwise upright and uncushioned main pub area.
Despite being a pub, the place seems to do a majority café style trade during the day, as young families, old fogies and retirees potter down to drink coffee and read the paper. However, there are some reliable intransigents propping up the bar drinking ale, and when you look at the range of options it’s clear these guys have the right idea over everyone else.
Rather unusually, the Yarborough has a multitap keg ale panel behind the bar in addition to several cask pumps in front. It’s a curiosity in an otherwise old fashioned place, but the joy is that there are several unusual beers to try. Yes, they really have taken a step up with the range of offerings here. Despite the very decent and rotating cask ale options,
During the evening the Yarbrough does thankfully escape second gear, with a different crowd gathering. I would recommend sitting towards the end of the bar area for the most atmosphere as the fairy lights around the beams and general ambience around the bar is something to take in.
They have made some strange design decisions in some of the smaller side rooms which are wholly regrettable and not in keeping with inn-keeping, but hopefully soon someone will see sense and consolidate the whole pub back to its core.
There were also some wranglings in the last few years with the owner Tom Woods whose mediocre ales (sorry, but its true) were being outsold, unsurprisingly, by the other, superior options. It seems that this has now been resolved by the sheer variety on offer.
However, despite the usual provincial quirks that stop the Yarbrough reaching its potential, the pub is run by a very enterprising lady and a core of committed employees that are clearly proud and determined of the pub. This shows in nearly everything the pub does, and despite the healthy competition for bums on seats in Brigg, they enjoy committed repeat custom, quite rightly.
I have no hesitation in recommending paying a visit if you’re anywhere near Brigg. (Added 2017)

name: The White Lion
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.6
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
description: Worth the climb, your prize is a traditional country pub with shovels of home cooking in a genteel environment. However, be sure to check behind the bar for some interesting drinks choices, and hang around in the evening for some local village life.

After a brutal 20 minute ascent from Hebden Bridge to the beautiful and ancient village of Heptonstall your reward after the labour, sweating and panting is lunch and a pint at the lovely White Lion pub in Heptonstall, set right out onto the cobbled street looking very much as it would have done for 100 years.
The central location allows the White Lion to claim a spot as the epicentre of community goings on, while also serving as a stopping-off point for day-trippers and hikers, eager to experience the historic atmosphere of Heptonstall.
The pub itself is divided into a traditional bar and pub area with a fairly elegant wooden paneled bar, and a rather genteel dining area which either needs to age substantially or be replaced entirely, I’m not sure which.
Many people will be here for the pub grub, which delivers on the ‘Yorkshire Portions’ stereotype, particularly the meat and potato pie which looks as though it was cut using a snow shovel. However, the drinks selection is pretty impressive for a village pub, with a range of classic and local real ales, as you could expect, but some decent export lagers and a bottle selection that covers a few European styles. The food is decent value, and the drinks, steady value. The staff will be pleased to serve you at any time of day.
The White Lion is a considerably better pub than its more gruff, down to Earth neighbour The Cross Inn which had gone too far the other way with lowest common denominator stuff all round, and on a last viewing had closed down. However it looks from recent evidence to have been taken over, in which case a very short crawl between the two pubs would be desirable.
Folk music and community events are also at the heart of The White Lion’s success and despite the lofty location and exertion to reach it, there is much to recommend doing so. Head up The Buttress, a pack horse lane that is now overgrown and horribly uneven, and follow the steps up from across the main road at the top. At the top of those stairs walk 100 metres further up the road into Heptonstall and you’ve made it. Not for the faint-hearted, I warned you.
The White Lion is a classic Yorkshire pub with much to recommend it.

name: The Adelphi
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.6
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
description: This Victorian corner pub with its ornate period features used to be the first port of call for Tetley’s workers. With the brewery little more than a car park with the original office functioning as a museum and ‘art space’, the pub attracts a different crowd these days.
It’s testament to the pub’s over-arching quality that it pulls in a range of ages and classes. Its proximity to a stack of post-grad city centre apartments is purely fortuitous, as the pub long pre-dates their existence, but gives it a stock of young customers with plenty of disposable income. However, it’s also only over the road from the tough Leeds pub The Old Red Lion, a venue I doubt many have even dared enter (but probably should do). Along with young types, there is a middle class, middle aged crowd who enjoy the refurbished, preened environment and some die hard working class folk who gather round the bar clawing at the brass and supping whatever’s the cheapest beer going.
The pub has changed hands a few times, but is currently staffed by people who know about good customer service, while the beers resolutely stay in the same format. 3 or 4 rotating cask pumps serving session cask ale, a couple of regulars, and a whole host of unnecessary surplus Euro lager. Nevertheless, there’s more than likely something there to suit your needs. The prices are rather high though.
Pleasingly, Adelphi have a number of community events and deals to sustain your interest. Pub quizzes, occasional upstairs gigs and events, drinks deals and so on all help give the impression of a pub actively courting custom and treating you, even if it is largely psychological.
Leeds needs to keep hold of the very few traditional pubs it has left in the centre, and Adelphi is no doubt among the best of those, taking everything into consideration.
(Added August 2023)

name: The Angel Inn
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.7
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
description: Sam Smiths pubs come in a variety of shapes and sizes, though most have endeavoured to preserve and maintain a traditional style of pub going.
Most of their places have a preserved in aspic feel, simultaneously looking Victorian and yet in many other ways how they would have been in the 1970s. Much of that has to do with the cultural setup, a stripped back format, no music, just simple tables, chairs and a bar, and old fashioned opening hours. It’s difficult to visit one without feeling as though you’re in a museum.
Sam Smiths are also known for being off-the-chart in terms of value for money, seemingly existing in another economy altogether, although that has started to change since the mid-00s, and particularly in London. Over the next decade or two, depending on how the business functions, this peculiarity, and with it, one of the main reasons to visit a Sam Smiths pub may vanish.
If you’ve never been in one before, then come to terms with the factor it doesn’t have any brands of anything other than their own stuff. Right down to the bottled cherry beer or the malt whiskey, everything is relabelled under their own brand, or made in-house.
A regular sight is a newcomer peering about as if they’ve wandered into a museum asking if they serve a ‘Carling or owt like that’. Don’t worry if this all seems like stepping into bizarro world, there are plenty of serviceable ales and lagers, most of which you can buy for at least £1 cheaper than you would get elsewhere.
Angel Inn has a great spot occupying one of the arcades off Brigate in Leeds. Whether approaching from the top or the bottom, the alley entrance is one of those irreplaceably atmospheric entrances to a pub, and gives you that tingling feeling. Once you step through the doors it really does feel as though modern Leeds which surrounds the pub has vanished.
This is a pub with plenty of space yet designed in a way that always feels homely. There’s a small drinking area at the bar which is a nice space, very old fashioned but sometimes difficult to prise away from the regulars. To the left of the entrance is the main lounge area where most of the more gnarled Leeds locals hang out.
Angel Inn’s greatest asset is throwing together classes of people that would otherwise choose to socialise apart from each other. It’s the combination of cheap drinks and down to earth venue (working class + students) with the central location and atmospheric historical venue (middle class) that creates this dynamic.
It isn’t healthy to exist in class cliques, never meeting, and the Angel is a great, and usually friendly way of associating with different people.
You’ll find the staff fairly gruff but fairly stolid. There’s another form of politeness I’ve discovered through visiting lots of Czech pubs which I can best describe as ‘greeted as equals’, and that’s how it’s like here. You’re acknowledged, served quickly and not judged, which I find respectful enough, but don’t expect many airs and graces, it’s just that type of place.
The best beers on offer are the thick session ale Old Brewery Bitter which can verge on overly toffee sweet at times but can be put away in vast quantities, and the genuinely good Extra Stout with a flavour and consistency that is a match for any regular stout, including a Dublin Guinness. Oddly enough, their outsourced fruit beers are rather good as well. I recommend the Taddy Lager over any others, which is a genuine steady lager beer with a real beer flavour. Try and steer clear from the increasingly poorly kept and expensive Wheat Beer, the overly floral gloopy Organic Lager and the Sovereign Bitter which is insipid.
If you want a night out on a tenner, a Sam Smiths pub is still the place to go. My favourite spot in the pub is upstairs by the window, looking out over the yard. It is a cosy, expansive lounge area with a thick carpet and crimson walls. Watching the lights coming on in the early evening and seeing the transition from day to night is one of the grea

name: The Grove Inn
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.1
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
description: The Grove Inn is probably Leeds best traditional folk music pub, with a concert room, snug, traditional games area all mainly furnished in accordance with historic pub traditions.
This sort of place is becoming something of a rarity, and despite the value of upholding traditions, many local people unfairly deride such places as being grotty, such is the clamour in Leeds for the corporate and familiar.

There have been some concessions, as the lounge area is warmer and more comfortable than it was, thanks to a refurbishment and new owners prepared to actually turn the heating on at some point. Strangely though, the snug’s creaking, exposed unupholstered seating still hasn’t been fixed. I thought the whole point of a snug was that it was…well…precisely.
There’s a great atmosphere in the concert room in the evening, though you may find it a tad cliquey as they close the door, which does provide some privacy for the other pubgoers (and allows them to charge on the door) but makes it a little intimidating when you first step in.
There are some wonderful preserved features, and it’s still worth having a little explore to enjoy them all. Sadly despite the signage offering John Smith’s Magnet, that retro beer bit the dust quite some time ago.
The beer offerings are another great reason to visit, focusing intently on cask real ale and cider, usually 3-4 good ales to go at. Prices are moderate but certainly on the higher side if you’ve arrived from somewhere like Sheffield for the evening.
The location near Bridgewater Place means it also attracts a mixed crowd, with some business people enjoying the down to earth environments along with the crusty bar flies and the odd gruff labourer popping in for a quick pint. Lots of young folk work in the vicinity, but Leeds youngsters are too-cool-for-school and wouldn’t be seen dead in a place like The Grove Inn, if you discount occasional chin stroking troubadour and their groupies who turn up for open mic nights.
In addition to all of this there is some sturdy and pretty inexpensive pub grub which emerges from a tiny kitchen adjacent to the bar. 
Visit The Grove Inn while it still exists in its current form. You never know with Leeds, cultural vandalism comes second nature to people with more money than taste and it wouldn’t be at all surprising to see it being targeted for refurbishment by some genius with his finger on the pulse.
The Grove is a classic pub in many ways, a refreshingly workaday no B.S place to drink an immaculately kept cask ale and lounge around. Everything else is a plus, but when you strip all that back, it would still be worth visiting. (Added 2017)

name: Garden Gate
description:
EBG Rating:: 8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️

description: UPDATE: SUBJECT TO LONG CLOSURES AND CURRENTLY WITHOUT TENANTS 
A historic relic with rare preserved décor and real ales. Some rough edges due to location and ownership but a true community asset.

name: Kirkstall Bridge Inn
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.7
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
description: This pub manages a surprisingly rare thing for Leeds, a cosy traditional pub with plenty of atmosphere, community events and local character. Similarly, it manages to not be bland, sterile or mediocre despite many pressures that might lean it towards being so.
The building itself is a bit of a peculiarity as the street entrance at the front is considerably higher than the rear, meaning depending which one you take you end up in completely different parts of the pub. Although there’s a car park at the back, there is a beer garden which, until the terrible flooding in December 2015 was nice to sit out with river views and the eponymous bridge. For a year later you could still see the detritis everywhere around, the ‘grass’ under the pub furniture little more than grimy muck. Hopefully they’ve taken a pressure washer to it at this point, but you may find it nicer to get ye inside.
Unusually, you may find the ‘top floor’ the nicest area, with a cosy but spacious central room and a bar area looking through to a classic snug. If you can get a seat in the snug, definitely do so, as you have great access to the bar and have the most comfortable spot in the place.
Kirkstall Bridge is the de facto brewery tap for Kirkstall Brewery, operating 100 metres up the road. Even subtracting all their beers, the choice is excellent, with a nice blend of traditional cask ales and some interesting minor breweries and craft type brews. There’s also a committedly decent range of bottles – you won’t go far wrong for a beer in here. The only slight drawback is the expense, as the pub never approaches great value. Only the Kirkstall brewery beers could be seen to be anywhere near reasonable, and even then you’ll scratch your face wondering how they can ship the stuff many miles down the road and sell it cheaper than it is here.
As you’d expect, the pub is the centre point for Kirkstall’s social activities, a reasonably pleasant post-grad neighbourhood far more akin to Sheffield than some of the boroughs of Leeds that have been gutted of decent pubs. This gives it a sense of friendliness and youthful vibrancy without the pretentiousness that usually accompanies it in Leeds, and puts off people from other generations. It’s a down to earth crowd of various ages enjoying some great beers in a cosy community venue. With that, Kirkstall Bridge wins the right to appear here. (Added 2018)

name: North Bar
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.6
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️
description: Once of a day, North Bar would have been one of the first choices I could think of for this directory, yet now, I had to seriously consider its inclusion.
Originally North Bar was intended to be a ‘brown café’, inspired by Belgium bars with simple wooden furniture and a minimalist format; where atmosphere is drummed up simply by the leisurely pace and drinking during the day, melting into a more vibrant convivial atmosphere as the evening progresses. Although North Bar has always been expensive with erratic service, this format was a success and North Bar remained a staple venue in Leeds for over a decade.
Nevertheless, following a series of decidedly poor design choices, prices that seem to be lurching out of control, a decision to reposition itself as a US and British craft beer venue, and a whole host of competitors serving similar beer at better prices, North Bar finds itself in a far less enviable position.
North Bar’s raison d’etre for me during university days was discovering new European beers of various kinds. It’s arguably where I most developed my interest in German and Belgian beer for example, dipping across the bar and waggling my finger at whichever funky bottle caught my eye. At this point you could expect most of the bar taps to be doing likewise, yet most of these have gone, and the bottle selection appears to be little more than lip service these days as the focus has switched to serving American and UK ‘craft beers’.
With this switch, one of North Bar’s unique qualities has been lost, and instead it falls into a dozen or more similar places serving similar beer, just at higher prices. In order to recapture the magic they must seriously reconsider this craft scene sell-out and return to selling and promoting beers you can’t get elsewhere.
To make matters worse, the brown café feel has been degraded by the installation (in an already small narrow bar) or some tacky wooden strips along the ceiling, which add, I must say, nothing whatsoever, and just make the place feel more generic.
And furthermore (in an already small narrow bar), some genius decided that – LOL - let’s put a photobooth in here! A spectacularly rubbish idea. Clog up a bar where it’s already difficult to find a seat with a novelty that probably gets used ten times a week.
The first time ever, last month, I turned up and was struck that I didn’t actually desire to drink a single beer they were offering.
Imagine all this happening, and then being met with an almost tangible smugness at the bar as though they’re utterly convinced that their changes have made the bar the best place in town.
From characterful brown café to bellendy identikit craft ale bar in ten years, the metamorphosis is nearly complete.
Why then, is it included?
Sometimes you can be the harshest critic to your oldest friends.
Admittedly, there still are excellent ales to be had. The Belgian and German beers may have taken a back seat but haven’t gone away, and if you have £7 quid and rising to spare on a single beer, there are some difficult-to-find offerings in that chiller. They have also slightly improved their cask ale offerings which is hardly the point of the bar but generally worthy of praise.
Likewise, when it’s quiet, it’s still a nice place to be. North Bar’s best time of day is late-afternoon, early evening where it starts to get busier, but at a rate you barely notice while you’re sitting back and enjoying a beer.
I must use this opportunity to implore North Bar to take a look at what they were doing in the early 00’s and get back to that as soon as possible. We don’t need yet another craft ale bar, nor does North Bar warrant kookying up. North Bar was always best as a Belgian beer bar, with a great range of German beers, a simple brown café. You don’t get places like that very often in the UK. Why go from being different to being the same?

name: Wapentake
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
description: A relatively new entrant to Leeds bar roster, and a welcome change from the arch-scenesters trying desperately to copy London 18 months late, usually with a limited budget and even more limited imagination.
Wapentake is happy being low-key and down to earth, and its position on Kirkgate helps link up possible pub crawls in Leeds better than ever.
Upon entering the bar, your impression may be the place has a bit more of a café feel than a pub, but swing right to the bar area to discover a decent selection of beers for a place of its size, and a small but well-chosen bottle selection in the fridges behind. This is definitely set up primarily for beer drinking.
A couple of casks, a couple of keg ales and a few lager options which are sold for a fair price, some of which represent relatively good value. The often variable in quality Staropramen is always kept here very well, while the new 4% lager Pravha and whichever blonde/pale ale they have on cask is usually sold cheaply.
Scanning across the room, you’ll find paintings from local artists (so far so café), a piano inviting you to play it, and some sturdy seating towards the back. If you carry on further, you’ll find a beer garden. Despite the bar being squished into a row of terraces they have done quite well to fashion this out of a tiny Victorian back yard. There isn’t much of a sun-facing window of opportunity out there, but during the summer you can enjoy a few hours out there.
Upstairs is a similar picture, with some mish-mash furniture and décor of a slightly twee nature, but not so much as to be genuinely upsetting. Rather out of character, there’s a big screen TV which selectively shows football and rugby games, meaning it is also a bit of a hidden gem if you’re looking for a less testosterone fuelled venue to watch a game.
Not long after opening, Wapentake has attracted a crowd who quickly liked what it was offering. While some of the affectations such as the artisinal bread and deli, and the slightly vanilla-twee décor may be irritating, it’s a great all-rounder and has often been the answer to the questions ‘where should we meet up?’ and ‘where should we go next?’

All the same, in the final reckoning this remains a pub well worth spending time in. (added 2017)

name: The Blake Hotel
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Rotating range of cask and keg ales and good lagers. Simple but well equipped back bar with gins and large whisky selection.

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Simple traditional neighbourhood corner local. Upholstered bench seating, mid-brown tables, slight hint towards a retro revival while still seeming authentic.

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Calm, friendly and democratic during the day. Buzzy and neighbourly at night.

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Pub quiz, beer garden, board games, occasional events.

Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Good for the area,

description: You will struggle to find a better reviewed drinking hole, in even the Sheffield area. The reviews are well-founded, it is a classic example of a neighbourhood pub. Resurrected from a bordered up terrace as late as 2009, the crew in charge now know all about how to run a great community pub and are now rewarded with a stream of loyal custom.
The template is almost embarrassingly simple. While The Blake Hotel may be in all respects a traditional pub, don’t expect it to be crowded with horse brasses or tarred black. The décor is kept to a minimum, while still retaining a homely neighbourly pub feel. The main room in the Blake follows a fairly classical template of of dark green wallpaper, brown furniture and a cream ceiling. There are a few large paintings and the odd pot here and there to remind you you’re in a pub.
The bar area is compact and simple and the offerings remain very good value . Naturally you’ll be wanting a pint of thick cask bitter and there is plenty to go at, though take a look behind the bar at the enormous whisky selection, one of the few occasions where a dram may be called for.
Once you’re sorted for a drink have a sit down and a chat in the preserved genteel environment of the Blake. There won’t be any music playing or games machines whirring away, just the hubbub of a friendly crowd, the classic sound of a harmonious pub.
The pub is sequestered away, so it’s for those in the know. Finding it for the first time always feels like a discovery, then when you’re inside staff and the customers seem to be all part of the same machine, with some local characters milling about, and different generations sitting drinking together.
Be prepared for a hell of a climb unless you’re approaching the pub from Crookesmoor, the road up to the pub is so steep there are handrails to assist you. Your reward lies close to the top.
It is the kind of pub that by rights should have died out long ago, and all the more reason therefore to keep going at every opportunity. (Added 2017)

name: The Cobden View
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
description: My write up of this pub is quite personal, having lived only a few doors down for years. It’s another of Sheffield’s web of good neighbourhood pubs which allow you to plan a pub crawl almost regardless of what area of Sheffield you are deposited.
Cobden View manages a fair range of amenities that rarely clash with one another. It has a pool table, a dartboard, it does live sport, barbecues in the summer, pub quizzes, folk music, an extensive jukebox and has in the past offered free food to tempt people down. There are plenty of reasons to visit, and it’s a cosy venue too with properly upholstered seating and thick carpets.
The décor has always had the feel of needing a little bit of work, but all the same, it isn’t offensive.
You can expect cask ales at a decent price, kept well and sold at volume. Although they have at times had interesting bottles, the fridge options are a bit of a sideshow to the traditional fare on the taps.
Whether it’s to kill time, watch a game, enjoy the sunshine in the back garden, or pop down with a book, there always seems to be a reason to go to the Cobden.
At its best, the main lounge area to the right as you walk in is packed with students and rag tag locals (the local council has a strong showing for the Green party) who can get quite an atmosphere going in the evening. On folk music nights there is a collaborative and open feel, with no obligation to be quiet, which means at times the folk musicians win and at others the loud chat of the groups at around win. Being a part time contributor to the music, I can tell you from experience the quiet has to be earned with good playing (or crowd pleasing).
Sure, there are a few things here and there that would make the place even better, but the landlord works his socks off and is a generous guy.
It is one of those pubs where you only need to visit half a dozen times before you can name the regulars and the bar staff, and indeed it is the people that make it a special place, a genuine and vital community pub which needs your custom and goodwill.

One that's grown and grown on us over time. (Added August 2023)

name: The Beer Engine
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
description: At the bottom of London Road in Sheffield you will find a relatively new endeavour, having changed hands through some gloomy and depressing pubs and bars previously. The new incarnation, Beer Engine supplies a surprisingly bright but nevertheless homely, simple pub wherein many great beers can be drunk.
The décor is minimalist to say the least, with huge chunky wooden tables of a light hue with plain whitewashed walls. The layout does well to make the space feel compact and pub like, with a couple of side rooms that work well for groups and especially if you need a more private space for plotting and suchlike.
The colour scheme makes it a good choice for a casual drink during the afternoon, and there is a beer garden out the back, but similarly when it turns to night time to place definitely turns on a full on pub feel.
The location ensures an interesting, mixed crowd, with London Road being a multicultural area, and fairly close to Sheffield United’s football ground, so there are always a few outlying folk ready to give this a try. Similarly, it seems to attract students from the nearby accommodation and cheaper rented properties up the road. As with a lot of Sheffield pubs you can guarantee an intergenerational blend soaking up the ale together.
With a name like Beer Engine, the pressure is on, and they don’t disappoint, with a good deal of cask ale, rotational keg beer from various more craft style breweries and a decent range of lagers and world beers should the inclination arise. The cask beer is well kept, and the bar is well staffed, meaning you get served good beer quickly – this seems to be one of the things they’re trying to deliver on.
With the clean décor and ‘newness’, even with the local crowd you never truly feel as though the pub has developed the kind of character where you’d say it was an institution, but reviews don’t lie. People come here because they really like it, and despite very healthy competition we recommend walking down the road from the centre to Beer Engine.

name: Sheffield Tap
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
description: The brewery and pub chain Pivovar are partly to thank for a resurgence in the ‘station pub’ a concept that used to be an institution across England. Unfortunately these pubs seemed to be particularly vulnerable to the plague and pestilence brought about by brewery ownership, neglectful pubco’s and lowest common denominator pubgoing, that seemed to reach its nadir somewhere around the mid to late 90s.
Thankfully, in Yorkshire at least, the ‘real ale trail’ has seen a resurgence, partly due to a number of rail stations being located in beautiful Dales locations. It was these rural locations that were the last bastion of the quality station pub, but thankfully the network is growing, and the refurbishment of major rail stations has been seen as an opportunity to restablish the tradition in cities as well.
Sheffield Tap has done a great job of preserving the original features of the pub, with beautiful tiled walls, grand mirror panels stretching up to the ceiling and tastefully retrofitted wooden panels in some of the ante rooms. For a while, Sheffield Tap remained a modest size, but with capacity to expand, and this expansion has now taken place, opening out into two further rooms. Give them a go.
You can expect to pay a reasonable whack for the craft ales and exported beers, but not so much that you’ll regret it – they are still within the boundaries of fairness. Service tends to be lickety-split efficient as well. It’s a station so they realise many are there to have a drink and be on their way.
The backrooms have given the pub more room to breathe, so it is less hectic and business like in those backrooms if you wish to stay for longer. It still remains an odd venue to remain for hours, as looking out over the station platforms and never actually taking a train feels a bit weird. I find it works best when you’re looking to kill time.
As you’d expect, the naturally transient custom means there isn’t a cast of regulars in the pub, but the surroundings do give a sense of the former glory, which the brewing kit and the expanded space has somewhat resurrected. Even many of those glorious Victorian drinking parlours were there for a good time rather than a long time, and a visit to Sheffield Tap will suit this plan just fine. Grab one of their fantastic beers and recline, admiring the fixtures and fittings and enjoying the sound of conversation scattering in echoes along the tiles. (Added 2017)

name: The Brothers Arms
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
description: Another Sheffield backstreet, another great pub. The Brothers would stand out a mile in most places, but unless you’re living in Heeley specifically, the array of other options makes it difficult to pick it out as a specific destination.
However, when joined on as part of a pub crawl to the nearby, and also excellent Sheaf View and the White Lion, you’ll find the excuse you’re looking for.
The pub is set up on a hill with a grand view over West Sheffield, and may initially throw you off, with the traditional signage for Ye Olde Shakespeare Inn large and undisturbed. It’s only when you get nearer you’ll see the modern, simpler (and to be honest, not great) renamed branding.
Worry not for the branding though, as the value to the pub lies inside. An unusual entrance to the pub involves you having to walk up a set of stairs to get to the main bar area. The pub may be out on a limb but that doesn’t stop the locals from flocking here in their droves as part of the aforementioned crawl.
Great cask ales, homeliness and simplicity is again the not-so-secret recipe for success. It’s difficult to see how so many pubs get it so wrong. Whether it’s nasty décor, capitulation to template chain pubs or just poor ownership, there seems to be a million and one diversions from what should be simple, reliable and successful principles governing good inn-keeping. When you visit the Brothers and sit yourself down in a cosy corner, have a game of darts, or prop up the bar with the rest of the throng, you’ll pull your hair out (if you have any left) wondering how people could get it so wrong.
Until you ingratiate yourself as a regular you might find the service sturdy and Northern rather than specifically friendly, which in a way typifies the feel of the pub, lying somewhere between working class boozer and friendly folksy tavern. I’m glad the balance doesn’t swing too far either way, as the pub is much the better for the variety of people it attracts – another thing the Sheffield pub scene excels at.
Southerners will be delighted at most of the beer prices, while similarly you might find some interesting European beers knocking about in here. The Brothers comes with a reputation for cheap ale that isn’t all that well deserved, but it’s far from offensive.
If you can wade through the luxury of other options in the city, or just happen to be in the area, the Brothers is another excellent and enjoyable place for a drink. The beer, the decor, the atmosphere, the amenities, the value. None of it can be faulted, and it fits comfortably and firmly in with the mission of our website.

name: Klub Invalida
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
description: “Come on guys, let’s head down Klub Udruzenja Za Sport I Rekreaciju Invalida Kotor”, said no-one, probably not even in Montenegrin. In one of Kotor’s tiny charming squares you’ll see a sign in Cyrillic indicating the above unwieldy name, as well the typical Niksicko insignia awning, with a few plain patio seats out front. You’ll also see another modern swanky bar adjacent, called Bokun. Looks quite Western-friendly and approachable doesn’t it? Shun that place, and head here for a true local experience.
You may already have deciphered, but this venue is a very informal club for retired sportsmen, or more accurately when you arrive, a Caffe Bar in the Dalmatian tradition, just with the generic attempts at modernity removed, but all the great aspects: the local character, the good value and the commitment to beer drinking amplified.
Instead of paying 3 euros for a large Niksicko, as is nearly standard elsewhere, grab a table out front or in the bar itself and order a bottle of Niksicko for half that price.
It’s pleasant outside in the sunshine but there’s a slice of local life to be enjoyed by diving inside in the evening, with a crappy old telly perched at the front of the room displaying the evening’s football, and a grand old trophy cabinet by the door displaying the club members’ various exploits in the 60s and 70s.
This may not sound like everyone’s idea of fun, but the gnarled elderly couple (probably 50 years old but looking worse for it) are friendly in their own Slavic way, and ordering a beer will produce an almost metronomically identical process. The master of ceremonies, in his tatty grey sweater ceases whatever he is doing, rather slowly assembles the bottles on a tray, and opens them in front of you one by one, in each case barking ‘Zvolite’ which appears to be Montenegrin for ‘voila’ or ‘cheers’, or a bit of both.
The crowd in KUZSIRIK (that acronym half works, though I doubt they call it that) are how you can image Kotor being minus the tourists. Some elderly folk clinging on to their spot in the old town, some labourers popping in for a morning/lunch/evening/last thing at night drink, the odd official and even the local constabulary, which certainly raised a few eyebrows from where we were sitting. Don’t expect them to speak much English or have much to do with you personally. They are happy you’re there seemingly; there is an understated appreciation about it all, but this is really their place for which you are their fleeting intruder. The busier the place is, the better.
As for the drinks offerings, Niksicko is far from the worst lager in the region, and stands up to a few pints, but pleasingly they have brought out an unfiltered version recently which boosts the flavour further, and stands up as a genuinely pleasant drink, albeit one that may become sickly after 5 or 6. The pleasure of paying a little over a pound for one of these (especially if you have arrived in Kotor from Dubrovnik, where value goes to die) will boost the experience further. Wine and Rakija is sold (the rakija is stored en masse in a big chest freezer) for pennies as well. Generally, finding a fairly specialist offering in such a gruff traditional place was a nice surprise.
There are some amusing eccentricities and oddities, for example over Easter each table had a saucer containing hard-boiled eggs for your enjoyment, that appeared to have been boiled in beetroot juice for good measure. There is an element of unabashed and unapologetic crapness about the way they make nearly no effort to market their existence, almost as though they’re actually trying not to be noticed too much. It’s quaint, if that’s not too patronising a word, to be in a bar where it isn’t primarily about making money.
Kotor experiences frequent afternoon thunderstorms, but being ‘stuck’ in a place like this while the square temporarily becomes a lake for two hours is no great shame, indeed it just gives you an excuse to turn around yet again and say ‘two please’. There are some nice spots in the centre of Kotor, but this is the only one with a genuine locals atmosphere, local prices and a memorable authenticity the Caffe Bars of Croatia and Montenegro seem almost pathologically incapable and distinterested in creating. Anyone going out for a beer and a chat in Kotor should be basing their entire evening around it.

name: CAFFE BAR LIBERTINA
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.9
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
description: A night out in Dubrovnik old town can be an expensive business and not a particularly enthralling one, with some really generic places and dull wine bars, leaving a sleepy, slovenly and fairly unexciting feel in general, with the added bonus of being shrouded in cigarette smoke for good measure. You won’t find many local haunts anywhere and finding even a simple crap lager for less than £3 close to impossible.
You may read blogs telling you how Dubrovnik being expensive is a myth, but that claim is now redundant. As a consequence of exchange rate changes, Game of Thrones tourism and the natural curve Dubrovnik and Croatia has enjoyed in general, the cat is well out of the bag. The old town is ruthlessly priced and research will lead you to places that sink in quality dramatically in the search for what are ultimately meagre savings.
The old town may have been hollowed out to cater for apartment dwellers and American backpackers but even so, the locals need a few places to relax. Libertina is hardly a shining example of good value or good beer, but fortunately it executes the main thing this sight exists to champion – it’s a really good atmospheric pub.
You’ll find Libertina stuck at the end of the uphill rabbit warrens at the north end of the old town, a slightly less visited corner, and one you might miss out on altogether if you weren’t to know about it. There’s an arched doorway and a rather pleasant semi-circular bar area patrolled by a kindly, rather simple sort of chap. The shape of the place invites communal drinking and you’ll quietly sing Hallelujah as you enjoy the environment of a true pub.
The place is decorated in a vaguely nautical theme, not overstated but enough to give it a traditional style. Libertina certainly isn’t interested in attracting the seen and be-seen crowd, and outside of the height of summer you’ll find the place largely filled with locals, which is a delight as a trip to Dubrovnik usually involves only interacting in a service capacity as the stand by the entrances to restaurants trying to attract your custom.
Libertina has a prime spot, with a raised seating area at the back of the room with cushions. It’s very cosy and snug, and if you make it there, you’re nearly all set for the evening. The downside is Ozujsko for £3 will slightly burn your pocked, but it’s difficult to do any better elsewhere in the city – you may as well pay it somewhere that’s good.
It’s one of the few places in the city that has a real hubbub and character, so despite the fact you can technically get better beer elsewhere (Glam Café for good beer but an otherwise generic experience) you’ll want to spend the wealth of your time in the evening in, Dubrovnik’s best pub.

name: Azimut
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.2
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
description: Going out for a drink on the Dalmatian coast invariably involves choosing from a selection of Caffe Bars, which may have interesting names at times like ‘TURBO’ or ‘KUM’ but in practise offer a nearly identical offering that nearly defines the term generic. After a few days anyone interested in good beer and good pub going will be tearing their hair out (if they have any left) in frustration.
Sibenik’s nightlife offerings are in the main, no different. There’s a Riva with patio furniture so you can relax by the calm seas and people watch – fine for a while. When it gets colder and darker, venturing inside becomes necessary, and it is then where the particularly poor beer selection, poor music choices and absence of interesting décor or atmosphere starts to seriously grate.
Azimut is Sibenik’s alternative antidote to all that, a club and live music venue of sorts, with offbeat décor inspired by Hungarian ruin/garden bars making the most of its cellar situation nearly underneath the main square. As with a lot of places on the Croatian coast, it doesn’t really get going until the summer, but even out of season there is a core crowd you’ll find lining the bar chatting and messing around, and a side room which is geared up for live music but also has games involved. The eventual end feel is quite fun feeling and the sort of space you want to hang out in.
There’s what counts for an interesting selection of beers, with some English ales making an appearance, although sadly short on Croatian craft beer at the time of writing – only Tomislav was available, which is tasty but too strong to make a session on. The prices are a few kuna more than elsewhere, which is fine given the location, and not offensively dear.
You would think there would be a few places like this given young Croatians enjoy going out in the evening, and Sibenik is starting to attract the attention of Western tourists, but so far the nightlife seems depressingly obsessed with creating modern aspirational lifestyle bars to create that ‘summer vibe’, but ultimately blend in to one and project mediocrity and cheapness rather than glamour.
Hanging out in Azimut is a bit like breathing fresh air after all that. Quite some imagination and bravery obviously went into creating it, and any stay in Sibenik by anyone desiring a beer and a good time in the evening will involve a visit here.

name: The Pub
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
description: While Ollie’s Pub might on some level be a rather garish pilgrimage site for ex-pats and British tourists, with all of the loutishness that involves, you can’t really take a trip to Malta and not at least grin and bear one pint in Oliver Reed’s final (and fitting) resting place.
“The Pub” as it is definitively labelled, sticks out of the street incongruously like a grandfather clock in a sand dune. There’s no doubting what you’re in for.
Once you’re sat down and some of the blaring noise of the patrons starts to fade into the background hubbub, you can take a look around and appreciate that this place isn’t half bad.
Upholstered English pub seating of a rather aged, characterful hue lining both sides of what is a rather small pub and bar area, juxtaposed by a craggy sandstone ceiling which reminds you where you actually are.
The John Smith and Guinness taps bring you back into sturdy pub territory, and it’s a bit of a toss-up whether to have a pint of those for old time’s sake or one of the Farson’s range brewed in Malta.
Once you get started on a session the atmosphere inside, even if it spills over into obnoxious at points is undeniably vibrant, and there is that ‘letting your hair down’ feel that often accompanies these types of places.
Clearly the pub needs a toilet, and there’s no space downstairs for one, however what they’ve done upstairs is rather dramatic and upsetting, with a huge amount of space wasted for this 1970’s toilet cubicle, all formica and metal latches in the middle of the room, despite there in theory being space for a neater solution and some upstairs drinking to boot. You’ll want to extend your stay in the toilet to read the grafitti, which certainly captures the whole spectrum of the British nationality.
It’s important to know what you’re in for, but a good evening could certainly be had once you get seated. Leave some of your usual reservations behind on this one occasion.

name: Cafe Jubilee
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
description: Sometimes quiet towns and cities can churn up such desperation for a drink that you’re prepared to lower your standards with alarming ease as your wanderings take you past boarded up shops and sleeping houses. Valletta certainly knows how to make a beer drinking pubgoer concerned, as on an evening you may find what is otherwise a large old town to be boarded up and asleep in the manner of an English market town circa 1950 on a Sunday.
It’s vital to do some digging if you want to hang around all evening in Valletta, as turning up on spec could lead to a good hour of traipsing around fruitlessly for drinking options, something which can become more confusing on account of the inconsistent labelling of streets on printed maps flitting from Maltese to English whenever it feels like it.
Café Jubilee is a bit of a star in this void, a bar I’d be happy to visit were it in my town. The striking art nouveau decor and artwork makes it a very stylish and atmospheric place for a drink, regardless of how many people are there, yet it is actually a popular place with young people, and fills up in the evening. Grab any table you get the chance to. I’d say it goes past simply being tasteful and really crams in the art pieces to build a memorably busy-looking atmosphere.
There is an unavoidable café element to the place, as that’s the daytime purpose but I felt it transformed sufficiently on an evening to be a typical pub style meeting place, with a communal vibe developing that makes it feel more homely.
It’s also a place to find Farson’s Blue Label on tap, reasonably rare as most other places served only Cisk. The combination of cask bitter and the cosy, ornate surrounding are just the tonic to a pub scene otherwise lacking on a number of levels. Service and price are not notable, but neither are they offensive.
The good news is Café Jubilee are stationed in Gzira and Gozo too, providing further places of refuge as you try to navigate options that fall between tacky ex-pat bars and generic Mediterranean café terraces.

name: Špunka
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
description: This boldly-named drop in bar is well located in the epicentre of Uzupis, meaning it’s a short walk for anyone from the old town, as well as pulling in some people from the suburbs.
It’s surprising that they chose such a modest venue; it really is a small place, with the bar occupying almost half the surface area of its one main room. All the evidence suggests there’s enough footfall for them to have made a pub three times as big and made a success out of it.
So at times, crowding around the bar is the only real option, but for much of the evening you should be able to grab a stool either at or opposite the bar and drink on the ledge.
The bar is only interested in serving small/medium sized Lithuanian ales, so there are some exciting options on tap, including a couple of dark lagers and Baltic porter which are essential on any trip to Lithuania.
The beer is great, though probably a little more expensive than most, but the best thing is the local, cosy feel. It’s designed to feel pub-like rather than stark and modern, and treads a fine line between that typical ‘craft beer pub look’ and a characterful venue.
You’ll find a nice range of people in here, the odd tourist, grumpy old men sharing space with excitable youngsters, sharing space with a business crowd, sharing space with couples having an intimate drink together. It’s a must-visit when you go to Vilnius.
The only downside is there is nowhere to sit down and relax, so although you may want to hang around, the stool seating just isn’t comfortable enough to want to spend your whole evening there, much as you may want to. (Added 2017)

name: Omama
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.3
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
description: Well worth the 15 minute stroll from the old town, Omama is located in a basement in a sleepy backstreet in Bratislava, near to the university and hospital buildings, and provides a decent excuse to get out of the old town and see other areas of the city, which, while humdrum help give an impression of its constituent parts.
It will be apparent right from your entering the bar that you’re onto a winner. Despite the subterranean situation, there is a fairly high ceiling and the building itself has cellar windows dotted around the perimeter meaning plenty of light comes through from the outside, or at least just enough to make you feel like you aren’t in a bunker.
The bar’s decoration is all about retro ephemera, with panels and signs from the early 20th century, not only for beer but brands like Persil and Vim, which suit the place and help keep you occupied if you’re drinking solo. The furnishings are in good condition but have at least developed some age and character, and the choice of colour helps the place overall feel more like a pub than a bar.
I was drinking Svijany Maz, which at the time seemed like quite a good beer, but has rather fallen down the pecking order in subsequent years.
It wouldn’t be a Hostinec without some down and dirty food options so if the mood strikes you can order some pub grub or snacks for a very reasonable price. Meat, cheese, bread and beer, what more could you ask for?
While it may seem off the beaten track for a tourist, it seems everyone in the 18-45 age category knows the place well. The pub layout has bench seating across a network of different rooms so holds a surprising amount of people and even on a busy night you should find a seat somewhere. The place is clean and smells fresh, so hasn’t quite got the sheer raw appeal of a smoky Czech/Slovak pub, but it is a well designed, characterful and friendly pub that would almost certainly become a regular haunt upon residence in Bratislava.

name: Gázfröccs
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.6

description: Sopron's answer to the ruin bar scene. Offbeat + alternative, plenty of amenities to enjoy.

name: Bar Marsella
description:
EBG Rating:: 9.6
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️
description: Marsella isn’t exactly a secret, as any basic search about Barcelona’s bar scene will prove, but just because Barca residents known all about it doesn’t make it passé for a newcomer. There are some good reasons why it has become a bit of an institution.

You’ll need to walk to the Raval district just a short walk west of La Rambla. This has been seen as an edgier district in the past but they seem to have cleaned it up, and while there may be some drunkards around late in the evening, and migrant workers trying desperately to sell you beer, it’s about as avoidable as the kind of contact you’d expect from almost every city centre.

The only thing to watch out for is being corned by any groups down streets you’re unsure of.
After a short walk the faded and stained net curtains and rather geriatric frontage of Marsella hoves into view. You might need to do a double take of which door panel to pull to enter, and it looks so delicate and aged that any mistreatment might damage the whole edifice.
This continues once you’re inside.

You’ll find a single-room bar with quite a wide space at the front doubling as part dance-floor part bar area. There probably won’t be any dancing going on when you arrive, and you’ll see most people gathered along the seating areas on the left of the room.
Take a moment to inspect the cracked plaster everywhere, the decrepit wood panelling and former grandeur, which brings to mind a Havana cocktail bar. There are shelves and bookcases along the far wall with bottles that look untouched for several decades.

Marsella is known for its absinth, and you may find some brave souls partaking in this dubious ritual as you scan the room, but far more of an astute decision would be to order one of their enormous and boozy cocktails that are made with panache but presented plainly and simply (contrast to any cocktail bar in England where the added value is all about the artifice and presentation). They may do beer as well, but only bottles.

It’s a double team with a master and apprentice. His teacher, a scholarly old soul who tends the bar and chips in here and there, and a young man who does the table service and most of the heavy lifting.

The atmosphere is powerful, but difficult to explain. I’d recommend plonking yourself on a table where you can see the bar area on your left and the seating area on your right, as this gives you the full panorama. There is a hell of a lot to look at in the bar, but don’t forget to take time to appreciate the general scene itself, where at points you will feel as if you’re fading into the history of the place.

Perhaps it’s the glow of the lights against the walnut-coloured wooden panels, or that undefinable ‘vibe’ that makes it an unforgettable destination, but the short of it is, they’ve created something simply by doing nothing. Since 1820 they’ve opened their doors and just let it gradually age (and in some senses rot) around them.

You can read the anecdotes about Hemingway, Picasso, Woody Allen if you like, but I preferred to sit there and considering the wider churn of people that must have frequented the place over time, mostly to enjoy the absinth and heady surroundings.
Places like this don’t come along every day.

name: U Krále Jiřího
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
description: The ‘King George’ on Cheb’s central square demonstrates a certain sense of cultural bleeding, as Cheb’s proximity to the German border (and historic belonging to the old German empire) gives it a distinctly Germanic feel, along with the more usual Czech and Bohemian features.
The style of the place corresponds far more closely to a country/small town pub you would find in England and Germany, with a menu offering hearty and very affordable pub grub, and a slight partition between dining and drinking with a bar area set up for drinking and smoking (although drinking can be done in both areas).
It’s a very popular venue on evenings, and being single-minded about it, the bar area simply isn’t big enough. No-one seems to have realised this indicates an as yet unfulfilled demand for a dedicated hospoda in central Cheb, which is another issue. Hang out by the bar and watch some footy on TV or just soak up the smokey and lively atmosphere. Everyone generally minds their own business but there’s a varied enough crowd to strike up a conversation.
Their best beer is Gambrinus Nefiltrovany, a much improved and frankly delicious option that’s sold for less than 30kc (ie. very good value). If Germans weren’t so parochial about their own beers they would be seething at paying over three times as much in such close proximity.There are a few other classic Czech beers to go at as well.
Being a pub restaurant, you may find it closing relatively early, which leaves you on a forlorn trail trying to find other drinking holes in Cheb (don’t give up – try the church). For what it is U Krale Jiriho does an excellent job and may even remind you quite a bit of traditional pubgoing in dear old Blighty.

name: Moeder Lambic
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
description: No surprise unearthed bar here, this one is very well known about. Lavished with money and tastefully designed, Moeder Lambic successfully elevated small-time lambic, sour and farmhouse ale brewed in Belgium and Northern France into the public consciousness, arguably quite some time before ‘craft ale’ took hold and claimed to do the same, and with a great deal more class and élan.
Stalingrad’s own branch of Moeder Lambic is less pub-like (Although with a refurbishment of Saint-Gilles, that is likely to become less true) with a long rectangular room, tall ceiling and lots of backlit dark grey stone and varnished wood everywhere. It’s a rather classy affair with a long bar gleaming with the various glasses and an impressive tap selection that seems to run the length of the bar.
Moeder Lambic offers a superb selection of 75cl bottles, versus the standard bottle sizes which are more modest, while the stuff on taps is often rare and high quality and these are what you are directed towards choosing. You pay for it, as the 25cl servings come for the price of a full sized beer elsewhere in Brussels (even in the centre), but there is at least a fairness about it when you visit. If you’re with a crowd you may find choosing one of the cheaper wine bottle sized beers slightly more affordable. Nevertheless, the prices are largely in line with high ABV% craft beer in England.
Moeder Lambic is one of those places where the servers have a confident swagger, and it does seem to pride itself on good customer service. There is a sense they are enjoying keeping the show on the road. This doesn’t always ring true during peak periods, but if you visit mid-late afternoon and order a good bottle, you can expect that brought out as if you were a VIP, gleaming bespoke glasses, tray of seeds to nibble, bottle places in a serving basked on a metal platter. Lots of this is just valueless ‘added value’, but it underlines that Moeder Lambic is an upscale treat. It’s a good sign to visit and see 2 of the same staff members year after year.
There are a few issues with Moeder Lambic. The bench layout is not condusive to a communal atmosphere, meaning it can feel more like a diner than a pub. The bar area gets overly crowded and you have to perch inbetween people talking to order, intrusive for them and awkward for me, something I really dislike doing. Their merchandise behind the bar is self-aggrandizing, cynical and laughably expensive – cult bars become cult all by themselves – trying to turn Moeder Lambic into a brand just smacks of BrewDog style commercialism.
Nevertheless, the thought of a holiday to Brussels without going for a beer at Moeder Lambic seems almost hollow. If you grab a seat while it’s getting gradually busier on an evening, the atmosphere seems to bubble up while the booze takes hold – and there is some truly great booze even by Belgian standards. It doesn’t matter that Moeder Lambic isn’t quite as good as it think it is, because the concept and the execution is classy and brings beer drinking up to a level of cocktail bars without doing so in a particularly pretentious way.
This is maintained by the crowd that visit, as it is still a frequently visited spot for Bruxelloise. During busy points in the evening they seem to make a point of turning up to grab the tables as if to exert their authority over the tourists.
A change in style from brown cafes and quirky pubs, Moeder Lambic is yet another essential feature of Brussels’ extraordinary tapestry of bars and beer.

name: Hostinec U rotundy
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.1
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
description: Some great bars are out there hiding in plain sight, having managed to camouflage themselves in such a way that only the precise cross-section of people they are seeking the custom of ever enter in, and everyone else passes by as though it’s a members-only club or the sort of disreptuable dump they would never entertain the thought of frequenting. A great example of such a place is Hostinec U Rotundy in Prague, named after a dinky and rather out on a limb rotunda just 100 metres down the road, which acts as a handy waymarker for tracking this place down, a comfortable 10 minutes walk from the centre of the old town, and very close to the river.
The exterior is actually rather grand, even if the building itself looks rather ill-maintained, more of a Budapest type townhouse than a Prague one, especially when you take into account the knobbly grey-brown stone façade.
Wandering in, you are met almost immediately by the beer tap, with barely enough time to wipe your feet and take a measure of your surroundings. It’s an unusual setup but brutally efficient in some ways. Have a quick look at the beer offerings and voice your choice.
There are subtle class differences from bar to bar in Czech Republic which you can partly deduce from looking at the beer offerings. In Prague, Staropramen is largely available in the most working class pubs, if you don’t count their modern chain bar ‘Potrefena Hus’, which is reliable in a Wetherspoons kind of sense, but without the similar value for money. It is Staropramen which you’ll be ordering here. This beer is suffering a little from Carlsberg’s ownership, with some dodgy brewed under license operations across Europe which are dragging the quality down (try a Croatian Staropramen and feel true sympathy for the Croats) and trading on the label alone. However, despite that and the fact it so regularly doesn’t seem to be kept very well, there is a good beer there lurking in the background. U Rotundy is as good a place as any to try it in its best form.
The light 10 degree version is absurdly easy to wash down, and while you’re doing so, reacquaint yourself with the beer prices – 27 czech crowns…in Prague! You’re looking at one of the cheapest beers in the city in the Old Town district itself where a Pilsner Urquell is generally between 42-50 crowns these days. In current exchange rate terms this is under a pound a pint, even if you add on the extra 68ml that would bring a half litre to that point you’re getting a beer for under a pound in the old town of Prague, something which was apparently declared dead several years ago (when the exchange rate was far more favourable to the pound than it is now). Discoveries like this reinforce Prague’s reputation as a cheap beer mecca.
Now, a pub isn’t all about the beer and the price of it (though I’m sure some of the patrons of U Rotundy would probably argue otherwise), and a few of you may be feeling intrigued as to the place itself. I would liken it to a Czech equivalent of a Sam Smiths pub. The place is a throwback, probably even to Communist era Prague, and like many old fashioned pubs without music, there’s a calmness about the place only punctured by the occasional burst of laughter or if the sport is on telly. Although it doesn’t seem like the sort of place, they do serve food and if you read the reviews they are surprisingly good. It wouldn’t be my ideal locale to dine in, but when you need to line your stomach in preparation for several beers, why not streamline the experience, eh?
U Rotundy is the antithesis of glamourous, with its cheap beer and Staropramen insignia table cloths each thousands of times washed over, and is entirely geared up for the loyal custom of locals, engaged in volume drinking and happily accepting the transit custom of tourists like myself treating it as a living museum and gawping at the price labels. That said, it’s no soup kitchen or long dark airport lounge of the soul, this is a true pub in all senses, comfortable enough to lean back and relax, associate with your friends and acquaintances and have a chat. U Rotundy seemed to me missing that essential something that would propel it to the top of the ratings, and I think that was down to the cheap table cloths and slightly stark surroundings even for my tastes, but even then you’ll find the lack of concessions to modernity and absolute adherence to down and dirty drinking and smoking somewhat endearing, indeed a reflection of the national character. This is most typified by the fact they could sell their beer for 40% more and still receive plenty of custom, but choose not to, almost pride themselves on their reluctance to raise the price. Pubs like that are always loveable because they give you the sense the owners are on a similar wavelength to yourself.
It’s the kind of place that will make a certain percentage of people throw their nose in their air and squeal in discomfort. For the rest of us, there is a simple no-nonsense pub with efficient service, local character and outstandingly cheap good beer, so much so that considering all factors I would lay it out on the line as the best relative value beer I have ever had.

name: Sousedský Pivovar Bašta
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.6
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️

name: Vzorkovna
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.3
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
description: Vzorkovna is an alternative hideout for when the smokey cream, brown and greens of traditional Czech pivnices get a bit samey. It’s an interesting literally bohemian bunker of different rooms and moods, somewhere between a bar and a club.
First things first: A strange payment system that may initially send off the wrong signals. You rent a fob for 50kc, which is then used inside to pay for beer. You’ll note the server becoming irate as for the zillionth time they ask a clueless newcomer to blam their fob against the not very well signposted counting machine at the bar. After your time in the bunker you emerge at the top to settle up your account with the doorman. Sounds dodgy as anything, but I can confirm no swindling or funny business goes on, and the guy at the top is reasonably easy going.
Once you’re over that initially strange faff you can concentrate on drinking and having a good time. The bars are stocked with 6 or 7 interesting Czech beers on tap. Yes, bars plural, this venue holds quite a web of different rooms, and it’s worth having a good walk around to explore where you’d prefer to hang out. One room looks like the galley of a ship, another is a very compact little music venue, there are maze like corridors, stairs up to balconies and down into basements, and every now and then a dog passes doing laps of the place.
It’s a nice reminder that Prague, just like Budapest and Krakow does have a good underground scene, it’s just so buried under high quality regular pubs that you occasionally have to remind yourself to partake in it.
It’s quite obviously a bit of a hipster/alt-crowd hangout for twenty somethings, but there’s enough space to choose how you want to hang out, whether that’s finding a snug corner, or reclining with some of the dropouts, or enjoying the live music. There’s plenty to do, and despite the fact beer is served in bloody jam jars, even that cannot prevent this strong recommendation.
A: 9/10 B: 10/10 C: 9/10 D: 8/10 E: 8/10 F: 8/10

name: King Grizzly
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.1
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️

description: There’s a certain appeal to a corner drop-in bar that’s basically a load of wood. Wooden floor, wooden ceiling, wooden ledges, wooden barrels, wooden seats, wooden bar. King Grizzly is like the spit and sawdust bars of old, if you took special care to remove both title elements from the equation.

Being slap bang in the centre of Florence doesn’t yet appear to have rendered King Grizzly either overcrowded or overpriced, and it may be something to do with the ostentatiously growly fuzzy bear appearance. Those upturned barrels probably put half the Aperol Spritz crowd off, while the exterior has a certain anonymous look that you could walk past it a dozen times before noticing it properly.

What this means in reality is that anyone in the vicinity who is after a real pub experience and a good beer can enjoy both of those in comfort without struggling for seating room or access to the bar. The personification of King Grizzly seems to be the chap behind the bar, one of those bearded sorts where the beard makes him look wise beyond his years. Affable, helpful, and unlike nearly all Italian bars and restaurants he will give you a glass of tap water (many places claim it’s illegal to serve tap water to customers) rather than charging you for mineral water. Mr Grizzly can guide you to a beer that you’ll like, which was particularly useful as my girlfriend is still struggling to get into beer. An Italian double-wit beer and a salty Germanic Gose later, and it feels like we might be making progress!

Yes, this is a craft beer place, in that most of the offerings are from the ‘craft scene’ as it were, rather than traditional breweries, and are priced accordingly. However, none of the prices should scare off any English tourists who these days are used to spending £5+ upwards on terrible lager elsewhere, and when you put it into context, the prices are perfectly reasonable considering the excellent quality. If you ever needed persuading that Italian beer is getting its act together, you will leave this pub converted.
It’s one of those places where you can say you met as strangers and left as friends. A great example of how a good pub and a good beer can bring people together. So good that a place like this can be directly in the old town of Florence. The Grizzly King: A Romance of the Wild.

The beer offerings have improved, unfortunately at the expense of the prices, but that doesn't deter a broad crowd forming at this place these days which seems to go from strength to strength with each visit. The setting makes this a superbly atmospheric pub whether quiet or busy, but if you find it at its peak, there are few places in the country to match it. A younger crowd with a lively but not raucous feel, this is the thinking person's pub. Essential stop off in the city. (Added 2018)
