Small pub by a railway bridge which a large glass window at the entrance more similar to a cafe. Inside the old school boozer features have been retained with pews, piano and a large bar. The old painted over pub sign is hung on the wall.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Popular evening spot with a natural buzz and excitement, but an effective quiet afternoon spot also.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Piano, outdoor seating. On the food front no gastro, just good bar snacks, pork pies, sausage rolls, scotch eggs, roast pork in baps plus veggie options. The music is played on vinyl which is great, there is also live piano music on Sundays and Tuesdays and Wednesdays. No tea, no coffee, but a bloody mary kit is behind the bar. Pub stays open to midnight most days. Pub quiz Monday.

Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Priced according to strength, and overall entirely fair given the standard of some ales you can nab.
description: In its previous life, this was a resolute basic boozer with sports, Carlsberg and Guinness. Then, around 2009 it was taken over by a brewery and with a committed emphasis on cleaning it up, improving the drinks offering without removing the character. Since then, it has attained the status of local classic, a place anyone in North London might think about taking the train to visit (and it is in a triangle of 3 available stops). On a row of shops by a railway bridge, as you approach there is a timeless since of permanence to the exterior. It has changed, it has received a lick of paint, but the function overall has not. Here you will find exclusively beer and cider from independent breweries, often small and in need of this kind of platform. Spit n sawdust type floors, pew seating and old signage is balanced by the large front mirror, and a café vibe at the front known as 'Cockney corner' after the stalwarts who decided to stay. At the back in the garden, poets corner describes the vaguely Bohemian, if middle class crowd. In the evenings the place becomes busy and buzzy, finding a seat a matter of ruthless opportunism, but not impossible if you give it 10-15 minutes usually. During the day the worn wood and general ambience endows the place with a classy charm not unlike a brown café of Belgium or Netherlands. One of the highlights of pubgoing in North London. (Added September 2023)

name: The Pineapple
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.6
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
4 rotating cask ales, and reasonably well stocked back-bar. 
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Lavish, exuberant mid-Victorian neighbourhood pub with large mirrors, Corinthian columns, rich reds and golds with communal seating. Compact with a bar at the front and seats around the room extending to a rear courtyard with atrium.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A loved and cherished local is a fine thing, and here is among the finest examples in London. Popular community boozer with a true range of people. 
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Thai food, snacks, books, board games, outdoor seating, community events.
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Entirely reasonable prices for cask ales given it's North London.
description: A loved and cherished local is a fine thing, and here is among the finest examples in London. Popular community boozer attracting the neighbourhood. It's rather garish exterior that is more likely to have you reaching for a pair of sunglasses than entering the pub gives no hint to the warm, lavish exuberant Victorian interior. Strangely enough the architect is unknown!  Another threatened pub that was saved by a rush of community support, a good reminder of the rewards of using your local amenities, particularly special pubs like these. Although there is a Thai food kitchen, the interior is very much geared for casual socialising with books, board games and hangout spots. The cask handpulled ales are on rotation from smaller brewers and provide a continuing low-key interest as well. Check out the atrium to the rear of the pub and be sure to explore! (Added September 2023)

name: Old Eagle Pub
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.7
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Cask ales mainly from a mainstream range, but well kept. Reasonable but largely typical back bar selection.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Three-storey Victorian corner pub with some original Mosaics at the entrance and L shaped corner bar. Decorated with dozens of old musical instruments hung up above the bar. Local art and a range of furnishing further add to its distinctive identity, a blessed relief given the Greene King involvement. If that isn't enough, renaissance sculptures, glass eagles and posters of old theatre shows complete the set.

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
An interesting mix of arty independent crowd and general boozehounds result from its location, which attracts general footfall. This helps give it a vibrancy without any smug cliquey feel.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Thai food, artwork, live music, Monday quiz, DJ set on Thursday, dog friendly, resident cat
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
A nice surprise, reasonably priced given the location. 
description: There are places such as this where the mainstream appears to be sitting willingly alongside the subculture, and this is to be applauded in an era where people live increasingly siloed existences. On some levels the offering will seem ho-hum - familiar mainstream ales and pub ownership, DJ nights, and a high street setting. On the other, its Victorian inheritance, collection of musical instruments, sculptures, theatre posters and cats balance the transient trade with a core of regulars and frequent guests. It is also an affordable venue for the area and London generally. Overall it made a sound impression - every time you dwell on a shortcoming a surprising highlight comes to reset your experience to a positive one. (Added September 2023)

name: Tapping The Admiral
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.1
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Strong range of cask ales, most from independent, smaller brewers, at least two ciders on pump, and a competent back bar.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A corner pub with some deco/naval stylings out front, L shaped traditional pub inside with a seating around the bar and space for standing in between.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Neighbourhood pub with a clear cast of regulars during the afternoon supplemented by people from further afield in the evening. Social and communal, low-key and unshowy.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Meals, pies, snacks, Sunday Roasts, outdoor seating, tap takeovers, pop up events, live music, quiz, books, board games
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Well in line with the going rate for the area and quite reasonable for North London.
description: On the side of 'The Castle', where reportedly Horatio Nelson's uncle frequented, then rebuilt into the Trafalgar, and now 'Tapping the Admiral', a nifty name referencing alcohol consumption and Nelson himself. Not exactly brought to life, as restored to its potential by the owners of the nearby Pineapple (also a great pub). Low-key and neighbourly, but that is intended as a compliment. This is an operation determined to do what pubs of this sort excel in - great cask handpulled ale and some ciders, community events and amenities, somewhere to socialise, a meeting place. The interior doesn't have the heritage glam of The Pineapple but it does have a sort of stolid appeal that would inspire loyalty if you lived anywhere near it. An essential stop off if visiting the pubs around Kentish Town. (Added September 2023)

name: Lord Clyde Southwark
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.7
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Traditional English cask ale selection but well kept and reliable. Largely perfunctory alternatives.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A 'corner pub'. From its eye-catching exterior with (defunct) Truman's Brewery signage to the upholstered interior of soft fabrics, carpet and communal bench seating. There is also lounge room behind the bar as you enter.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
TV, English pub grub, snacks, books, outdoor seating
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Very reasonably priced for ales considering what can be paid around London.
description: A gem of a backstreet corner boozer from the external Truman tilework to inside traditional decor with wooden half panelled walls throughout, upholstered communal seating and curtains over the doors. Kept in the same family for over 60 years until 2020. It's a real step back in time, so if you're keen to show someone a real London boozer rather than the chain owned mediocrity they are normally funnelled to, this is a prime candidate. During the day the typical horse/dog racing on TV, grumpy Landlady exchanging banter and regulars dipping in and out, with traditional cask handpulled ales service in good condition, and a terrace area in the summer where a younger crowd congregate. A stalwart, a vital, hopefully permanent fixture in Borough. (Added September 2023)

name: The Gladstone Arms
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.6
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Compact drinks range with independent UK craft keg the highlight.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A British Indian mix with impressive tiled exterior leading to a small downstairs of informal pub/café furniture. Terrace patio upstairs.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
It feels like a pub, and it is a pub, unlike many other Desi 'Pubs' which are more like restaurants with a casual social scene. The service is friendly and welcoming and a few regulars add to the sense of character and community with plenty of chat even at quieter times.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Desi food, snacks, live music, books, board games, community events, outdoor seating
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Lunch deals are very reasonable while the drinks offer overall is in line with other venues in the area.
description: Listed in David Jesudason's CAMRA published book 'Desi Pubs', this reportedly is the only pub in the country with a Landlady of Indian heritage. Family run with a distinctly friendly welcome and collegiate feel, these are people committed to procuring an atmosphere not only of civil tolerance but active cultural exchange. This may seem an over the top description for a multicultural city like London, but for the UK in general this counts as an absolute standout among a handful of such venues. As for the 'product' expect some craft keg ale options with a broad range of Indian dishes from typical Desi grills to Indo-Chinese and Indian Sunday roasts. With cricket on TV, live music events and outdoor seating, this pub that has been under threat multiple times in recent history now looks and feels vibrant (in the original meaning of the word, not the patronising/euphemistic sense), secure and back to life in good hands. (Added September 2023)

name: The Nell Gwynne Tavern
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.7
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️
Not its strong suit, a fairly perfunctory range of familiar brands. 
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Very appealing bawdy decor in this tiny backstreet pub down an alleyway with its red wallpaper, lamplight and theatre heritage hung on the walls. Grade II listed.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Very much keeping the spirit of the place alive, enter via an alleyway to be transported to olde London Town with its salacious theatre scene. You can easily imagine the gossip and clandestine activities that took place here. However these days it isn't merely a museum, it feels relevant and vibrant 

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Free jukebox, limited outdoor leaning space, fireplace, pub snacks and tapas.
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
Central London prices.
description: Yet another heritage pub threatened by property developers, The Nell Gwynne, built on the site of the famous Old Bull survived the latest attempt in 2016 to remove our cultural heritage so some already obscenely rich person could make more money. Grade II listed and named after Charles II's notorious mistress, this pub will transport you to the heady days of Victorian theatre-land. A small pub with bawdy lighting, oak shelving, fireplace and lamps, you'll find it tucked down a flagstone alleyway directly off the strand. The interior comes into its own in the evening but has a certain youthful energy during the afternoon too with a free jukebox and lively staff keeping the rhythm going. Although drinks are limited here, they play only a supporting role to what is an experience pub. (Added September 2023)

name: The Black Lion
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.6
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Beer focused with a balanced selection covering UK craft, European beers including some oddities and cask ale range. Well stocked back bar.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A piece of jaw-dropping one off magnificence. Filigree and detail covering walls and ceiling, something out of this world almost. High ceilings with a large bar area, dining room to the rear and old partitioned 'smoke room' (no longer smokey).
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️
Market town tavern type fare with some transience. Lacking some snug corners and cosiness but still a pleasant atmosphere overall.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️
Meals, snacks, dining room
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
London prices for food and drink.
description: A Grade II listed pub of national heritage importance, your jaw will drop as you enter to a scene of 19th century Flemish Gothic splendour, the walls and ceilings covered in filigree and ornate decoration, a show-stopper that will hang in your memory forever. That's reason enough to visit Kilburn, and you'll notice the contrast between here ant the high street. However, that's not all there is to it, with North Indian cooking, a good versatile drinks range and pleasant glow to the place in the evening. It projects significance and no wonder it received an award for the best refurbishment after years of PubCo neglect. Ignore reviews from Google which mix in their hotel accommodation. (Added September 2023)

name: new street pub
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️
1 or 2 basic cask ales with a perfunctory lager + cider selection. Not its strong point.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Traditional backstreet boozer in a stone cottage. Small with a snug bar room and wider lounge to the rear, pool room to the left with further seating.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Fully local with cast of regulars, banter flowing back and forth but a friendly welcome too. 
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Snacks, occasional events, pool table, TV
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Very good value for the cask ales.
description: Out by Pellon on the edge of town, it's a simple small backstreet boozer with its cast of regulars and banter, but friendly. 3 cask pumps, 1 in regular use, 2 and 3 occasionally used. Remember it's CASH ONLY here! 

Enjoyed the atmosphere and environment which was quite cosy.

A snug bar room to the right of the entrance, old fashioned pool room to the left, and lounge to the rear with TV. Generally tasteful design with sympathetic pubby decorations and exposed brick, communal furnishings.

A Heritage listing says as follows:

This is a classic end-of-terrace local, a former beerhouse, which was remodelled by Webster’s brewery in 1935 (architects, Jackson & Fox). Their revamp included features, like the stand-up lobby, that were being designed into their much larger new pubs of the time – and the New Street preserves the planning and many of the fittings from the inter-war scheme. Original fittings include good oak-panelled doors and seating with Art Deco stepped armrests. (The fireplaces and lounge counter are later). CAMRA sought statutory listing in 2009, but without success. 

If you like a Halifax pub like the The Big Six it'll worth the trip out from the centre. (Added September 2023)

name: Na Můstku
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Basic options - lager and central European liqueurs, perfunctory alternatives. But they also have Poutnik lager from Pehlrimov on tap, and that's a great beer, so...
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Surviving unspoilt boozer with cream walls, ramshackle seating, personalised interior and - rather unusually - a giant dragon fixed to the ceiling. 
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
While this is a throwback, there is a sense of relevance and fixture to the place. You can feel the years but also the day-to-day rhythms. It isn't exclusively a hold out for old men either, and you'll find a reasonably mixed crowd, some enjoying it for the cheap prices and relaxed atmosphere. Quite friendly and tolerant to a clear newcomer. A truly unpretentious, unvarnished hangout to relax in, which some people with love, others will hate.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
TV, books, board games, basic Czech 'food with beer' type snacks
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Very affordable prices all-round.
description: Those seeking a legitimate old Brno pub near the centre - look no further! This is a throwback Starobrno fourth-grade pub with some distinctive touches, none more so than the impressive dragon attached to ceiling. The interior is a pub of old, but the atmosphere has not receded into irrelevance - the day to day rhythms, cast of regulars and a few younger groups are testament to a pub that has a wider appeal than simply to old fogeys. There is also Poutnik - an excellent lager on tap for a great price. With books, board games and a TV there is plenty to do, and with a tolerant, non-cliquey atmosphere, plenty of reason to make a first visit even if it may be initially a little intimidating. A truly unpretentious, unvarnished hangout to relax in, which some people with love, others will hate.(Added October 2023)

name: Restaurace U Bansethů
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.7
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Pilsner Urquell from the tank with a full tapster setup. 
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A typical upright pub-diner with rows of communal wooden seats in a corner venue. Adjoined to a minibrewery it shares a kitchen with.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Feels like the centrifuge of social activity during the day in Nusle district. Busy, chatty, but rarely/never breaking out into any revelry.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, outdoor seating, newspapers
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Fair value for drinks and still very reasonable value for its daily menu.
description: One of Prague's famous pubs made so by its association with writer Jaroslav Hasek, whose anarchist meetings took place here while developing his satirical (and hilarious) political party The Party For Moderate Progress Within The Bounds of The Law.  These days its a busy, business like but still charming enough fixture in Nusle district's social scene, with rows of street drinking and an old fashioned pub diner inside. Known across the city for its baked duck stuffed with dumplings, this can be obtained at lunchtime at a very affordable price. In the past this place had a reputation for being very frosty to foreigners, but these days if you come armed with a few phrases and good manners, you will be treated as well as anyone in the pub. A further quirk is it shared a kitchen with the adjoining microbrewery pub, the two places both distinct and yet slightly melding into one. (Added October 2023)

name: Café Bar Pilotů
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.9
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Cocktails themed around the businesses in the neighbourhood and large back bar, with some tap beer available.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Bookish, artsy and loungey, with local artwork, high shelves and a large rotor blade at the bar.  
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A lively, popular and relevant feeling hangout spot that hits a nice balance between the special feel of a cocktail destination bar and informal social space to relax.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Snacks, books, records, occasional events
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
Typical cocktail bar prices
description: Vrsovice, hipster neighbourhood with an international flavour - not particularly tourist, these are more like ex-pats, people that visited Prague and decided to stay for longer. A mixed crowd visits Pilotu with its huge rotor blade catching the eye on the entrance, as well as its high shelves filled with books, records and booze. It's a good use of space overall with a front bar and lounge space at the back with local artists represented on the walls. Striking the right balance between a special experience to justify the prices and a relaxing place you can socialise at ease. Cocktails created along a theme of navigating the local neighbourhood are genuinely creative. Well worth checking out. (Added October 2023)

name: Pivnice Na tržišti
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
A Branik pub, so basic offerings deliberately in order to keep prices low. 
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
An unspoilt homely little hangout with some personal touches in the window, genteel old-school boozer.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
An interesting mix of the typical grizzled old geezers who inhabit such places and the younger Vršovice crowd that are here to enjoy the low prices and retro environment.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Simple Czech 'beer meals', TV, snacks
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Very low prices all-round, around 30-35% cheaper than average albeit for a budget range of wares.
description: One unexpected quirk of Vršovice becoming such a fashionable, nouveau-riche district of Prague has been to shed an attractive, complimentary contrast on the few old school boozers that remains. This one is in a prime spot, surrounded by instagrammable cafes and craft beer joints. Staffed by a kindly old woman (by Czech standards) and churning out honest budget fare which attracts a canny range of the typical grizzled regulars and youngsters here for a cheap pint and the retro experience. As usual, this considerable improves the atmosphere and the kind of democratic social mixing you find in a pub. There are some personal touches to the place which make it an attractive hangout spot even if first appearances and the odd scary glance may prove intimidating at first. It squeaks onto our guide. (Added October 2023)

name: Hospudka U báby
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Basic offerings augmented with a couple of more modern beers available.

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
An unspoilt homely little hangout, open plan on entrance with communal seating. A smaller taproom tucked away unsighted which is not ideal, unless you're a regular. 

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
An interesting mix of the typical grizzled old geezers who inhabit such places and the younger crowd that are here to enjoy the low prices and retro environment.

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Simple Czech 'beer meals', TV, snacks

Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Very low prices for the basic stuff, a real dive into yesteryear.

description: Hiding around the back of Florenc's ugly snarl of intersection and metro station is this old time hospoda. Bring a few Czech phrases and you'll receive pleasant service from the hostess. This is one of Prague's very cheapest boozers, half the price of places that are only a few hundred metres west. With local life and an unextinguished flavour of times past, that is reason enough to give it a try. (Added October 2023)

name: The Old Hall
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.7
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Sam Smiths range of drinks, 1 handpulled cask ale, some interesting fruit beers and old fashioned options, poor lager options.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Stone building around a 15th century timber frame hall. Baronial feel inside with high ceilings, 16th century plaster ceiling and exposed timbers, communal seating around the sides. A second floor with fully exposed timber rafters. One of only 4 of its kind in Yorkshire. Worth visiting for alone.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️
A quiet, but comfortable and cosy place that could use some low key background ambience to set a tempo when it's lacking customers.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Meals, snacks, outdoor seating, darts, dominoes
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Fair value with some budget options, particularly the £3 cask ale Old Brewery Bitter.
description: A bittersweet feeling that Sam Smiths run this pub. The incredible venue is well-preserved and maintained due to the money poured in, but could benefit from some concessions towards the present day to help kick it into life. A 15th century timberframe hall which has since been converted into a stone building, its interior is astonishing, easily worth the trip to Heckmondwike in and of itself. With friendly service, darts and dominoes, cooked meals and outdoor seating in summer, there are plenty of reasons to visit in spite of the backwards policies of its owner. (Added October 2023)

name: Black Bull
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.7
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Extensive cask ale range from Ossett Brewery with some guest ales. Mediocre keg options that could use improvement, standard back bar.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Stone in with multiroom layout. A small snug bar room to the right of the entrance and cosy lounge bar room to the rear. The the left of the door, darts and dominoes with further patio seating at the back. Tastefully decorated with breweriana and typical warm pub colours of red and greens with natural wood fittings. Standout tiling and brass fittings at the bar reflecting the patterns, cut off cask barrels hoisted above the counter.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A lively local boozer with cast of regulars and long term stewardship, here is one pub that remains vibrant.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Darts, dominoes, board games, snacks, community events, outdoor seating
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Fair value in general for the offerings.
description: Ossett Brewery pub ownership has become a watchword for maintaining tradition without losing relevance or a social scene. Its well priced, well-kept cask ales with simple pub games and snacks are a big draw, and the Black Bull is no different with its dart board and dominoes nights, cosy multi-room layout and appealing drinks selection. The pub itself is hugely elevated by a dynamic core of locals and long standing stewardship. (Added October 2023)

name: The Ainsbury Micro Pub
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Compact but well-kept range of regional handpulled cask ales, a decent enough keg and fridge selection too. Beer specialists.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A micro-pub with a bar room that's barely the size of an entrance way, with bench seats and two tables by each window. A small, compact upstairs painted tastefully in dark green offers a streetside view and a more lounge-like layout.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Local life with cast of regulars, you may immediately feel like a fish out of water. The point to these places is really about getting stuck in. If you don't like the sound of that, don't visit. There is help from the bar staff who will suggest the quieter upstairs if the bar room is too full-on.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️
Snacks, books, board games
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Reasonably fair value for money for the drinks.
description: The Micro Pub is a quirky format, part inspired by the ale houses of the past with their repurposed/homely layout and social focus, with more modern influences such as ales of different styles. There are many iterations, good and bad - here is one of the effective ones. True local life in situ with a wash of banter flying back and forth at the bar. A tiny bar room with two tables does not provide much escape from that, so steel yourself or get stuck in among them. A decent range of beers for the size and a tastefully decorated upstairs provides enough of an appeal to warrant an inclusion on our guide. (Added October 2023)

name: Baba yagas house
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.9
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Cocktails, mixers and a decent enough range of keg beers should keep most happy.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A standout element, highly personalised artsy interior with artwork against warm wood strip. A one-room setup with high ceiling with dangling decorations. 
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Off-beat but fairly homely place that can do sleepy loungey atmosphere as well as busy evening buzz.

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, books, board games, occasional events, art for sale
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Fair overall, perhaps a little pricier for food than ideal.
description: This distinctive off-beat bar manages to straddle several different points of interest without feeling like a stretch. The cocktails are well made but don't think this is a specialist cocktail place. This one room bar is warm, personalised and distinctive with a high ceiling and spread of artwork across the wall (much of which can be purchased). There are books and boardgames adding to the feel of being a casual hangout spot, but the product is good too, from its tapas small plates to the drinks selection which takes in a few craft keg options too. A relatively rare example of such a place being its own thing rather than displaying a derivative approach. Easily recommendable. (Added October 2023)

name: The Dog And Rabbit
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
While beer focused with local cask, craft keg and Belgian bottles, pay attention to the whiskies and gins too which are pretty good.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
A one room ex-retail unit, carpeted and furnished somewhere between an ale house and a pub, relatively effective but unflashy.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Cosy and social with a neighbourly lounge feel, somewhere you could park up for several hours for a drink and a chat. Does well to appeal to a broad range of people.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Snacks, books, board games, occasional events
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Fair, and not above typical
description: High street ale house with a comfortable interior. While unflashy, there is a solid feel to it that belies the fact it is clearly an ex-retail unit. That gives the place a sense of ease and it's the kind of place you could happily spend the afternoon. Cask and keg choices are modern and space is given to the microbrew operation and local/regional brewers, but this is complimented by good gins and whiskies. Overall, not one to look past if you're in the area. (Added October 2023)

name: Left Luggage Room
description:
EBG Rating:: 8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Focus on cask and keg ales, the choice is broad, but it isn't all about the beer with a good range of alternatives available.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Barn-like interior with exposed slanted rafters. Part of Monkseaton station with heritage signage and a terrace by the Metro tracks themselves.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Busy and buzzy, a popular spot for commuters and locals, the clear standout in the area. At peak times the queue can snake back through the room which spoils the atmosphere somewhat.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Books, board games, meals, snacks, outdoor seating, occasional events
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Scrupulously fair value.
description: A superior Station Pub, this one benefits from outdoor seating by the tracks and heritage signage. Inside a high ceiling with an angle barn-like space leads towards the bar which is very well stocked with national cask and keg beer, although plenty of alternatives are available. Despite the captive audience prices remain scrupulously fair. Well worth a stop off in Monkseaton, and it's a short enough walk to Whitley Bay beach past another couple of decent bars. (Added October 2023)

name: The Town Mouse
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A very acceptable range of keg craft of various styles including a good fridge. Beer specialists so limited alternatives.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
Basement pub, pokey with dark green paint and hops pinned to the corners. A little bit dank in the corners.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Nice intimate basement feel with a fairly social atmosphere.
Amenities/Events: ❤️
Snacks
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
City centre prices, but not unreasonable.
description: One of Newcastle's longer-standing micropubs/craft beer venues in the centre. A basement venue with steps leading down to a little bar painted dark green with niches and sturdy furniture. A fixture with a crowd of semi-regulars, dog walkers and those on the ale scene. Could perhaps use a bit more decoration and homeliness in some of its danker corners, but it's clear this is a superior option. (Added October 2023)

name: Wigan Central
description:
EBG Rating:: 8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Impressive array of local cask ales, craft keg and European bottles available, ever changing and award winning. 
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
An ale house situated under the railway arches, a station pub of sorts. Exposed brickwork with railway ephemera, heritage signage and RMT ties pinned above the bar. Two rooms, the main bar and a wider function style room with a piano.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A pleasant enough worn-in character to the place which keeps things going whether busy or quiet. An all-rounder with a largely more mature crowd of 30+ 
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Pies, tapas spreads, live music events, departure boards, snacks, limited outdoor seating
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Clearly fair value for the beer offerings.
description: Multi-award winning station-themed ale house with an RMT union connection displayed by virtue of dozens of ties pinned behind the bar. Situated under the station arches itself, embedding itself literally in the railway. The crowd come here for a social ale house atmosphere and strong drinks selection. While the overall ensemble isn't eye-catching or buzzing enough to knock you over, there is an amiable buzz and communal enough scene to be among alongside the top quality ales. This is helped along by occasional live music events and the sporting calendar (Added October 2023)

name: The Swan & Railway Hotel
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.7
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Cask ale specialists with a range of guests and Bass permanently on tap. Hotel so a reasonable range of alternatives.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
1898 station hotel with red brick exterior and eye-catching glazed tiled walls in the hallway, mosaic flooring. A stained glass window and impressive further piece above the bar. A long bar room with communal seating opposite the bar itself, with several siderooms to the left of the entrance. Traditional 'heritage' appearance.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
The rites and rituals of any station-adjacent pub adds to the atmosphere here, likewise the Hotel which is maintained. Sport on during the afternoon reflects what is an old geezers hold out until becoming livelier later.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Meals, snacks, jukebox, hotel rooms, sport on TV, occasional events
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Fair value for what is on offer, including for food.
description: A late 19th century station hotel well preserved with some striking heritage features from the mosaic floor on entry, to its tiled walls and preserved stained glass. The present-day function is as a cask ale boozer with the signature Bass pump proudly displayed and several changing guest ales. Basic pub grub, jukebox and sport on TV provides enough reason to linger whether quiet or busy. Somewhat of an institution. While the overall effect is very good rather than spectacular, you can't look past it on your visit to Wigan. (Added October 2023)

name: The White Hart Pub
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
description:

name: Brewer's Pride
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.3
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
The de facto Brewery Tap for Ossett with their range of beers on cask in pristine condition, with 1 or 2 guest ales. Beer focused but a relatively well stocked back bar.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A standalone brick building on an industrial estate. An odd location, but inside you'll find two lounges and a bar room in an opened out ale house. Still traditionally furnished with bench seats and two fireplaces. The backroom still retains décor from when it was taken over by Ossett.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Despite the remote location you may be surprised by the cast of locals even mid-week. Popular with somewhat of a loyal following who make the trek down here. Very cosy in autumn and winter with the fire running.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Pies and pub snacks, fireplaces, live music, community events
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Scrupulously fair value for food and drink.
description: A Free House, but in effect Ossett Brewing's nearest thing to a brewery tap, you'll find this 19th century building on its own down at hill by an industrial estate, a highly unlikely setting given the lack of neighbouring custom. Despite this, you'll find a loyal surprisingly plentiful band of customers even midweek. They're not mistaken, as this is a really lovely place. Two fireplaces at either side of the opened-out main room maintain cosiness, with communal seating around it. This pub is for drinking and socialising, not dining, although their pies and pasties are very good. Characterful rooms including the backroom which is largely unchanged from its former owners. With live events and a sense of community, this ticks all the boxes aside from its odd location! (Added October 2023)

name: Boons
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A strong selection of cask 
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
With two entrances, one through the beer garden off the main road into a smallish market town pub with central bar and communal seating around it. Traditional features such as beams above the bar, the pub is also festooned with flags.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A market town pub atmosphere, bustling with locals in the evening as it enjoys a central location. Very much a social space rather than a dining pub, with a range of people.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
TV, snacks, outdoor seating
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Fair value
description: A market town pub offering that bustling evening social scene that comes from a central location and plenty of passing footfall. The clientele is varied which results not only from location but the offerings from the outdoor seating, sport on TV and social niches. A traditional interior up to a point, but a pub that feels relevant. Cask ale fans can rejoice in a strong range of well-kept local ales to choose from. It's a place that ticks a lot of boxes. (Added October 2023)

name: Klášterní pivovar Porta Coeli
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Excellent range of central European lagers brewed on site with at least 6 taps at any one time. Perfunctory alternatives
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
The skeleton of the building has natural character, set in a monastery complex. Enter to find a small taproom with curved ceiling and brewkit on show. Perhaps overly brightly lit, plain and stark as a result.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A young crowd assemble at what is really a village pub, giving it an immediate sense of vibrancy and relevance, a big plus over the often middle aged dynamic of such places, however the place does close early.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, limited outdoor seating in summer. 
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Fair value for money given the selection being offered and the quality.
description: One of the superior brewpubs in a country where they are somewhat of a religion, its monastery setting adding character before you have even walked through the door. Upon arrival you'll find a taproom with classic curved ceiling on the historic premises, but it has been whitewashed and bright-lit. While that could render the place overly stark, that is balanced by a young, vibrant crowd and tasteful design choices. That, along with the excellent beer selection and fair value merits it worthy of inclusion. While it may look remote on a map, the town of Tisnov is only 35 minutes by train from Brno, with the monastery a 20 minute walk from there. Well worth exploring. (Added November 2023)

name: Táborka U Havlu
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Two bargain basement lagers with 1 tap of changing specialist beer from a range of brewers. Simple and predictable back bar and alternatives.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
Varnished wood strip panelling throughout, a small pubby vycep (taproom) leading to a larger pub room with pool table in the centre
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
When they say a true locals pub, they don't come any more local than this one. No tourists are going here, and even a lot of the local neighbourhood aren't. This is a true informal, smokey, grimy hangout that looks to have been parachuted in from the 1990s.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Pizza, snacks, pool table, TV, darts, occasional live music
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Superb value and one of the cheaper prices in the whole city.
description: A local's local, trust us, there are no tourists choosing to come to Pankrac in order to visit this pub. Tucked around the corner on a sliproad by a motorway, you only visit here if you know it in advance. The outside has an overly dramatic red Krusovice signage which is at least eye-catching. Enter to find a blast-from-the-past taproom with old geezers smoking and hollering at the TV, pool being played in the main room and very occasionally live music in the lounge. It's not a hostile place, although you may find it intimidating at first, the service is kind and the locals won't are not hostile. As you'd expect with a 'pajzl' of this kind, the prices are dirt cheap, but like U Prasivky, there's a nice surprise in store with a tap set aside for a rotating offer of specialist beers. This is a way of extending an olive branch to the next generation and secure the business' long term future - however, word is yet to spread about it. So, in a strange way, if you visit here you'll be ahead of the curve. (Added November 2023)

name: U Rumlíka
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.9
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
An superior range of non-standard and lesser spotted Czech lagers and ales. Beer focused so alternatives are perfunctory.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
Appealing appearance from the outside, warmth exuding from a corner pub with a back garden. Formerly a Kozel branded pub, now the hoarding is for Kamenice, a sign of the times. Inside there's a simple hospoda with a fairly charming low-key nature, which matches the neighbourhood it is set in.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A casual, calm local hangout with no music, just simple socialising inside or in the garden. This works both when quiet or busy.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Snacks, books, outdoor seating
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Entirely fair value for what is offered.
description: Near a park in a tucked out of the way corner of Prague but a short walk from Na Veseli tram stop is U Rumlika, a hilltop corner pivnice in a quiet neighbourhood. They specialist in multitap offerings of regional Czech lagers and craft styles, which is an upgrade from its previous life as a Kozel pub. However, they haven't thrown the baby out with the bathwater - you'll find the hospoda room intact and characterful, with simple seating around the taproom and an intimate feel. There's a pleasant yard too. Certainly worth journeying out to try. (Added November 2023)

name: U Rysů
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
A basic offering of Pilsner Urquell and Gambrinus on tap with a better back bar covering bases well.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Heritage building with eye-catching signage on a roadside. This leads to a bunker of reds and browns with World War memorabilia decorating the place. Some of it is quite eyebrow-raising but from all the reviews I have read there is no underlying political intent. It is worth knowing though.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A lot of character before anyone even steps through the door. A particularly worn-in feel, 'if these walls could talk'. Busier in evenings as the local neighbourhood turn out, while the service is very friendly even to outsiders.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, limited outdoor seating, games, TV
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Fair value for money for everything.
description: A way out in Zabehlice,, there are no nearby trams or buses so a walk from Sporilov tram or a bus along the village road will have to suffice. A historic building hosts this place, a worn-in and characterfully gloomy pub with plenty of identity and memories seemingly seeping from the walls. World War memorabilia decorates the place - we've checked all reviews of the pub and there doesn't appear to be any political leaning intended with it - but you may wish to bear that in mind while deciding on a visit. Service was cheery and friendly and we're interested to go back on a busy evening to see it at its zenith. (Added November 2023)

name: Hospoda Vršava
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Pivovar Malenovice and Dalesice, along with some more familiar names at this beer focused pub which offers Moravian wines and a stock back bar.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
A spacious pub with large taproom and side rooms. Chunky, solid-feeling with lots of square angles and heavy furniture. Appealing exterior signage and garden.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A village social scene which attracts visitors from the city too, which combines to have a friendly, but vibrant blend of regulars and occasional visitors. Informal, but not cliquey.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Pizza, Czech pub snacks, outdoor seating, takeaway, TV
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Good value for both food and drinks.
description: Connected via a bus route to the city centre of Zlin, this village pub combines a neighbourly feel with a certain sense of city vibrance. On the periphery but not isolated entirely. A friendly pub with attractive signage which lures you in. A basic layout of sturdy furniture and right angles, brightly lit, but not sterile or cookie cutter either. Service is friendly and they offer a strong range of local and regional beers, with Moravian wines. Pizza has been added to the usual basic Czech pub snacks which is welcome, and there is a terrace for summer socialising. Overall a versatile place you could take a group of young men or women, or families. A true pub feel, so worth an inclusion. (Added November 2023)

name: Hospůdka U Kovárny
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Pilsner Urquell and Prazdroj's Volba Sladku are the beer options - never a disaster but not cutting edge, with a good wine selection and competent back bar.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A very strong suit. This truly homely pub gives a hint of its style from the leafy, bespoke appearance of its exterior on a quiet side road. Inside, wood and warm hues are added to with a surprisingly non-minimalist, homely decor of ornaments, and oil paintings. A taproom with partition to a social lounge space to the rear.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Fabulous to be among the throng of people socialising. There's a lot of love for the place which is evident as you're part of it. Service is fair, and the place is popular. Don't be abashed, ask for space if there's part of a table free.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, TV, outdoor seating
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Unremarkable, fair.
description: Zlin's best pub, what it lacks in the latest beers from small independent brewers it compensates for in virtually every other department. A beautifully curated homely feeling pub which has that genius loci that so many try and fail to attain. Being among the throng, even for a night, is to have been part of that magic. Chunky wooden tables, large dressers, warm hues to the paintwork. Oil paintings and ornaments surround you, adding to the experience, making it feel more distinctive and giving the place its identity. The fact the regular beer is Pilsner Urquell is hardly a disaster, and the rotating Volba Sladku offer is a bonus. Look out for Moravian wines and a competent back bar of Czech liqueurs. An essential stop off if visiting the city, and a genteel counterbalance to the modern look of the city itself. (Added November 2023)

name: Pivovar Malenovice
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.3
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Brewery tap with a range of well-made traditional country-style Czech lagers with a few more modern alternatives, and a competent back bar.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Large premises on a village roadside. A historic interior of brick vaults and simple wooden seating. Informal and casual rather than hi-spec.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
The focus of the town's social scene as well as a popular venue for those living in larger towns nearby. Friendly service.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Takeaway, meals, snacks, outdoor seating, occasional events
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Superb value, these days you will not find such good beer so cheaply in most places in Europe.
description: Czechia's brewpub operations tend to either be well-financed slick restaurants or almost comically non-descript, so it is nice to discover a venue with a real identity, friendly staff and a social hub in what is a characterful old venue with brick vaults, curved ceilings and classic bar area. This is accessible off the main road but also via little track around a stream, which almost feels like entering a farm. The beers are certainly competent up and down the range, focusing on traditional Czech styles, properly served and extremely good value for money. Sit among a social neighbourly crowd where you get the impression most people know each other or at least live nearby. A proper pub. (Added November 2023)

name: Pub U Musea - Ponorka
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️
Basic uncomplicated selection of cheap booze and spirits.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
The submarine handle on the door reflects its vague theme. Once inside you'll find a typical unreconstructed smokey Czech boozer which has a certain warren like shape to it. Taproom near the door, and plenty of space to socialise further in.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Nothing less than a cult venue in the city, explicitly for informal, unpretentious socialising, to let your hair down and let someone else somewhere else worry about how they look or act. A little bit of an edge but safe and welcoming to newcomers.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Smoking permitted, live music, food (!), snacks, TV
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Fair value for the offering, deliberately budget focused wares.
description: A cult space in Olomouc, this unpretentious rock club known as the Submarine offers a space to let your hair down, smoke, hang out, and socialise and leave the modern world and its pretensions behind. Live music acts aren't so surprising but the presence of cooked meals is. Unsure who would eat here but the late kitchen is certainly useful in a pinch. Drinks offerings are basic but decent, but the real focus of the bar is to provide a meeting place for the city's alternative scene. Apparently more or less unchanged for 25 years. (Added November 2023)

name: U Čerta
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.6
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
description: Characterful gloomy pivnice with gothic theme, 'The Devil' is a predictable prompt as to what to expect. Candlelight and gothic artwork to enjoy a drink among a characterful interior. Closed for years between 2018-2022, we are delighted it has returned.  Not least because Trebon's nightlife is close to non-existent without it. (Added 2017)

name: Sitsimäe Kelder
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️
Basic offerings in line with the business model of aiming at the budget end of the market. Bases are covered however. For what it's worth, the beer is immaculately poured here.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
An old style dive, a basement of a house that looks literally like an illegal drinking den with the sole exception of a small red sign indicating the bar. Drop down to a small room, corrugated iron walls furnished with wooden stools. Warm and glowing inside with typical traditional pub signage and old beer kegs.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
The exciting feeling of dropping almost off the map sustains a visit here even in quiet times. This is the counterpoint to flash bars in the centre and virtually the sole survivor of the suburban Tallinn pubs.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Snacks, small grocery selection
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Easily the cheapest bar going in Tallinn.
description: Connected well by one of the most frequent tram lines, getting out of Tallinn through the industrial neighbourhoods is simple, but the journey does reinforce the different faces of the city. This is like connecting with the poorer end of the Baltics and Scandinavia, a surviving corner pub set in a basement opposite a kiosk. It truly is a surviving dive there are zero equivalents of elsewhere in Tallinn's suburbs. This makes it worth a try alone. You'll also find the cheapest pint in the city and a pleasingly ad hoc operation that strips back a lot of the surrounding b.s of pubs. Go while it still exists, as it seems certain the doors will close for good whenever the owner retires, and with it the entire suburban pub scene of a capital city. (Added November)

name: Pööbel
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.6
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Multitap pub with a balance of local craft, European classics and a few big names, a range cleverly reflecting the all-rounder nature of the place. Well-stocked back bar.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Attractive large wooden building painted light green and cream, but inside there is a modern design with big overhead lamps creating moody splodges of light in an otherwise low lit bar. Two main rooms with a snug to the side. There are thankfully some touches sympathetic to the building with bookshelves and original wood fittings visible. Chalk/blackboard style ceiling covered in writing. 
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
An all-rounder pub with a welcoming feel. Social but among disparate groups rather than the intermingling of somewhere like Valli Baar across the park. Warm, friendly hideout you could happily spend an afternoon in.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, music, community events, outdoor seating in summer
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
A little more expensive than expected given it is outside the centre and given the beer options are not all cutting edge.
description: Part of the essential core of Tallinn pubs, this well executed all-rounder in a large woodstrip building is set by the Hirvepark, away from the hustle of the old town. There is a corresponding calmness and hideout nature to the venue even with the modern makeover of the interior. Thankfully the lighting remains moody rather than starkly lit, and there are some sympathetic treatments of the original wood fittings. Beer and food options are selected to appeal to a broad range, and this is a place where you can just as easily bring a laptop and sit all day with coffee as you can turning up with a group for a late drink. All this without being overly bland makes it an important venue to bear in mind. (Added November 2023)

name: Valli Baar
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Basic lager tap options with better fridge choices. A simple, budget range covering hard liquor and wines.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Under cultural heritage preservation, a 1969 fit with wooden boards and mirrors. A one room affair with stools fixed to the floor around a U-shaped bar. Bank notes from around the world stapled to the fittings.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A bar where you can be in conversation with a total stranger almost instantly, there is a sense of bottled lightning to the place that is so rarely found. It isn't often quiet but there is a calm and character which makes those times enjoyable too.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️
Snacks
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Fair value, on the cheaper end for old town prices.
description: Among Estonia's most famous pubs, this simple unchanged boozer has been preserved from its late 60s era fit stemming from the days of Soviet occupation. It is now heritage listed by the city authorities which bodes well for its future. The modernist interior of wood panels, mirrors and stools fixed around a U-shaped bar has a certain academic appeal, but it is the countless good times spent here that really cements its reputation. One of the simplest places in the world to strike up a conversation with a stranger, the bar-top format encourages cross-chat, as do the occasionally gregarious patrons. A good range of people from youngsters to old grizzlies with a certain rosey-cheeked middle aged contingent enjoying the same basic drinks at budget prices. Famous for its herring snacks and spicy concoction 'Millimallikas', liqueur, which should be avoided unless you're feeling reckless. Very few Baltic bars honestly feel like an institution, but this place feels more of an institution than many English pubs, which really underscores how special it is. (Added November 2023)

name: Koht
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.6
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Estonian craft beer with some other European options supplemented by an adjoining bottleshop. As far as beer goes, very strong. Basic back bar for alternatives and café style options.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Tucked in a courtyard, a sign outside cryptically suggests it's open when it's open and closed when it's closed. Enter to find a small vaulted room with fireplace and lounge style furniture. The curved ceilings decorated with bank notes around the world, and there's a fish tank on a ledge. 
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Supremely cosy in the winter months with the fire going in the intimate vaulted space. Set down with a nice beer and company, you will not want to leave.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Pizza (only some nights), bottle shop, fireplace, books, board games, occasional events, limited outdoor seating in summer.
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Surprisingly fair value given the central location. While not cheap by Eastern European standards it certainly competes with local ones. 
description: Plainly called "Koht", or 'place' in Estonian, but also known as Golden Lion (after the building) or Moonshine Bar, you'll need to head into a courtyard to spot the door to the corner of the place. It's hardly a hidden bar, but those easily confused may need some reassurance that yes, that black door is the entrance to the bar. Inside you'll find a small space inside old vaults with a real fire in the corner, fish tank on a ledge and comfortable lounge seating. In winter (6 months a year in Tallinn) it's a supremely cosy spot with limited seating, but we found no difficulty on any of the 3 occasions finding a spot to sit. The beer selection is excellent with 8 or so taps covering local beer to European classics, with an adjoining bottle shop which expands the range further. There is no doubt this occupies the vast majority of the purpose of the bar, but there are alternatives and the bar retains a slight hint of café to it as a result. Simply an unmissable stop off when in the city. (Added November 2023)

name: Vana Villem Pub
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.7
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Their own label beers compliment an otherwise mainstream European selection. A decent back bar with Vana Tallinn liqueurs, it is fully equipped.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Eye-popping recreation of a Gin Palace but in Estonia, surely some intellectual property has been purloined in its resemblance to some of England's pubs. A large galleried hall dominated by central bar with rising plinth guiding the eye towards a stained glass inset ceiling feature. Wood fittings and comfortable seating based in niches.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Warm, welcoming and pubby overall.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Meals, snacks, TV, own label beers
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Fair for food, slightly more expensive for drinks, although there are multi-buy deals on offer, suitable for groups.
description: Dating from 1997, this extraordinary venue hasn't so much as taken the leaf out of the book of English gin palaces as stolen away with the whole damn tome. Maintained immaculately, there are so few signs of wear and tear it feels like it could have opened last week. A central bar which strongly resembles The Old Joint Stock in Birmingham or The Old Bank of England in London with a stack rising and drawing your eyes towards a marvellous stained glass ceiling. The pub is galleried in that familiar fashion with levels and niches to choose from. The rest of the concept is familiar - decent grub and decent beer, with the addition of their own beers which add a further point of interest.  While it is outside the old centre, it is easily reached on the main road between the airport and centre and should be strongly considered. It is also warm and well-heated during winter. (Added November 2023)

name: Mr. Mauruse Pub
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.6
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
A compact range from the typical macro suppliers, with a couple of lesser spotted exceptions - such as Kasteel Rouge on our visit. A competent back bar,
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Basement venue tucked away in a building set apart from the road. When inside green lamps, dark wood tables, leather seats and bookshelves give the place a gentleman's study appearance.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A bunker type atmosphere that gives the place a kind of timeless inertia. Shut away from ground level it could be 2pm or 2am, you'd never know. Relaxing and warm, somewhere to get away from things rather than start a party.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, books, newspapers
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Typical prices for the centre, not unusually cheap or expensive.
description: Mr. Maurus is a fictitious person from AH Tammsaari's book Truth and Justice. Mr. Maurus was the director of a private school in it). Why it has been applied to this pub we are yet to find out, but you'll find a very reliable basement venue kitted out in the manner of a gentleman's study. Brooding green table lamps, dark wood and bookshelves provide an intimate atmosphere in a timeless basement space where it could be 2pm or 2am. Beer choices are solid, but unspectacular, while food here gets good reviews for its hearty portions. One not even some locals are aware of due to being set apart from the main road and the centre. Definitely one to bear in mind. (Added November 2023)

name: III Draakon
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Deliberately spartan range of unmarked goods, which includes their own frothy beer - light or dark, with wines and liqueurs also available.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Situated in the medieval era town hall, this surprisingly small venue is comprised of two rooms with stone walls, stone floors, chunky tables and candles. Although Medieval-themed, this is very much on the minimalist 'Inn' concept rather than any faux heraldry or big budget idea.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A love or hate idea, leaning heavily into a rustic centuries old concept of a Medieval inn rather than an enormous dining hall. You order and receive food and drink at the bar and place your empties in a basket. The two rooms are truly befitting of the concept - cosy, rustic, satisfyingly cro-magnon.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, gifts
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
Slightly higher than average but fair given the most central of central locations.
description: An admittedly love or hate venue - we loved it, those who are averse to Medieval style venues had best look elsewhere. However, we may be able to keep you hooked with the promise that this is not your average Medieval themed restaurant with huge dining halls, faux heraldry and impossible platters of meat. Instead, you'll find a surprisingly small, simply middle ages inn, two stone-walled, candlelit rooms with simple seating and a simple concept. Two women staff the bar and kitchen, one serving drinks and food, the other cooking. You order and collect direct from them, then take your wares to a table of your choice. The interior is suitably gloomy and almost hysterically rustic and cro-magnon in its approach. Food orders are spartan - Elk broth, sausages with gherkin you fish out of an upturned barrel, and ribs - that's more or less it - you can buy carrot and other veg separately. The beer comes in two options - light or dark and the price is described always as "moneys" rather than Euros. There are some unfortunately unavoidably cheesy/tourist elements but the core of the experience remains sound - candles, beer, stone, wood, warmth and cheer. (Added November 2023)

name: Spiżarnia Malborska
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.9
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A non-standard regional lager on tap (still Polish lager so don't get too excited), but the main draw is the extensive bottle selection covering a variety of styles including from smaller producers. Competent back bar.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Looks like a selection of huts from the outside, woodstrip exterior which leads to a gloomy, candlelit interior with antique decor falling somewhere between a Western saloon an an abandoned house.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Very characterful venue enhanced by a roaring fireplace. Largely locals outside of the high season.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Limited meals, snacks, outdoor seating, fireplace, takeaway
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Very good value for money in this day and age in Poland
description: In a town without so much as a pub to speak of, it's impressive that Spizarnia not only offers a pub business but one focused primarily on drinks and socialising. There is usually a limited selection of food - pretty good food at that, but that plays a supporting role. The interior and atmosphere are superb with a fireplace kicking out heat among an ensemble of antique furniture and faded wood everywhere you look. Drink local beer and fun craft styles from a large selection among the candlelight and hazy gloom. We can enthusiastically recommend a visit. (Added December 2023)

name: Bar "80dziesiątka"
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️
Only bottled beers - basic at that. Some spirits and liqueurs too.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A surviving shack, relic from the PRL days with old counter and menu with daily items scrawled on. Basic seating that is nevertheless warmly lit and welcoming.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
An experience you won't find easily these days as the old working class venues die out. Still well-used by local workers knocking off their shifts and a social space of sorts.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Hot meals, groceries, snacks
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Scrupulously good value for money.
description: The Gdansk shipyard is emblematic of working culture not only in Europe but worldwide, the epicentre of the solidarity movement. A working class remnant of that era, this relic from a bygone era allows a peek into what life was like. The experience becomes even more realistic when the shipworkers arrive with their muddy boots and high vis jackets! A one-room shack with unchanged counter, bottle opener attached to a chain, old sign in/savings book shelf and handwritten menu gives a flavour of what to expect. Is it a pub or bar? Well, everyone will have their views, but here you can come to socialise and yes, drink, in a casual environment. Scrupulously honest, the staff will look you in the eye as you are one of them, even as a tourist. It isn't somewhere you would choose for a night out but neither are many venues. One for the purists, historians and curious, intrepid explorers to get stuck into. (Added December 2023)

name: No To Cyk
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️
Basic beer, vodka and liqueur offerings from a mainstream selection.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
PRL-era decor plasters the walls with plenty of retro adornments besides. Enter through a submarine like heavy door into a two storey bar with mezzanine area.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
The place can be 4 or 5 rows deep at the bar or similarly easy to find a seat or leaning post - it depends when you visit. The atmosphere is generally pleasant with the decor mixing in with a good buzz, although the music may be mainstream for some, it's hardly unusual for such a bar.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️
Snacks, late opening
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Not particularly notable.
description: Communism themed bar - though quite light on the kitsch, a late bar that gets lively on weekends - but the fact it's almost always there as an option makes it a practical choice you can return to when it dies down. One to go for fun and when it gets late rather than for any kind of epicurean exploration or private space. (Added December 2023)

name: Cafe Lamus
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.6
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Czech lagers and Polish craft seems an honest admission of who does what best, and there's a good range of alternatives too.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Colourful vintage chic with a 1970s aesthetic in a small bar with an even smaller backroom. 
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Loungey, occasionally moody, perhaps lacking an edge but the friendly atmosphere compensates.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Snacks, board games, book
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Considering the competition and the bar's role in the city at large, pretty good value here.
description: Stylish and loungey, Lamus has been on the corner of Lawendowa for many years now but it stays well maintained, not over-subscribed and fairly priced, which is to its credit. Small, but friendly with the usual array of board games and books to get stuck into as you sprawl across the loungey vintage furnishings in a 70s aesthetic. Czech lagers and Polish craft are available with a very decent range of alternatives too. When exploring the old town this is a place to keep up your sleeve. (Added December 2023)

name: Graciarnia
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.6
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Strong tap selection of Polish craft beers including some local efforts, with some cans and bottles. Decent enough back bar for mixers, cocktails, shots etc.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Basement pub in an L shape with fairylights and shelves of board games. Fairly tight for space but not outright cramped.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Popular neighbourhood venue with a young crowd of Polish locals, friendly and welcoming, busy and buzzy
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Pub quiz, snacks, board games, books, assorted other events, seasonal offerings
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
On par with the city in general
description: A popular basement bar in Wrzeszcz district - that underpins any attempt to start a bar crawl around this neighbourhood with its handy location. The young crowd makes it feel vibrant but not tacky - craft beer, board games and quizzes is the speed of things here, and you'll feel welcome from setting foot through the door. The array of amenities is of course strategically positioned to get you to stay and buy more drinks - but at least here they are worth drinking with a compact but well chosen spread of Polish craft with the odd Belgian/German appearance sprinkled in. Certainly among the superior bars in Gdansk. (Added December 2023)

name: Cafe Szafa
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.7
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Unexciting lager options with some middle bottle choices is augmented at least with a competent backbar and cocktail menu.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A diminutive bar with a small space at the entrance with mezzanine and booth of old theatre seats. The design takes in eclecticism, shabby chic, funky, off-beat, all of that and is colourfully list - the overall impression is very positive.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A characterful spot which is generated by its decor and the casual/informal atmosphere of ex-pats and Poles hanging out. The energy level is about right for early/mid-evening drinks.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Snacks, limited outdoor seating, games
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Happy hour deals are pretty decent, otherwise you'll find city centre prices.
description: A handy find, Café Szafa is removed from the heart of the old town action but on the map enough to attract a balance of locals, ex-pats and the odd tourist which gives it a good sense of vibrancy. Being Poland, the bar is executed with a typically eclectic range of antiques, salvage and quirky decorations, colourfully lit, giving it an offbeat, fun, but not arch or pretentious feel. With some happy hour deals worth noting and a generally friendly vibe, this is well worth adding to your roster, even if we wish the drinks selection could be brought up to date a little. (Added December 2023)

name: Pub Spółdzielnia
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Browar Amber beers on tap with a compact bottle selection that perhaps isn't quite cutting edge for Poland these days, but is nevertheless reasonable. Competent back bar.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Converted retail space into a 70s style lounge/living room with large rugs, sofas and tables covering the sprawling floors. Bar to the rear. Vintage furniture and cabinets by the walls.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Social and entirely untouristy due to the location, one to really see what's going on in Polish suburbia.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, books, board games, events
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Good value overall.
description: There is no point dragging you out to the fringes of Oliwa district from central Gdansk without good reason, but here it is. It actually doesn't take that long at all by tram or train. A lovely neighbourhood pub set in a retail arcade that has transformed the space into a pubby/lounge like room of comfortable, vintage furniture and social space, with large carpets and tasteful choices all-round. It's more spacious than it may seem at first, so be sure to wander around and pick your favourite spot. The atmosphere can rise and fall due to the tendency for large groups to arrive/leave - but the underlying impression is positive. With tap selections from Browar Amber, the first Polish craft brewery since independence, and a reasonable range of alternatives, there's enough to keep you occupied here before moving on. Take a look at the train and tram options and you'll discover it really isn't that far away after all. (Added December 2023)

name: Polufka Pub
description:
EBG Rating:: 8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Superb selection of Polish craft beer in the fridge, with 8 options on keg. Alternatives are perfunctory.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
A neighbourhood pub, that aside of the stylish signage outside is a live-in, unpretentious and characterfully battered boozer. Football scarves line the ceiling in the main bar room with a wall full of board games to choose from and Tv opposite the bar. Downstairs a surprising amount of basement space opens up with booth seating.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Very much a locals hangout, not a place you'll pass on the tourist trail, and all the better, with a true pub atmosphere every bit as good as you'd find in England or Ireland.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
This is what the pub is really all about. It serves its community with live events, football screenings, quiz, books, board games, and seasonal festivities.
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Fair value for money considering all factors.
description: One of Gdansk's brightest sparks on the pub scene, it isn't one you'll wander past but one you'll need to make a concerted point of fitting into your schedule - but it's worth it. Among all pubs in the city it's difficult to think of one that serves its community better than Polufka, with more amenities than you can shake a stick at, and an environment that is democratic, wholesome, shorn of pretentiousness but not mediocre or conventional either. You may not take a first date here but you might take them every week after if things go well. The beer selection is terrific both on tap but particularly the array of fridge options, while the hoard of board games, books, football matches, quizzes, live events and so much more keep you hooked. Plain and simply, there should be one of these pubs on every street. (Added December 2023)

name: The New Inn
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Ales from breweries located in the village itself, with a range of cask and keg to choose from, vastly superior to most rural offerings as a result and a standout in the region.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
Traditional roadside village pub with a pubby ground floor and social space set out primarily for drinking and socialising, with a games room to the side. A dining room upstairs and hotel rooms to the side show the scale of the operation is bigger than first meets the eye. Plain, homely decoration in large part that at least hasn't gone down the route of anodyne grey/beige washing.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Popular village pub with cast of locals complimented by the hotel visitors and lunch trade. Friendly and welcoming feel.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Meals, snacks, outdoor seating, beer shop, hotel, fireplaces, pool table, darts
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Fair value overall, but nothing overly notable.
description: Cropton's brewing operations are its most notable present day feature and here is the pub that shows it off. A vastly superior cask and keg range by the standards of usual village pubs and a popular destination pub not only for beer fans but locals, day-trippers and hotel guests. The set up is unpretentious and typically Yorkshire, gladly ungentrified and the presence of a games room as well as the upstairs dining room shows it off as a true all-rounder. (Added December 2023)

name: The Sun
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Known for a rotation of guest cask ales from regional brewers, but a decent selection of whiskies are notable too. Keg and fridge options are the let down.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Stone cottage facing the main road, enter to a small front room and quarter circle wooden bar, with pump clips lining the ceiling and beams, communal seating in the various corners. There is an barn extension with exposed rafters for games and overspill.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A true neighbourhood atmosphere, by locals for locals, but friendly and not especially cliquey.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Community events, petanque court, TV, darts, books, board games, snacks.
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Nothing unusual
description: A short walk out from the centre to this expanded stone cottage facing a street. Inside you'll find the original cosy pub with a homely layout and social seating. Offering a rotation of guest ales, good selection of quality whiskies and a host of amenities, this is a community pub with a strong local following and atmosphere to match. Simply the standout option in the town. (added December 2023)

name: The Hillary Step
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
High quality ale selection covering local cask and craft + european Keg, but it is not beer dominated with a decent back bar for alternatives.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Set in a small row of shops, a heated outdoor area obscure the front, but once inside you'll find an effective a refit in Art Deco style with aged wood, lamplight and a long drag to the rear of the bar up a couple of steps. 
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
