Atmospheric venue with a natural feel to its ambience, whether busy or quiet, somewhere you could go on your own or with a group. Woozy early evening tipple seems to be the core of the appeal. Despite the refit and smart bar area there is a casual, neighbourly feel without much pretense.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, books, board games, occasional live events
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Standard value for money though not any less than you'd pay in central Manchester.
description: Well worth the 9 minute walk from the tram stop to this refit bar that's almost out on its own in Whalley Range. A stylish and atmospheric bar with Deco influences, but it isn't stuffy or upright at all, instead there's a casual neighbourly feel and an excellent beer selection. Overall it stands out a fair way above the local competition and if it were in central Manchester no doubt we'd be there a lot more often. (Added January 2024)

name: The Barrel
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.9
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Thwaites pub, a limited selection of cask ale but very well kept, the IPA particularly good.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A high street pub, walk in off the street to a low-slung cottage with a small intimate bar with upholstered bench seating opposite the bar and around a centrepiece fireplace with the eponymous barrel fitted above it. A backroom is along similar lines with a further fireplace.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Very cosy and welcoming, a social rather than food focus and a lovely environment to be in.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Snacks, games, fireplace, outdoor seating
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Typical for the area.
description: Thwaites do not have a spotless record for maintaining their traditional pubs in an unspoilt fashion, but here is one of their finer examples. Walk in directly from the high street to a cosy, intimate and immediately attractive pub with two roaring fireplaces and comfortable seating. The emphasis is social rather than foody too, so you'll see visitors and village residents rubbing shoulders. A superior example of a pub of this style and worth seeking out if in the area. (Added January 2024)

name: The Millowners Arms
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.6
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A decent range covering cask and keg with some local and independent brewers. Competent back bar.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Striking ex-industrial building with a traditional pub fitting. Large fireplace sadly not in use but tastefully decorated. Upholstered bench seating and plenty of pillars/joists from its original use.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Natural ambience from its original industrial use and tasteful decor, normally sleepy and cool, but can become raucous on events nights, festivals, and in summer.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Outside seating, snacks, foods, museum, occasional events, board games
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Fair value for money
description: The opposite of a pub you'd walk past by accident, this is somewhere with footfall only from Museum visitors. Aside of that it is frequented by people in the know. It's a difficult task even then given the number of good pubs in the vicinity to persuade people to travel further into Kelham Islands industrial heart. The museum is opposite and the pub itself is part of that complex, repurposed tastefully into a colourful, atmospheric and quite dusky surrounding of exposed brick, fairylights and props. The offering mixed traditional with modern, there is social bench seating and board games to attract people to hang around. Its best suit is in summer with outdoor tables by the river, which culminates in the beer festival days where the place reaches its zenith. One not to overlook. (Added January 2024)

name: Les 3 Singes
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.6
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A very strong multitap selection covering regional French beers complimented with high quality Belgian and German offerings. Limited alternatives.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
A small terrace out front, with a narrow interior and modern refit, light green ceiling panels with some of the monkey theme present in and around it. Perhaps missing an essential hook or identity.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A pleasant place to hang out, calm in the afternoon then lively and social in the winter.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Snacks, outdoor seating, occasional events
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Still high but on par with the offerings in the area
description: Beer specialists, this is part of an emerging chain (also in Mulhouse) focusing on a wide range of French, Belgian and German beers, which feels appropriate for its location. The 3 Monkeys theme is not overbearing, in fact they could hopefully do a little more to add to its identity and décor, but the space is pleasant to be in and clearly social and superior in the city. A standout recommendation therefore. (Added January 2024)

name: Les Incorruptibles
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.7
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Considering this is an all-comers tavern and one of the main drinking spots in Colmar, the choice is actually superior with specialist beers such as Paix-Dieu alongside the Alsace regulars on tap and a competent back bar
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Situated in a historic timberframe building with a terrace outside, the corner location stand out. Inside you'll find a traditional tavern with wood beams and social seating, which has been colourfully decorated.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A clear sense this is one of the mainstays in the city, with a broad clientele. Lively and pacey.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
TV, snacks, outdoor seating, occasional events
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Fair value overall but nothing outstanding.
description: A charming name and a historic building is a good start. This is a French tavern with a social drinking focus and a broad clientele up and down the classes. Unpretentious which will put off people looking for a refined experience, but the product is there, with some superior beer options on a surprisingly long tap list and the interior retains a sense of intimacy as befits the timber frame style, chunky wood and warm cosy surroundings. The pace and social energy along with the music and TV keeps things buzzing along even during the afternoons. It may put some people off, but it's an effective operation. (Added January 2024)

name: La Taverne Française
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.4
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Alsace bieres with Belgian bottles, with the usual Picon/Cynar bottles ready on demand. Competent back bar.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Corner pub with a lived-in, informality, plastered with event posters, furnished with simple wooden seating. Somewhere between alternative and bourgeois. There is additional seating in a cosy backroom.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Friendly, young crowd with a social scene even during afternoons, owing to its versatility. Liberal/left leaning.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Occasional events, limited outdoor seating, snacks, board games
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Fair value with some special offers.
description: Among Strasbourg's finest bars, the sense of institution pervades as you enter a busy bar. This could be mid afternoon or late at night - it's a fixture of the social scene. With a young audience of students and young professionals, you'll need to pick your moment well to find a seat or table. Friendly and sociable, this is a versatile spot suitable for any time of day or year, with a lived-in and personalised interior with a good spot of personality. Drinks are decent enough with some Alsace offerings, and a broad range, with some special offers, though here the purpose is more functional, they are not intending to be specialists. There will be enough to keep most people happy. A must-visit venue in Strasbourg. (Added January 2024)

name: Kitsch'n Bar
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.3
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A superior range of tap beer above average although not fully specialist, you'll find what's on offer a nice surprise. Broad bar/café alternatives also available catering for a good range.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Kitsch by name, kitsch by nature, the name is a play on words and here we have a bar decked out like a fever dream of a retro kitchenette. Utensils hanging from the ceiling, dozens of clocks on the wall. Stuffed animals and hilariously bad-taste cross-stitch are just a flavour of what you'll encounter. A small bar with a main room to the right and smaller area to the left of the bar as you enter.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Social  and informal with an easy versatility - it could be somewhere you meet for coffee, or for evening fun. A range of people between students and early 40s.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, board games, live events, special offers, limited outdoor seating (seasonable)
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Some fair value to be had here overall.
description: A truly well-named bar that gives a strong clue what to expect on entry. Kitchen and kitsch combine in a colourful collection of bad taste and eclectica among a kitchenette type environment. The social scene is strong here with a friendly feel and sense of regular meeting place, and a superior selection of drinks is very welcome too. Very enjoyable and high up the list of any bars to visit in Strasbourg. (Added January 2024)

name: LAÀB - L'Amer À Boire
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.2
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
One of Strasbourg's strongest port of calls for specialist beers, especially in the city centre. Several taps of Alsace and nearby regional beers from small independent brewers. This is supported with a good back bar of alternatives.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
Tucked around a corner and situated just off the road, dive into what feels like a winter cabin with wood strip and warm lighting - modern rather than rustic. A one room affair normally with a basement for events. Instruments are pinned to the wall and the musical leanings are quickly obvious.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Musical get-togethers light up the atmosphere here and provide a joy and camaraderie to proceedings. Service is friendly and the atmosphere is social and relaxed. Nothing to dislike.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Snacks, live music, limited outdoor space (seasonal), other events, instruments
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Considering the quality of produce, fair value.
description: Laab's concept is music and beer, cultural concepts we're very much in favour of, but it is notable how the pointed business concept makes you think that the two sometimes don't go hand in hand, whether that's the dreadful offerings at arena gigs or other specialist music venues. Here though, the selection shines and is to be enjoyed in an environment that is very much a pub. Warm with a slight cabin-like feel even with its modern fittings, the places energy is drawn from live performances and a social scene enjoying high quality beer from small independent Alsatian brewers. The bar offers quiz nights, comedy shows and overall tries to provide for its community. An essential stop off on any trip to Strasbourg. (Added January 2024)

name: Le Grincheux
description:
EBG Rating:: 8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Extraordinarily good. Somewhere you can easily find 4 beers from a modern Czech independent brewery alongside a treasure trove of whiskies and rums. This is an epicurean's dream.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
A strange frontage with outdated signage and an automatic door isn't an auspicious start but it gets better inside with a wood fit bar area, games area opposite and a backroom with balcony and chandelier. A mish-mash which sort of hangs together despite things pulling in different directions.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
An obvious central mainstay with a wash of people coming and going, from those seeking specialist drinks to the average group of friends out for the evenings. 
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Darts, table football, snacks, board games
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Fair value and on par with the city centre.
description: Epicureans take note! With an enormous spirits board and 15+ beer taps focusing on high quality offerings from around Europe, you'll be in hog's heaven. The atmosphere of the bar is not particularly arch hipster, it's more informal if anything with a wooden interior, games area and an audience interest in casual hangouts just as much as superior produce. There are a few elements pulling the place this way and that, but it sneaks up on you, as will some of the whiskies. (Added January 2024)

name: Code Bar
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.7
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Inventive cocktails on a slimline, but award winning menu. Back bar of alternatives is available.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
The ground floor is like wandering into a Manhattan dive bar with notes on the ceiling, top hats as lampshades along a small simple narrow bar. Downstairs is a different affair with curved strip lighting and vaulted ceiling. The upstairs is far preferable.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
If you are lucky enough to grab a seat (try opening) at the main bar then it's a buzzy, social atmosphere with a sense of fun about it.
Amenities/Events: ❤️
Snacks
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
Undeniable expensive on the upper end of what's available around the city, with the quality coming reasonably close to matching.
description: Code Bar has made some of the tastemakers and listmakers guides in the past and now it joins ours. As with many cocktail bars it takes its inspiration from Manhattan speakeasies, from the bell for entry to the informal, small narrow bar area decorated with bank notes and top hats, with the cocktail making a kind of performance happening in front of you. Arrive early for any chance whatsoever of obtaining a seat on that level, or you'll be sent downstairs to what is sadly a bit of an overflow area. The cocktail options are slimline but distinctive, and reach a high standard if not quite the prices it thinks are merited. For the bar buzz and sense of fun, this is a popular place that's well worth a look. (Added January 2024)

name: Brasserie de la Lanterne
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Competent brewpub range although offerings can be limited depending on the season. Simple but functional range of alternatives.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Pleasant space, situated down a side alley, the signage is low key and upon entering the room is small and fairly intimate too with the brewkit opposite the bar, and large chunky communal tables in between.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Pleasant, informal and social. There's a sense the place has been around a while, and perhaps no longer the new young thing, but also a sense of sturdy reliability and a fixture on the map.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, shop, events
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Reasonably good value considering the location and what's on offer.
description: A central European brewpub may bring to mind sprawling halls and huge dinnerplates, but here you'll find something much more low key. A small deliberately informal drinks-focused pub which blends a modern and traditional interior to create what is an understated but reliable and affordable hangout spot. They've been around a while but that does come with its pluses and minuses. In certain seasons the tap and bottle offerings can be better than others, but the beer is competent and makes a virtue of making themselves as small a target as possible rather than shooting for the stars with a bottle rocket. A pleasant social hangout that's lacking pretense and overall pretty appealing. (Added January 2024)

name: La Perestroïka
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.6
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
6 tap beers including 1 seasonal rotation, mainly from the local macro brewery behind Meteor. Limited bottle selection but competent range of alternatives to beer.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Decorated with Soviet era propaganda, but the theme is not overbearing, it sits in the background. Enter to find a lower bar room, raised rear room and atrium for semi-outdoors seating at the back. Worn in and lived in, you'll see the graffiti starting to crawl up the wood strip panels.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Slight station pub vibes with its proximity to the Gare, with transient custom as well as people simply chilling out. A more diverse hangout spot, this is a place with a more multicultural audience than some other bars in Strasbourg which is to its credit, although just watch out for the odd stragglers here and there.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️
Snacks, outdoor seating
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Fair value for Strasbourg across the menu
description: An unusual theme, with an understated but effective execution, the Soviet propaganda posters draw the eye but also sit in the background to what is a homely lived-in café bar and informal hangout. The audience is multicultural (if male dominated) which makes a change from some others around the city, with the main drawback being the occasional station bar problem of seedy people coming and going. A very friendly and welcoming team of female staff help keep things on-kilter though, and the affordable prices and sense of authenticity help bring this one around to deserving an inclusion overall. (Added January 2024)

name: Aedaen Speakeasy
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.6
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Highly inventive, avant-garde and sometimes moving over to downright bizarre bordering on mind-boggling cocktail creations. They are nonetheless highly distinctive and provide an experience you won't forget in a hurry.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Enter a pizza restaurant and walk past the bar and the oven to the back of the room. A shelf distracts you from what appears to be the door. Pull the shelf and crouch underneath to enter the bar. An odd bespoke space with a high ceiling has been decked out in a half-boudoir, half fanciful Alice in Wonderland style, with sofas around a spacious bar area. There's a glass partition to a smoking area with further seating.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A sense of fun and whimsy to finding the place adds to the experience, while the atmosphere can rise and fall, it still feels like you are in somewhere secret and secluded.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️
Snacks, smoking area
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
Cocktails perched at the high end, which they try to justify with the distinctive menu and sense of ceremony to the presentation. Overall worth it for a one off experience. 
description: A secret bar accessible through a pizza takeaway, although locals don't bat an eyelid suggesting they've seen it all before as you walk towards the back room to a suspicious looking door. Pull the shelve and crouch under the partition to enter the hidden space. A retrofit interior which would clearly never have been intended for a bar of this sort proves an odd base for this place. They've done a reasonable job with the decor, somewhere between boudoir and fantasy, with a moose head that's so large you'd be fair to wonder if they'd dropped anything stronger in your drink. The cocktails follow this theme with some very distinctive creations taking in custard, trout eggs, roast chicken and far more besides in an attempt to dazzle you with bravura and ambition. Whether it quite hits the mark or not will depend on your tastes, but at least they're aiming high. Overall the novelty factor is high and on a one-off visit to Strasbourg this comes easily recommended. (Added January 2024)

name: Les Berthom
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Beer focus from a decent range, leaning heavily towards Belgium. Options are superior but largely familiar, the format is a little superseded these days.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
Corner bar with an appealing exterior, part of Strasbourg's historic tour. Inside there's a pleasant enough space dominated by the bar with niches and leaning posts, but it is still a modern fit of a traditional bar.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
The bar has been around long enough to gather a cast of frequent visitors which mingle among tourists most of the year in an effective blend. There's a bit of pace and energy to the place.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Snacks, music, TV, games
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Considering the central location, prices are not extortionate, mainly the going rate for the city.
description: Berthom has proven a reliable format for France, a chain with similar bars across different cities focusing on Belgian beer and a casual drinks-centred social environment that has plenty of familiar traditional appeal while being modern in some aspects too - a versatile all-rounder that is possibly no-one's favourite but never far from the answer to the question 'where next?' (Added January 2024)

name: Slip Inn
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.6
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A superior range for a neighbourhood pub with good cask, keg ales and lagers, with a standard back bar for alternatives.

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Traditional pub in a brick building with bar room on entrance, side-snug and back room with TV. Back yard extends the capacity further. Interior of cushioned upholstered seats and simple tables, unspoilt.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Plenty of unreconstructed charm in the old fittings, while this is a distinctly untouristy spot in York off the usual trail. Gets very busy on certain match days, but can be low key and chatty too.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Snacks, board games, TV, outdoor seating
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
About standard for free house prices these days, certainly not cheap.
description: What you might picture as a 'proper pub' - neighbourly ungentrified hangout spot with a homely feel. Well reviewed. Smallish place with the usually appealing down to earth and non-corporate environment that swings from low-key murmurs and private chat to busy and boisterous on football days. A three room setup with a side snug and back yard, there are different areas to pick from that have their own feel, quite unusual for such a small place. It took a few visits to win us around, but if you're familiar with The Swan, Phoenix, Golden Ball nearby and enjoy those, you need to add the Slip Inn to that last. (Added January 2024)

name: The Grayston Unity
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.6
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
description: Relocated from its miniature former location by the town hall, but keeping its style. Quirky in places as some posters and signage will confirm, there's a nice charm to the place that feels DIY rather than corporate. A good drinks range that feels good rather than great for somewhere like Halifax, but is pretty strong overall still and fair value. The larger venue doesn't have the same spirit as the previous one but its versatility may be a saving grace. We look forward to revising on busier occasions to verify that. (Added January 2024)

name: Chequers Inn
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.4
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
5 cask ales, which is decent these days for a rural pub, all from independent Yorkshire brewers. Typical back bar alternatives.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Village pub refit in the 1960s then preserved since. A stone Inn dating from the 16th century with a warren of small fireplace-lit rooms around a central bar. Low beams, settles, communal cushioned seating and thick carpet. 
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Cosy, traditional and intimate with village life accentuated by weekend daytrippers. Calm and enjoyable on a weekday, with busy trade Saturday and Sunday
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, books, fireplaces, outdoor seating, dog friendly, Wifi
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Matches the product and the location.
description: With a connection to the local church, it was only in 2012 that Chequers began opening on Sundays, and that traditional spirit appears to be behind its interior, largely unaltered since a 1962 refit. A 16th century stone cottage with some extensions added, the core of the pub is a series of small lounge rooms around a central bar. The low beams, fireplaces and traditional tables place you in an idyllic, supremely cosy rural setting. With a range of Yorkshire ales on cask, bookshelf with plenty of local interest, dog friendly approach, terrace for summer days, and straight talking welcome from the staff, there is a quintessentially Yorkshire feel to the place. A throwback but one that is still busy and beloved. (Added February 2024)

name: The Free Trade
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.9
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️
Local cask ales with typical low-rent keg options. A good pint of Guinness however.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
One of only two Northumberland pubs on CAMRA's inventory of Heritage interiors. Little altered since 1910, a wood-fit partition screens the bar area.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️
Depends on how busy it is and who the crowd is, but there is a natural ambience due to the natural character of the decades past. 
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Fireplace, TV, pool, snacks
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Very good value.
description: File under 'love or hate', this bunker boozer will delight those looking for an impromptu conversation, characterful surroundings and a throwback atmosphere, less so people seeking a wall full of different beers. One of only 2 pubs in Northumberland with a CAMRA Heritage interior, its history is apparent almost as soon as you walk through the entrance with its quirky partitioned layout and deep set patina of smoke, lacquer and damp. A fireplace helps keep things cosy, while a pool room to the rear is well used by local times. A real curio that's well worth seeking out. (Added February 2024)

name: The Barrels
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.9
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A Northumberland real ale Mecca with several well-kept classics. Compact but reasonable back bar.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Curved corner frontage which leads into a small bar with seating raised in the corner and a cosy side lounge. Basement event space. Decorated with curiosities and local heritage.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Lively core boozer that attracts most of the town and has a good range of people from visitors to locals up and down the class range, which adds to its social atmosphere
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Live music, events, snacks
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Fair value, not unusual for the area of profile of the pub
description: Berwick's stalwart social venue, mixing a good range of real ales, live events and cosy space in surroundings of curiosities and local heritage, you'll spot the dentist's chair by the bar as you enter, a local legend. Social and democratic, it draws in most of the town and its visitors by doing something most of the rest of the town aren't doing, which is both sad and a good thing. An essential stop in town. (Added February 2024)

name: Canny Man's
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.7
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Moderate beer selection but a broad range of whiskies. Wines are superior for a traditional pub too.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A labour of love, first established over 150 years ago as the Volunteer Arms, enter and you'll find a curation of artefacts and personal heritage that has been carefully fastened and preserved in place. Many aspects draw the eye across a small warren of rooms, from taxidermy to dummies, model ships, etc. 
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Hugely characterful whether it's empty or busy, the tone shifts only when service is to be encountered - as reviews are keen to point out, this is a love or hate experience.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, tasting nights, music
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
City centre prices
description: Infamous, the luke-warm ratings you'll read conceal the love-or-hate truth to this place. Lots of 5 star ratings, lots of 1. The pub has a long history, transformed from the Volunteer Arms by the Kerr family who were local whisky blenders, operating in the cellar of the pub for a time on their 'The Golden Drop'. James Kerr was a very particular fellow and the pub was always run to a set of rules both according to customers and even his staff, which is why some people truly take against the place. However, you will need to visit with an open mind, as there is an exquisite pub to be enjoyed. Rich reds, creams and lacquered wood around lamplight, nooks and crannies festooned with personal artefacts, books, heritage art and always something to draw the eye, whether it's the dummy fastened to the ceiling in the lounger or the huge Nebuchadnezzer wine bottles perched on the shelves. Unless you're a regular, service is only tolerant at best, but once served, enjoy your drinks in this wonderful environment that would draw you back often enough that you too could have the rare privilege of being seen as a treasured customer. You'll love it, or you'll hate it - it's best to be honest.

name: Kay’s Bar
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
6 cask ales with rotating choices, broad whisky selection and good Guinness. Perfunctory alternatives.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Formerly a wine and liquor merchants, converted to a pub in the 1970s, a small venue with shop front leading into a single bar with line of barrels and bench seating to the left, bar to the right and a niche next to a fireplace, with a small library room to the rear. Rich reds, lacquer and warm-hues of wood and lamplight.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Busy and bustling on match days with a quick trade, conversational and a range of generations involved. Equally atmospheric when quiet among the calm and comfort of the intimate surroundings.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Sandwiches, snacks, books, newspapers, TV, fireplace, occasional events
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
On the higher side for the city centre.
description: Despite appearance's, Kay's has only performed the function of a public house since 1976, the premises formerly the site of a wine and liquor merchants, the business name inherited from the proprietor. A small, cosy venue which fills up to standing room only within an hour of opening on busy match days, but that is luxuriously cosy, clandestine and intimate at quieter times. Attracting a range of ages, but there is an affluence on show due to its location in one of the wealthier parts of town, and that accents the vibe and atmosphere just a touch, without making it feel particularly discriminating. Whether you're sat opposite the bar by the barrels or in the reading room (snug) at the back, grab a newspaper or a dusty old book and settle in for the day, where you'll be seduced by its timeless charm. Or, if you prefer things a little livelier, join the throng in the build up to a Scottish rugby game. An essential visit. Kay's has also joined the ranks of pubs featured in Rankin's works. (Added February 2024)

name: The Oxford Bar
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Cask ales and whisky focus with a perfunctory back bar. Ales from largely independent Scottish brewers.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A whitewashed frontage with heritage signage, the iconic Oxford Bar awning greets you above the entrance. Move to a slim bar room on your left with a high bar that seems to raise line a stage above you, an effect accentuated by the steps ahead of you to the lounge. The furnishing is deliberately simple and wooden with cream walls, decorated seasonally with local artwork and photography. The lounge features a flickering fireplace most of the year.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Nothing less than a city institution, the connections to the police force and literary inclusions have cemented its reputation over the years, but the character comes from its simplicity and its age, little altered because there is so little to alter. Naturally the pub features tourists, particularly on weekends, but this is not a theme pub or a tat pub.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Snacks, local artwork, newspapers, fireplace
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Reasonable considering the location.
description: 'The Ox', possibly Edinburgh's most famous pub, endures and retains its relevance as a day-to-day pub, rather than a tourist destination. The beauty is in its simplicity, a two roomed shop with a bar that seems to loom above you, and a firelit lounge with simple seating. A good selection of cask ales and whiskies is of course a nice compliment to the setting. The local constabulary used to frequent the bar, leading it to be namedropped in several novels, most prominently Rankin's 'Rebus' series. On weekends the crowd turns more international, as you'd expect, but this still majestically performs the function of simple, honest local, the kind anyone would wish to be at the end of their street. (Added February 2024)

name: Bennets Bar
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.3
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Whisky specialists with over 100 to choose from, but a good range of cask ales compliments that, with the typically mediocre keg options virtually every Edinburgh pub seems stuck with.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Historic pub with fittings dating from 1906. CAMRA's heritage listing describes the fittings as follows:
" It is the last pub in the city with an original gantry featuring four spirit casks, and has an extraordinary tiled and mirrored interior, as well as a rare jug bar. It also stocks 120 single malt whiskies. The ornate gantry has niches, pilasters and scallop shell pediments. The original bar counter retains a former spittoon trough made of marble, which runs all along the front, and the bar top has two working brass water taps. Designed in 1891 by George Lyle, it has a fine ceiling with very decorative cornices and it was refitted in 1906. The magnificent interior features a tiled and extraordinary four-bay mirrored arcading all the way down the right-hand side with hand-painted pictorial tiles with allegorical figures by William B. Simpson & Sons of London. Below the arcading are red leather seating areas and tables inlaid with maps"
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Good character stemming from the fittings and environment, but the atmosphere is notable for its slightly more neighbourly feel, our on the edge of Morningside by the meadows, just far enough from the tourist crowds to remain local.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, books, TV
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Not unusual pricing overall, more expensive for drinks but some okay food deals.
description: Located far enough outside Edinburgh old town to retain a neighbourly feel, this heritage pub features fittings that are unique to the city and worth the short journey out to alone, but it's no museum with a good spread of products covering beers and whiskies and TV pulling in rugby fans, all keeping a sense of relevance. As you're seated you can't help but admire the huge mirrors and tilework, while the sensation of it being local rather than tourist property is notable versus many others you'll visit in and around the centre. (Added February 2024)

name: The Bow Bar
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.4
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Arguably the best range of beers in Edinburgh old town, with a handsome range of whiskies too - these are the focus.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Despite appearances, The Bow Bar has only existed in its current guise since the 1990s. A curator, Ian White used his collection of pub hoardings and fittings to create what on first glance appears to be a traditional little tavern. A one room affair with 'wet' ceiling, lamplight and classic bar fixtures including those narrow tables fit into the floor. 
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Busy, buzzy, you'll find everyone here from weekend visitors to real ale aficionados which gives the place a natural energy. Not somewhere for a quiet pint on weekends, but the energy is friendly and doesn't turn overly 'towny'.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️
Snacks, err...not much else!
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
On the high side, particularly the bottle selection.
description: Wandering past, Bow Bar looks for all the world like a heritage pub. If these walls could talk, eh? Well, if they could, they'd tell you it's only been around since the 1990s. Yes, rather like Holy Tavern in London, the interior is a recreation - a rather effective one - of a Victorian tavern. Opulent features with etched glass mirrors, stylish lamps and a classic 'wet' ceiling. In all honesty, it's probably best to visit the pub without this knowledge! Bow Bar excels in beers and whiskies with a superior cask, keg and bottle range and a shelf full of whisky options. Some of these come at an eye-watering cost, but you can still find some affordable options in amongst them. Based in the old town, the pub gets busy on weekdays with tourists and real ale fans, but reportedly it can be an oasis of calm on weekday afternoons. Certainly among Edinburgh's finest drinking holes. (Added February 2024)

name: The Blue Blazer
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.2
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A clearly superior range of beers with strong cask and keg options from smaller independent Scottish brewers, and the odd North East English brewer featuring too. The usual good selection of whiskies.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A curved frontage at a junction makes the Blazer stand out as you approach, which continues on entrance, met by a tiled floor with the 'school blazer' emblem and blue walls adjacent to the bar. The main bar room is open plan but an unusual shell shape, while the rear room is characterful in itself with a homely feel and upholstered bench seating.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A convivial city tavern without the hustle of Bow Bar or the tourists of The Oxford Bar, instead somewhere you'd find on the fringes of suburbs in English cities. Slightly upscale which may be why.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Books, board games, snacks, live events
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
On the high side for central Edinburgh.
description: Edinburgh's beer selection can be repetitive as you explore its pubs, so fans of smaller, local independent output will rejoice at the Blue Blazer. Named after a local school uniform, the emblem features as you enter and the colour scheme at the back. After that, there's a traditional pub layout with a shell shaped bar room and snug second room to the rear. The beer selection is among the strongest in the city centre on cask and keg, with good whiskies too - but you do pay for this privilege, sadly. With books, board games and live events, this feels more versatile and a 'hangout spot' rather than a destination, which provides a nice variety. Well worth checking out. (Added February 2024)

name: The Dagda Bar
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Strong selection of cask ales and, a less common spot, some half decent keg beer too, with a typically good range of whiskies, albeit not outstanding for somewhere like Edinburgh.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A small ground floor pub in a typical Georgian era tenement house. When you walk in, you've seen what there is to see. Dark ceiling with attractive lamps and a large bar counter.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A well-known, popular local with a mixed crowd of locals, visitors, students etc. Lively and social.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Snacks, quiz, chess, cards
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Fairly normal for the area.
description: The Dagda has become a contemporary Edinburgh classic but it hasn't always been this way, formerly a low key old boozer called Proctors. Now independently owned, they can choose their drinks and so provide a decent range for a pub of its size with a range of guest cask ales, some decent keg and a fair whisky selection. The bar aims to be an all-rounder and really achieves that, bringing in different walks of life and offering a social focus at a good, lively pace. Not one for an introspective dram by the fireplace, but somewhere to natter at the bar with old or new friends. One to mark on your list, for sure. (Added February 2024)

name: The Ventoux
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Real ale fans will scowl at the absence of cask ales, while the keg options are mediocre. A good selection of German and Belgian bottles is the saviour, with a competent back bar for alternatives.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
An attractive frontage with nouveau style frames leads to an alternative hangout. L-shaped room with cream walls, bench seating and a Belgian café type atmosphere accentuated with cycles on the ceiling. Two fish tanks either side of the room.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A quirky hangout that provides a breath of fresh air from the Victoriana and heritage pubs in the vicinity, somewhat alternative with a different crowd to match. 
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Pizzas (order from nearby), snacks, fish tanks, live events
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
No more than standard for the area
description: The sister pub to the Tourmalet, the Ventoux is another Tour de France themed café bar with an alternative feel, from the fish tanks in the knockabout bar room to the graffiti in the bogs - you know where you are. Casual and relaxed, with a lack of stuffiness that makes it a nice change to many of the Victoriana and heritage pubs nearby (nice though they are). An absence of good tap options is perhaps the key weakness, but if you're a fan of German and Belgian beers this fills the void satisfactorily. They have a connection to a nearby pizza place where you can order in. Altogether one to mark down unless you are absolutely scrupulously obsessed with cask ale. (Added February 2024)

name: Athletic Arms
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A decent selection of local cask ales from independent producers with moderate keg options and whisky selections.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
Corner bar with some original wood fittings including the typical narrow tables screwed into the floor. A classic neighbourhood pub layout opened out somewhat, with a snug room to the rear.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Local and neighbourly, far enough outside the centre to be free of tourists. Livelier on weekends and matchdays
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, TV, live events, functions
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Good value for beer but especially good value for pub grub, with further discounts available during the week and for members.
description: Situated between two graveyards, "Diggers" has been going since 1897 and aside of the pub being opened out, the core of the pub remains, a corner shape with narrow tables and communal seating, with a fine snug room to the rear. Far enough outside the centre to be almost entirely frequented by locals and die hard fans, you'll find fair value here, particularly for the food. As for the atmosphere, a sleepy social home-from-home afternoon changes to busy and buzzy on weekends and matchdays, with Tynecastle nearby. A pub that grows on you on repeat visits, it is easy to reach on a bus from the centre, so no excuses! (Added February 2024)

name: Barony Bar
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.7
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A decent but familiar selection of cask ales from small independent brewers with good whisky range. Keg options are not so great.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
As with many heritage pubs in Scotland, the venue began life as a wine and liquor merchants in the 19th century before a 1950s conversion to a pub. Inheriting fine Victorian features including an oak panelled bar, magnificent tiling and large mirrors with etched advertising, and this is before you get to the grand layered vaulted ceiling which continually draws the eye. 
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
An L-shaped pub with a busier feel to the bar and loungier feel to the rear, without losing its coherence, this versatility is to its credit. It is somewhere you could take all kinds of friends for an afternoon natter.

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, fireplace, pub quiz, live music at weekends
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
Edinburgh city centre prices, particularly steep for food.
description: A grand venue with an informal café style feel, the blend coming from its change of use from a wine and liquor merchants in the 19th century to a public house in the 1950s. The inherited fixtures and fittings give what is otherwise a compact space on a street leading out of town an eye-catching level of finesse and heritage, while the current operation keeps the place feeling casual and democratic. Particularly to its credit is its ability to blend the busier bar area with a loungier backroom behind the 'L', producing an organic atmosphere and sense of permanence. Drinks options are decent, if familiar, but do the job adequately, and it maintains a community feel with music on weekends, a pub quiz and food available. This sets it apart from the likes of the slightly more exclusive feeling Café Royal. One to keep in your pocket as an answer to "where next?" or just a good selection to meet with a friend for an afternoon natter and a pint. (Added February 2024)

name: Cafe Royal
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.7
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A broad selection of options from beer, wines, cocktails and whiskies. Tap options for beers are reasonably good given the format.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Beginning as a showroom for gas and sanitary fittings, it was not long until - like so many heritage venues in Edinburgh - it had been repurposed into a bar. Heavily redesigned in 1901 from its original 1860 appearance, a corner entrance leads to a lavish open plan room with central bar and booth seating. Eyecatching painted tiles from various inventors and scientists feature on the walls which had previously been used in technological exhibitions, but compliment the space as though they were intended for it. Towards the rear behind a walnut panel partition is the famous 'Oyster Bar' with its superb stained glass and marble counter that would be worth popping in to see even if you weren't intending to stay for a drink. 
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A sense of light novelty pervades as you are surrounded by this highly unusual and decorative work of art, which adds a frisson of excitement and exclusivity to the experience. Some of this is superficial and so when you strip that away and experience it as a social and drinking venue, it is much like being in a popular, bustling city tavern.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️
Food, snacks, newspapers
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
Among the city centre's more expensive drinking venues. 
description: Return to the days where the ornate, the lavish and luxurious was not simply the reserve of the ultra rich but a proud, fountaining exhibition of craftwork and achievement to be shared with the general public. Café Royal is one of the UKs most impressive lavish Victorian drinking venues with some frankly astonishing interior features which have been preserved and well-maintained. The stained glass in the rear Oyster Bar dazzles like the stained glass window of a cathedral, while the island bar and painted tilework lends a sense of novelty and exclusivity which makes the place a fun visit, although it won't be to everyone's tastes. Moving onto more down to earth topics, you'll find a reasonable range of cask ales from smaller independent Scottish breweries, decent selection of wines, whiskies and cocktails befitting a versatile venue that is less snobbish than it may initially appear. Stripping back the adornments and focusing just on the bare bones of the experience, it is a superior version of going for a drink in a bustling institution of a city tavern. The fact it adds to that is to its credit. Make sure you bring plenty of money though. (Added February 2024)

name: The Guildford Arms
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.7
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A stronger than average beer selection for an institution central pub is due to an absence of beer tie, with a quite impressive selection of cask ales from independent smaller Scottish breweries and even some interesting keg too. A well-stocked back bar for alternatives with the predictable whisky focus.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A survivor from the golden age of Scottish pub building, a corner building with revolving doors which leads to an opened out pub space (formerly partitioned, sadly removed), with impressive detailed sealing and grand bar. 
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️
A busy, bustling bar with transient trade. Perhaps a little towny at times, particularly on matchdays, although this comes with the territory. There is a feeling the open plan nature of the layout does not help the space fulfil its potential, but it is nevertheless an enjoyable place to be.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, TV, occasional live events during Fringe festival
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
A central venue with prices to match.
description: A survivor from the golden age of Scottish pub building and situated yards from some of Edinburgh grandest buildings, it is no surprise to find the pub has tried to keep up appearances with a magnificently lavish interior, the standout perhaps being its Jacobean style ceiling, but the revolving doors on entrance and grand bar are similarly notable. A strong beer selection will always make this a go-to for many, including even an up to date keg selection of modern beers, along with many cask ales from smaller independent brewers. Trade is brisk and the atmosphere can get lively, but there is a slight feeling the opened out cavernous nature of it moves the ambience further towards a Wetherspoons than would be ideal. Nevertheless, there remains plenty to enjoy. (Added February 2024)

name: Leslie's Bar
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.7
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Changing guest ales from smaller independent brewers and occasionally some reasonably welcome keg options too. A well-stocked back bar for alternatives. Sells its own label whisky distilled by Inverary.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Traditional exterior marked 'John Leslie'. A heritage interior dating from 1899 listed as being of national historic importance, split in two with snob-screens and hatches with order numbers on them. The bar has an alcove with banquettes while the lounge has three areas, a small snug by the door, an area around the fireplace and a corner with upholster seating.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A mixed crowd of locals and nearby students with a wider range of class present than you'd see in the city centre so much. Friendly and informal, with a knockabout feel despite the grandeur of the interior.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Board games, books, TV, snacks, fireplace, pub quiz
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Reasonably priced overall.
description: John Leslie was the second licensee, from 1902 to 1924 and has become the pubs brand name. Far enough outside the hustle and tourism of the city centre to retain a local crowd, also pleasing to see a wider range of clientele from up and down the class divides which accents the atmosphere in here - lively, fun but with places to lounge too. A large venue split at the entrance between bar and lounge, heritage features including a bar clock, snob screens and hatches where you would previously collect your order at the bar - a sign of the vast numbers of people who used to frequent these places. With their own label whisky available and snug rooms to enjoy, this is a pub with a few strings to its bow and well worth checking out. (Added February 2024)

name: The Ensign Ewart
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A whisky bar albeit with some interest cask ales available too. 
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
An appealing green and gold frontage which sticks out on one of the most prominent parts of Lawnmarket.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Touristy, sure, but once inside, the limited seating and cosy intimacy puts a lid on the worst of the excess, at least until later in the evening.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, live music
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
Not unusual for the area, ie. not cheap.
description: A historic pub which can be traced back centuries named after a Scottish military hero. The pub is a small affair with attracting little bar room with beams and some snug space to the rear. During the day it is cosy and clandestine enough to enjoy some of the whiskies and real ales on offer without it feeling too touristy. Staff offer a kind of quasi-table service which keeps a lid on any excess until the daily evening musical performances step up the tempo. Overall worth a look despite the touristy location. (Added February 2024)

name: Cat I'th Well
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.9
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
3 cask ales from local brewers, Timothy Taylors plus guest ales. Familiar country pub keg and back bar options.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Down at the bottom of a gully surrounded by steep hills, with a fast running stream, a stone Inn with a typically dour exterior. Inside you'll find a little changed pub, with the emphasis on little. A small bar with handsome fireplace and wood fittings, the entrance to the toilets particularly notable. These elements were rescued from a fire to a nearby castle and repurposed effectively, giving the Inn a slightly baronial feel in that corner of the room. Two other plainer, but cosy rooms complete the interior. A nice view of the valley from the beer garden.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A very cosy interior in winter with the coal fire in action and comfortable bench seating, with a social focus that is increasingly unfamiliar to rural pubs that have given up and thrown it all behind dining. The beer garden is well rated in summer months.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food (Thurs-Sun), Snacks, fireplace, outdoor seating, books
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
A normal price for a country pub
description: It doesn't take long on a bus out of Halifax to reach the moor tops, after which there is a short 10 minute steep descent down a country lane to this hidden gem - a phrase that is truly deserved in this instance.

A characterful stone Inn with a coal fire, comfortable bench seating and surroundings that look almost baronial  - due to the fixtures having been recovered from a nearby castle after a fire. This adds to the value and appearance, as well as the sheer cosiness.

The other good aspect is its social focus, increasingly rare as country pubs pivot to dining. This is a place where the bar is the social hangout, and all the better for it, while meals are served later in the week and on weekends. 

In the summer, the beer garden offers good views of Luddenden valley, but in all weathers be careful of the steep entrance and exit to the pub which will require a degree of fitness - or a car - to successfully traverse. 

With a series of hiking routes in and around the area this is a pub not to miss on a country ramble.

With three cask ales from nearby independent brewers, beer fans will be satisfied enough too. 

(Added February 2024)

name: Musta Kissa
description:
EBG Rating:: 8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Basic tap options but things improve in the fridge with some local Lapland-brewed craft beers alongside different styles. A competent back bar.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Small one-room affair, walk through the two doors and a saloon type swing door to a tiny off-beat little hangout with colourful lounge furniture and plants, bookish wallpaper and a little corner bar in a niche.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Simply a cut above the other Rovaniemi options and everyone here knows it. A sense of civilisation in what is otherwise an outpost city. Bohemian with a post-grad audience.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Snacks, books, board games, TV, occasional events
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
Typically fairly expensive.
description: When you're hovering one line of latitude below the Arctic circle, your expectations for a good pub are adjusted accordingly. All the more surprising then to find this bar, a slice of cosmopolitan life on the fringe of the town centre. Every bit as relevant as any Helsinki bar you can care to visit, this place is cosy, intimate, off-beat, friendly and one of the best places in the city. Tap beer options are unexciting but bolstered by superior fridge options including local craft ales, while a competent back bar keeps things ticking over fine. If you want to meet some locals and experience the cultural scene, there's no question that you start here. As it is tiny and very popular, we recommend not leaving it to chance, as you may not find a seat! (Added March 2024)

name: Uitto Pub, Rovaniemi
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.6
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Mainstream tap options are fortunately accentuated by interesting cans and bottles. A well stocked back bar, particularly for whiskies.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Saloon bar, open plan with booth seats and wood-strip. A safe but effectively executed concept. There is apparently a log-floating theme to the bar, so you may need to peer in closer detail to recognise that.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Popular versatile place with a very lively and social evening atmosphere, but large enough to have places to dip in and out of that activity.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, TV, darts, board games, outdoor seating
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
Relatively expensive.
description: One of the 'all-rounders' in Rovaniemi that is a cut above its direct competition. The key to its success is its versatility - there are a number of reasons to go here and it finds itself through a filtering system always somewhere near the top of places to go. With a log cabin/chalet vibe that is well-executed, if conservative, there's a homely feel despite being open plan, while the bar area is decent to linger around too. Plenty of amenities keeps people invested in the place, and the drinks selection is also good enough to keep most people satisfied. A pub that is more than the sum of its parts rather than having one glaringly obvious stellar aspect. (Added March 2024)

name: Pub Graali
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.1
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A superb range of beers covering English exports, European classics and Finnish craft, with a good whisky selection too. 
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A camelot theme thankfully does not expand into anything too indulgent once you pass through the entrance, instead you'll find a restrained saloon bar with long bar front and raised seating opposite. However, the lounge-like backrooms with gentleman's study appearance are very much worth exploring.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
One of those places that needs people there to drum up a good atmosphere, but if you can find the right evening, particularly in the lounge rooms, you can experience a very relaxing and convivial setting.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Snacks, TV, board games, books, occasional events
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
On the higher end.
description: Opening in 2001, the 'Grail' theme thankfully loses impetus almost as soon as you walk through the door, instead presenting you with a tidy bar with long bar top stretching opposite raised booth seating. You'll notice the Untappd screen, many beer taps and wall of craft cans to choose from, signifying that yes, this is a beer specialists and the choices are very strong for a provincial city such as this. Whiskies are also notable. While it is merely a pleasant and inoffensive place to enjoy these wares at quieter times, the atmosphere improves when it gets busy, particularly if you can grab a seat in the atmospheric lounge room, you may find yourself thinking out loud that it's one of the better pubs in Finland. (Added March 2024)

name: Leskinen
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.9
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
The beer selection is superb, eye-catching options of products that will be both tantalising in their rarity and unfamiliarity (unless you're Finnish) and overwhelming in their number. This includes 4 permanent taps for local brewery beers and cask ales from England! A well-stocked back bar for alternatives, especially whiskies, is also to its credit.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Open plan. Stylishly demure, low-key drinking lounge with muted lamplights and amber hues across black and dark woods.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Somehow both bar-like and pub-like with the wood and finish complimenting each other very well, but the overall atmosphere is helped when people are here, no doubt. Attracting a 30-something crowd, it is no party venue but becomes social and relaxing in the evenings.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Snacks, newspapers, board games, occasional events, function room
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
No doubt it is slightly more expensive for the area although not outstandingly
description: Established in 1992, Leskinen represents one of the longer-standing pub businesses in all of Finland. From modest beginnings they have become renowned for the selection of beers, both in terms of style and provenance. It is not all about the product though, as the bar maintains sleek, yet comfortable fittings and a sense of institution which has been earned over the decades, adding to the significance. There is no doubt whatsoever that it should be visited while in Oulu. (Added March 2024)

name: Jumpru Pub
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A good beer selection with a range of styles, but not a beer specialists, per se. Local beer from Sonnisaari is available. Competent back bar with cocktails advertised.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
An interesting complex, with an outdoor patio and warren of rooms inside. The bar room feels rather like a Czech pivnice with curved ceilings, backlit niches and booth seating, but several other rooms look equally appealing too.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Due to its size, it needs people to bring it to life. If quiet, the bar room has the most natural ambience.

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, outdoor seating, live music, games
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
Typical for the area, ie. not cheap.
description: A slight departure for the usual Finnish bar, this place takes advantage of its historic interior to provide a cosy Pivnice style bar with curved ceiling and warren of rooms which are used variously for live music and late evening hangouts. It is a successfully curated space. It is a true all-rounder and large space that people with different tastes will likely find their own corner to enjoy. With local beers, wine and cocktails, there's enough of a range to satisfy most needs, while it doesn't claim to be a specialist, it is at least certainly competent. A nice surprise find taken by chance on our visit to Oulu that comes recommended. Keep an eye out for the type of events that may change your opinion sharply about it (DJ sets, etc) before you visit. (Added March 2024)

name: Salhojankadun Pub Oy
description:
EBG Rating:: 9.3
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A broad drinks range, albeit perhaps 'last gen' but some curios here. Additionally the presence of cask ale from handpump - not guaranteed but as and when stocks last. Competent all-rounder back bar.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Instantly gobsmacking, like walking back to a London pub from the 1970s with its brown hues, corner bar, brewing signage and dart board. Impossible to detect from the otherwise plain glass shop frontage. Behind the bar there are further rooms including a pool room to the back.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Wonderful character with natural ambience even when completely quiet, with the atmosphere only getting better as it fills.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Piano, darts, pool table, board games, TV
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
Among the more expensive in the city, although not wildly beyond the going rate.
description: One of Finland's oldest pubs, formed in 1969, when licensing was coming in to combat alcohol abuse problems. The British pub was a format often used and the idea that this would provide a civilised space for social drinking that tempered excess proved to be effective. These days it is among the oldest continually running pub operations in Finland. You'd never spot this from the outside with its unprepossessing glass frontage offering barely any hint of what's inside. As you enter however, you will be transported into an almost unchanged simulacra of a British pub from the early 1970s, all brown hues, carved wood, brewing signage and mirrors, with darts, pool and a piano. The Anglophilia extends to occasional supply of fresh cask ales and British ales on keg too. But don't take this as being a themed pub - far from it. The length of time this has been open has endowed it with a particular character of its own, the events it has hosted, the stories it can tell push this far beyond the realm of some tacky theme establishment. The natural ambience whether late afternoon, or in the bustle of a winter evening is extraordinary. If it was located in London itself there is no doubt it could be classed among the very best traditional pubs in the city. As for Finland, it is certainly belongs the rarified air of the upper echelons. The darts and pool particularly give the place an easy casual nature which disarms the sometimes staid nature of Finnish pub going (excluding karaoke bars), the drinks are perhaps last-gen but will serve you well. It isn't especially cheap but you will have to suck it up on this occasion to experience one of the finest pubs in Europe. (Added March 2024)

name: Kievari Kahdet Kasvot
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.7
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
An extremely good selection of drinks ranging from supply of Sahti - a native Finnish brew to side pull Pilsner Urquell in about the best condition in Finland, to its broad selection of whiskies. Tastings from microbreweries also feature.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
A striking frontage with art nouveau facade, the window frames are quite a piece of art. Inside you'll find early 20th century style décor, high ceilings, with high tables opposite the bar and the pub room to the rear.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Beer+whisky tastings, stand-up, pool, darts, newspapers, sandwiches, pub snacks
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
When adjusting for the going rate in Finland, it must be said that everything here is reasonably priced.
description: "Two Faces" refers to the artwork on the building's exterior which are eyebrow raising before you've even walked in. The interior is a relatively unusual setup for a Finnish pub. High ceiling, an early 20th century feel with open plan seating behind a corner bar. The bar's core strength is its drinks with some superb offerings across beer, whiskies and more, including Sahti available all-year-round. The pricing here is definitely on the fair side by Finnish standard. Whether the atmosphere will really do it for you or not depends on the time of day and your tolerance for that kind of seating layout that's quite row-after-row rather than curated, but there's no doubt that they're doing their best on all other fronts and it still comes comfortably recommend as a superior option in the city. (Added March 2024)

name: Oluthuone Panimomestari
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A de facto taproom for Plevna beers, from Tampere itself. A wide range of styles - this is complimented by plenty of alternatives too. A beer specialists but there are a good range of whiskies notable too.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
A simple setup, open plan in a small-medium sized bar set around one corner of the room, with unflashy but comfortable seating.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A good social scene at the bar, otherwise can be a little private and staid during the afternoons, so seek out the evening atmosphere to find it at its best.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Snacks, newspapers, board games, quiz, bingo
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
Typical city centre prices, although at least for something different.
description: Most Finnish cities have at least one of these Oluthuone's, a reliable beer specialists to turn to. Tampere's has a twist, which is offering Plevna beers from a local brewery. 17 taps with styles that should keep most more than satisfied, and exploring the range gives this bar a niche that is quite welcome. Surroundings are otherwise familiar, a muted but well-enough curated open plan interior, with activities supplemented with quiz nights and bingo. Definitely a place to keep up your sleeve. (Added March 2024)

name: Ravintola Vanha Monttu
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Focusing on budget drinks, mainly from a mainstream perspective, although there is a selection, including a locally brewed attempt at Czech pils, 'Svejk'. If that doesn't appeal, there is a familiar back bar to acquaint yourself with.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A basement venue with a personalised, let's say worn-in interior encompassing several rooms. 
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Informal and somewhere to let your hair down, whether that's an afternoon away from the reserved streets to the height of an evening out. You'll find people willing to chat and make friends here, which may be your thing or not. It is ours.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Pub food, snacks, TV, jukebox, books, board games, karaoke, bingo
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Afternoon discounts lower the prices to a level that is very affordable by Finnish standards (and merely ordinary by others), but overall this is aiming at the budget end of the market.
description: A basement dive bar, don't be fooled by 'Ravintola', as virtually every business serving food seems to need to have that stuck on it by law in Finland. This is a casual hangout where you're more likely than elsewhere to get chatting with locals. Informal and homely, it is known as Tampere's living room. Don't come here for high end beers or refinement, but for a good laugh and a break from the usual stuffiness and staid atmosphere elsewhere, this should definitely be marked down. For those on a budget travelling to Finland, this will be an essential stop-off, particularly during Happy Hours. (Added March 2024)

name: Tiima
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
House cocktails which have a twist on familiar classics, a well-stocked bar that can rustle up almost anything if you've got the money.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A small venue, one-room with a compact bar and high shelf. Well-curated and well-lit overall.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
With a relaxing atmosphere that feels homely and a departure from the mainstream, which is generally what we are seeking from a cocktail experience.

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️
Snacks, books
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Honestly, given what you pay for a beer in Finland, not particularly expensive for a cocktail here.
description: Opened in 2017 in a former watchmaker's, Tiima is an award-winning cocktail bar with a mildly clandestine setup, a small one-room bar with tall shelves, exposed brickwork and candlelight. Choose from a menu of bespoke cocktails (normally a twist on some recognisable classics) and reflect on the narrower ratio between beer:cocktail prices in Finland. Part of an overall cultural complex, as you depart to the toilets you will discover the lobby to a wider building. An hour or two spent here is relaxing without feeling corporate or mainstream in the slightest. It comes recommended. (Added March 2024)

name: Tåget
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
So far a relatively mainstream selection available covering all bases perfunctorily.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Well, it's a train carriage with a bar fitted into it. 1990s spec upholstery with a 'pseud's corner' to the end of the trail with large seats and lamplight. Fun novelties such as the emergency brake reconfigured to be a water tap.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
The novelty value is high of course, but to find the bar busy with a wide range of people and a buzzing atmosphere is really special, making it feel like some accident or delay has been turned into a party, oddly World War style.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Summer BBQs are promised, outdoor seating in warmer weather, books, board games
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
Pretty standard for the area.
description: One-man team Janne Hiltunen, whose approach to life is to meet challenges head on, bit off a little more than he could chew in efforts to build a brewpub in the warehouses by Turku train station. The Ukraine war put a stay on the idea due to the rise in material costs and logistics disrupting his business model. As it so happens, he already had a backup plan in the guise of a 1990s train carriage, which saw service during the 1990s between Helsinki and St Petersburg. The blue and salmon pink decoration inside will make those who made the journey nostalgic for the area. Tåget now joins the list of venues repurposed from former use in Turku.

It is, for reasons both accidental and purposeful, a great experience. 

This side of the tracks in Turku is awaiting the usual redevelopment and gentrification, so for now, the cast of patrons is an interesting mix from punk/bohemian dropouts to middle aged families, with plenty in between.  The atmosphere in the carriage therefore feels like a journey, if rather over time than space. Kick back and have a game of chess or head over to the "pretentious" seats at the back which Janne has set up for a slightly different vibe.

Once full up, the intimacy is added to by the sense of transgression - should this be happening in a train carriage? There is a faintly end-of-days atmosphere as though we are hiding from zombies or air strikes, which on top of the superficial novelty factor makes this bar an extremely distinctive experience - not only for Finland, which is short on such places, but Europe in general. (Added March 2024)

name: Uusi Apteekki Pub
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.2
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
An impressive selection of whiskies dominated the range, but there are good beers here too, some harking back to the 1990s scene rather than cutting edge craft, but certainly distinctive enough to be notable. A brewing operation on site has sadly ceased.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
An old pharmacy converted sympathetically to a bar. Sweeping mid-brown bar area with a wide open-plan approach, pharmacy cabinets turned into leaning posts, and carpeted lounge rooms to the rear.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Without music, there is a soft hubbub of quiet chatter and conversation acoustically dampened by the carpeting. This leaves the atmosphere feeling both very comfortable, relaxing but discreet, in a manner some bars, even the ones going for that, fail to execute.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Snacks, books, board games
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
description: Opened in 1993 on the site of a former Pharmacy dating back to 1907, your first impression as you approach the building is of the Art Nouveau styling in the signage and the carved stone at the entrance.

Enter through a peculiar set of doors which also betray its former use to discover a preserved Pharmacy interior now operating as a pub!

A sweeping bar is backed by old wooden shelves and cabinets which extend along a lobby to the rear lounge rooms, while further cupboards in the centre of the main bar room act as leaning posts.

It is not sacrilege so much, the set up kind of works. Perhaps it is the large whisky selection and the medicinal utility that has served over the years that helps bridge the gap.

Without music and with a carpeted interior the ambience has a warm, subdued hubbub, at once homely but discreet. It will not be to everyone's tastes, but there is very little else remotely like it.

The pub has also hosted microbrewing operations in the last decades but not continuously by any means. The beer selection is decent but certainly traceable back to the 90s rather than offering a cutting edge selection. 

The pub has acquired a sense of institution, bolstered by its inclusion in crime novels, writers clearly influenced by a few visits here to sample its beer, whiskies and atmosphere. We impress upon you to pay a visit here too one day. (Added March 2024)

name: Panimoravintola Koulu
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
On-site brewery with 7-10 taps of their own beers, with some ciders available too and a decently stocked back bar of alternatives.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Impressive sprawling venue, a school building dating from 1889 which has received a sympathetic restoration. Set over two floors, with a lobby area acting as the bar, several loungers and upstairs banqueting hall with huge ceiling. 
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
The complex feels both liberating and swaddling in its side, big enough that you can explore each nook and cranny undeterred and at ease to do so. This is a not often found quality. 
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Meals, snacks, events, on-site-brewery, outdoor seating, takeaway, gift cards, function rooms
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Standard pricing however lunch buffets on weekdays are very good value.
description: One of a handful of truly standout buildings hosting drinking venues in Finland, a 19th century girl's school repurposed in the late 1990s into a brewery restaurant. The combination of Belle Époque architecture and detailing with a brewpub is not often seen, yet they somehow manage to make it work. A lobby area with booth seating opposite the brewkit serves as the bar room, with several lounges spread around it, and a beer garden to the rear of the building. Upstairs is an enormous banqueting hall, the Bellman Hall which used to host gym class. There is much to explore and feel free to, as the sense of belonging grows as you start to realise you can be at ease here, there are no security staff to enforcer cordons or people who will chastise you for being in the wrong place, and that adds to its likeability.

The brewery focuses on lagers which are in general a notch above the ordinary without really touching on superb, but their seasonal specials and one-offs also show plenty of creativity, and being Finland, the effort goes into keeping everything fresh and clean. 

Grab a brew and enjoy the feeling of being in a historic institution - keep an eye on the weekday buffet offering too. Those exploring Finland on a budget can fill your boots for a fair price.

(Added March 2024)

name: 5piste5 x Myrrys
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.7
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Finnish craft beers both in bottle/can and keg including takeaway. This is the focus, however some cider and spirits are also for sale.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A bottle shop, but the bar seems to be of equal if not greater focus overall. Offbeat with shabby chic lounge furniture, colourful decor and instruments which overall manages to avoid a template/corporate feel, although it will not be unfamiliar to customers of this kind of business.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Lively with a similar atmosphere to a British craft bar or micropub.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Takeout, gifts, instruments, books, board games, beer tasting events
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
City centre prices
description: A modern bottleshop/bar executed with just a hint of flair and confidence, without being suckered into to a particular corporate template as so many bars lacking imagination find themselves doing. The range focuses quite rightly on Finnish beer but there are a number of Scandi options in auxilary, while ciders, mead etc are also for sale. The space itself is generally pleasant with low-slung lounge furniture and a central location that feels very much part of the action. (Added March 2024)

name: Cosmic Comic Cafe
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
12 taps and 180 bottles with a focus on Finnish craft brewers, but very strong European support to that. Beer is the focus but of course there is a back bar.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
