Set in a shopping arcade, you may do a quick double take before realising that yes, this is it. An open plan, fairly gloomy interior with a bunker feel, a long bar leading to a back room and stage area. Decorated with a mild comic theme, with arcade machines and shelves of comics.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Gloomy but relaxing enough when quiet, it does need custom to really come into its own.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Comics, board games, books, snacks
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
City Centre prices.
description: A fairly long standing venue tucked away in a shopping centre - not one you'd just walk in, but a business whose success has spread via word of mouth. Hopefully we can do our bit on that front too.

An excellent drinks selection will grip you from the point you walk in with 12 taps and 180 bottles. The tap options try to display the best of Finnish brewing but other high quality European offerings tend to support those.

The place itself is designed as a kind of comic library as well, with some arcade machines and shelves of comics, making it a vaguely alternative leaning place - by the restrained standards of Finns.

There is no doubt it should be well up your list of venues to visit while in Turku. (Added March 2024)

name: Bar Petiit
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Focusing on quality over quantity, a range of wines, cocktails and yes - tapped beers which are all from independent small producers, it is superb.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A corner bar with low-key entrance leads into a twinkly low-lit space with bare brick walls, fairylights and a wood panelled bar, with mantelpiece to the right. A second room to the left offers loungier but quite off-beat, arty space. 
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A superb creation with natural ambience whether busy or quiet, simply put a place you feel like visiting and staying in. Detached from any sense of tourist or city centre churn.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Snacks, books, board games, occasional events
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
Typical Helsinki prices, albeit for very good quality wares.
description: Possibly Helsinki's best bar? When you look on a map you might feel off-put by the distance away from the city centre, but in reality it's a brief tram ride on a very well-served line out to Vallila district. In a district which borders on being suburbs, this beautiful bar offers intimacy with high quality wares in an arty, stimulating but not overly pretentious environment. I mean, can you ask for much more than that. Those of you not overly agitated by the thought of Greek natural wines may in turn be delighted by the Finnish craft ales on tap or the cocktails, while the venue itself is a beauty, the natural ambience making it ideal for an evening drink. Compact, but this means it feels intimate even at quieter times. There's no doubt anyone - save perhaps for the most inverted snob could deny this is an excellent bar. (Added March 2024)

name: Harry's Bar Kruna
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.2
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
On the budget end of things, simple selection of basic wares covering most bases.

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A basement bar set just off the street, with an interior of lounge simplicity, comfortable but certainly well-worn. A bar room and side lounge with pool room to the rear. In the lounge, net curtains, red upholstery and lamp light give it a certain stuck-in-time look.

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
One of the bars that lives up to the atmospheric venues of Finnish director Aki Kaurismaki's films. A simple living room, but one where conversation, chat and fun is in bountiful supply. A young-ish audience although not exclusively. There's a certain comfort, relaxation and golden glow that seems to pin you in your seat.

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Pool, snacks, books, board games, instruments

Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Reasonable prices in context of Helsinki centre

description: Director Aki Kaurismaki brought Helsinki's nightlife to the world stage, a panoply of out-of-time retro bars and peculiar characters that the city had produced, an enigmatic yet vivid world behind the veneer of society. Several such bars remain and Harry's is arguably one of them. Being a short walk from the central station makes this an achievable target for anyone seeking the experience, but we recommend doing so after dusk falls, when the atmosphere takes on a different colour. Set in a half-step basement, there is already a feel of clandestine activity as you set foot in the bar. A comfortable lounge area awaits with red upholstery, lamp light and net curtains offering a kind of caught-in-time atmosphere. As the evening progresses, with 2am closing, this kind of timeless hangout is where to find the true social activity in the city, not so much the upright beer destinations. Drinks are cheap and cheerful, (minus the cheap - it's Helsinki) and merely provide the lubrication for the socialising. (Added March 2024)

name: Vastarannan Kiiski
description:
EBG Rating:: 8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
13 beer taps covering some European classics but not neglecting Finnish craft ales from small independent producers. With cider and extensive Fridge range, it is deserving to call this an excellent selection.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A corner pub with a pubby feel, more so than many Helsinki efforts, with its textured wallpaper and ceiling, browns and blacks, and furniture to match. Somewhere between a Czech Hospoda/English Pub/German Gaststatte in appearance. L-shaped and open plan.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Neighbourhood life with its various rhythms and guises can be found here, whether that's on quiet afternoons or buzzy evenings. It isn't a raucous place though, this is a fairly restrained conversational sort of venue.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Toasties, board games, books, quiz
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
Happy hour deals available, but not particularly cheap outside that.
description: "The Contrarian", a beguiling name for a pub. Töölö district is in need of good bars and this is its shining light. In service for over 20 years, it has become a well-known, reliable neighbourhood haunt. With its homely setup and décor, there is a sense of familiarity even when you've never been before that helps put you at ease, without seeming to have come from a template. The beer selection here is excellent and varies meaning you are unlikely to become bored on repeat visits. Don't expect a raucous atmosphere here exactly, this is a pub where friends meet, partner's come to chat and relax, but partying and karaoke etc will be happening elsewhere. You have to judge the pub on what it is trying to achieve. On that basis it is a superior venue in Helsinki. (Added March 2024)

name: Bier-Bier
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Good rather than great, 8 taps with a reasonable fridge selection, with mixers and whiskies represented well.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Housed in an Art Nouveau building, a three room interior of dark wood panels and carved frames, ocean green walls, light wood tiled flooring, tan and dark leather upholstered furniture, exposed bulbs and copper detailing. The fireplaces and ceiling were inherited from an insurance company who used to be situated here.

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A feeling of natural ambience is achieved through the interior regardless of how busy it is, while it stays feeling relatively refined rather than somewhere to really let your hair down. 
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Snacks, newspapers, board games, outdoor seating, tastings, private events
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
The city centre going rate, ie. not cheap!
description: Formerly a showcase of beers, it has since stripped back its offering, but not to the extent where you have completely lost the point of it. There is still a good range on tap and in the fridge, while the interior in a 130 year old Art Nouveau building is a standout feature. The premises formerly house an insurance company, and quite a grand operation that must have been. Carved wood ceiling and lavish tiles provide plenty to look at as you recline in a kind of refined comfort not normally associated with Bier places. However, that is not to say it is completely staid - there is a natural feeling ambience to the place, and while it may not put everyone at ease it will certainly impress. (Added March 2024)

name: Black door
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.6
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A superior standout drinks selection covering European classics with the typical Scandi Anglophile selection, however studded with Finnish craft beers too, many of which are on rotation. Cider also well represented. A competent back bar, particularly for whiskies.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A fairly unassuming frontage, demure rather than screaming its existence. Enter up a couple of steps into a space with a central bar and bench seats adjacent. There is more lounging space to the rear. Furnishings are low key but well curated.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️
The typically staid Finnish character means you'll need to visit later on to feel more at ease here. During the afternoons it can feel more like a library, however it does come to life later on.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Snacks, books, board games, quiz, events, TV, occasional DJ
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
Top level city centre prices, however there are deals on during Happy Hour.
description: For beer drinkers in Helsinki this is something of an anchor venue. Established in 1992 as part of a new wave of beer specialist bars, which has generally kept up with recent developments too. A demure bar with dark furnishings, you'll need to visit later on to experience the atmosphere developing beyond its library-like afternoon vibes - there is not much cross-chat from people in this buttoned up society until they've had a few drinks. With plenty of amenities and drinks, these elevate the venue to beyond simply a utility but a real point of interest in the city centre. Head there for happy hour if you're seeking an affordable drink, or later for a better atmosphere. (Added March 2024)

name: Janoinen Lohi
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.6
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
14 beer taps with some really good, interesting drinks that always change, from European classics to Finnish craft beer. Ciders and whiskies the highlight from the alternatives.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A neighbourly feel akin to a Czech Hospoda on approach, but on entering the interior is a little more decorative. One room with dark wood, bench seats and a black ceiling adding to the general effect.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Far out of the centre enough to have a feel of a local's local, people who live in and around the neighbourhood use the place, and that obviously effects the general vibes. Don't expect any hostility, however, this is a pub that offers a polite welcome.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
TV, snacks, newspapers, books, board games, summer terrace.
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
Still fairly similar to city centre prices, although look out for afternoon Happy Hour deals.
description: Belonging to the 'Kalaravintolat' group, the concept is of an easygoing neighbourly Brown Café style pub where you can enjoy a drink. On your visit you will likely notice it takes in more than just the brown café concept, but English pubs, Czech Hospudky and German Gaststatten too. One-room corner pub off a junction, attracting local residents and a different crowd to the hustle and bustle of central Helsinki. That said, it is only 5 minutes away on a tram. The group pride themselves on a handsome selection of beers and this is no doubt one of the main reasons to venture out here with a great choice available covering classics through to modern Finnish craft across a range of styles, it is highly unlikely you will be disappointed. With local rhythms accenting the place afternoon or evening, it is a good experience to compare and contrast with the central spots, and not so local that you'll be treated unpleasantly either. (Added March 2024)

name: Pikkulintu Ruttopuisto
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.6
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
An absurdly good selection of beer and whiskies. 22 beer taps hosting some of the finest beers around Europe, both ales and lager, with a shelf of 300+ whiskies to go at. The alternatives seem almost obscured by the greatness of this, but they are there.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
Retail unit turned bar, they have tried their best to personalise the place but it still could be a Costa Coffee but for a few posters here and there. 
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Busy, lively and buzzy, which makes a huge difference when the look of the venue itself is a little lacking. A popular spot with some energy about it. 

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Snacks, books, shop
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Considering what is available, and the location, it has to be considered if not very cheap, then competitive versus local rivals.
description: Beer fans, look no further. Whisky fans, look no further. This popular retail outlet-turned bar brings on the product. This is A-grade stuff which is brought forth with huge enthusiasm by the owners. With a loyal bordering on fervent customer base, there's a lively atmosphere in an otherwise utterly unexciting venue which propels the place above simply a well of delights, but somewhere you'd like to spend social time in too. (Added March 2024)

name: Musta Kissa Bar
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
While not in any way trying to be a specialists, there is a selection superior to what you'd find in many other such alternative hangouts, with a fair range of beers and competent back bar. 
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A small bar along an otherwise fairly austere street of tall tenement blocks. Inside it is a one-room colourful affair, ramshackle and bohemian, with some artwork featuring music performances. The steps down to the toilets are protected by a gate, presumably so people don't go flying in busier times and break their ankles.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Part of the alternative Helsinki scene, so a better gender split and always the chance of some impromptu music performances or art events going on. The point to the place seems more and more apparent the later into the evening it becomes.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Live music, instruments, snacks, events
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
Still not especially cheap.
description: The friendliness and refreshingly open attitude is a big boost to what on first glance may not seem like much. But live music, cultural events and a friendly owner and general good vibes propel it up our list. (Added March 2024)

name: Schluggstube Antiquitätenbar
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.6
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Feldschlosschen beers and mainstream bottles - with some standouts, with a well stocked back bar for alternatives.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A lavish spread of kitsch from floor to ceiling, the extravagance hinted at outside. Enter the one room bar to find yourself immersed in a cornucopia of taxidermy, mannequin limbs, flags, pinatas, mirrors, candelabras, and chandeliers. It lived a former life as an antique shop.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Due to the interior there is always something to enjoy even during quieter times, but the fact is it takes off truly later on with plenty of cross chat and fun.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Snacks, music, 
Value For Money: ❤️
Possibly among the more expensive bars in Basel centre for what is for sale, which is saying something. 
description: No less than a cult venue at this point, a former antique shop owned Hansjörg Bürgin  started in the1970s although the Schluggstube became a bar within 15 years. It has passed down within the family and offers a permanent beacon of nightlife in city centre that is not exactly studded with great bars. The signage hints at the extravagance inside, but it is only when entering that you find out just how extravagant. Immersed in a cornucopia of taxidermy, mannequin limbs, flags, pinatas, mirrors, candelabras, and chandeliers plastered from wall to ceiling. Beers are only perfunctory here but there are plenty of reasonably alternatives, so long as you have the money - it is not a cheap place to go. However, when the pace increases in the evening there is no doubt it is one of the best bars in Europe. (Added March 2024)

name: Flore
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.2
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
10+ wines by the glass with a French slant, not only regional. 4 beers on tap with a wider menu including Swiss craft beer, some of which is top class. 
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Corner café with tables around the entrance and customers doing some pretty intense people watching. Inside, a pleasant deco-themed bar with attractive, personalised bar area and bench seats with lights and patterns behind as decoration. A further backroom with slightly more of a private feel.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A highlight of Basel, this is where a lot of social exchange happens, the bar adroitly versatile enough to segue from chatty morning cafe to snoozy lunchtime lounge to brooding evening hangout without many shortcomings for either. An informal, friendly vibe.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, board games, music, events
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
Typical Basel prices, ie. not cheap, although nothing extortionate relative to the competition.
description: A superior versatile café bar that proves such a venue can be a beer and wine lovers venue all in one, a chatty gossip mill, a cosy lounge, a night spot, a drinking hole all at once without feeling bland or concessionary. As you approach you'll note the somewhat territorial pavement dwellers doing some pretty intense people watching, but it becomes instantly relaxed and convivial once you take your seat inside. Staff are friendly and the atmosphere is European, that is to say, Basel being on the corner of 3 countries makes it very international in flavour. With music, board games, bistro style food and enough space to accommodate all these different needs, it is time to appreciate the deft way this venue pulls all these things together, particularly in an age when business ideas are so ruthlessly discriminatory towards specific audiences. Yes, this is located in Klein-Basel, the Clara district which is a younger, less staid area of the city centre, and Flore is at the apex of the post-grad social scene onwards. Be warned though: CASH ONLY.

(Added March 2024)

name: Zum Johann Taproom
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.9
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A beer specialists with 18 taps of some of the best beers around Europe - including some UK based beers, which are lesser seen in continental Europe. A fridge full of tempting looking beer bottles compliments this. Limited alternatives.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A neighbourhood bar in a historic building, step up from the street to a raised bar room with attractive wood fittings and patterned walls. Muted warm lighting works well with this combination. A pubby layout with communal seating around the bar, and pretty beer garden to the rear.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
An interior of natural character, and atmosphere is local, although clearly focused on the craft beer demographic - white, middle class, etc, but this isn't always the case, and in summer its handsome beer garden is in use by a wider range of people. Best explored either on sunny days outside or winter evenings inside.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Cheese/meat platters, snacks, outdoor seating, occasional events
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
Typical Basel prices but this time for high quality wares. 
description: Craft taprooms can veer into interchangeability and templates to the extent that the prospect of yet another one can cause eyes to glaze over. This is certainly not the case with Zum Johann where they have carefully curated the interior space to feel pubby and somewhere you could hang out for a while. No cheap seats and stark lighting here, this is a neighbourhood building with wood fittings and patterned tiles which catch the eye on entrance. A very pretty beer garden to the rear which looks to be delightful in summer. And the beer? Yes, the beer - 18 taps and some superb options that are ever changing, touching on everything from Swiss craft to English imports, with a damn good fridge too. Certainly among the superior options in Basel, not to be missed. (Added March 2024)

name: BrauBudeBasel
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A brewery taproom so an unsurprising beer focus. 4 of their beers direct from the barrel.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
A simple setup in reasonably intimate space, not exactly distinctive but the natural space of the building provides a degree of character. Plain wood, black panels, familiar modern lighting. 
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A social spot with an atmosphere somewhere between a neighbourhood pub and a craft beer bar, homely enough that it overall feels like the former.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Brewery wares, merch, snacks/platters, limited outdoor seating
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
Familiar Basel pricing.
description: A brewery tap that's a nice, homely neighbourhood pub rather than some arch 'statement' in some warehouse or other, which significantly improves the atmosphere and social value as you step inside, it is like the kind of pub you'd be happy to go every week. Not super distinctive in appearance, but the atmosphere and building itself compensate for that. With four of its own beers, some of which rotating for new and seasonal offerings, there's enough to go at. While a modern creation, it definitely fills a void in Basel's scene. (Added March 2024)

name: Beat Bar Butzemann
description:
EBG Rating:: 8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Delirium Tremens on tap, an unusual feature for any German bar really, while there are some very decent alternatives like Waldhaus Bio-Zwickl. Reasonably well covered back bar too. 
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A one room scuzzy punk hangout with music and comics posters plastering the walls. Bar to the left with small niche for table football to the right. 
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Student neighbourhood scene, with a relaxed, friendly feel. Enough character and identity to be a place to go at quieter times as well as busy.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Snacks, TV, Table football, smoking permitted, DJ sets, occasional events
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Decent value for what's on offer, although nothing eye-catching. 
description: To understand Freiburg's nightlife you have to connect with its student scene. This means checking out the district of Stuhlinger west of the tracks as well as the Altstadt. Home to a few of the best punk and dive bars outside Berlin, this is a lively city with energy that belies its low-rise, genteel architecture and winding streets. Position Butzemann in the heart of Neukolln or Ehrenfeld and it would be right at home. A scuzzy, unpretentious hangout with a friendly collegiate vibe, some decent drinks including Tremens on tap and table football for some fun. Prices are reasonable and there are events hosted here, but mainly it's about enjoying a venue that's at the heart of a particular scene, also because you can visit many cities and not find a single place like this one. (Added March 2024)

name: Cafe Atlantik
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.4
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
An all-rounder with everything from Landbier to Kir Royal available - the staff may not be familiar with everything but be patient with them!
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Battered old kneipe in building dating to 1890, site of a former brewery. Interior is ramshackle but loveable with dark wood and raise seating, with some nooks and crannies to the left of the bar and wider performance space to the right.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
The holy union of students and grizzled old men show you what type of place this is, but the venue is such a cult destination that honestly you can find female phD students sitting alone with their laptop and coffee doing work here, and couples chatting in the corner. A great atmosphere day or night.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Meals, snacks, live performances, events 
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Very good value daily dishes and happy hour deals, while everything else is more normal, but  fairly priced for the area.
description: Nothing less than a legendary kneipe in Germany. In the building of a former brewery Neumayer whose signage is still visible outside (in disarmingly good condition), it has houses a restaurant, club and jazz bar across storied decades of the 20th Century. The operation Atlantik has existed since 1984 with a focus on providing cultural events and good food and drink at a fair price. The interior is charmingly battered, immediately putting you in mind of a Zizkov dive bar, with a congregation of students and grizzled elderlies, with a few in between here for a cheap meal or the events - which unusually emphasize slam poetry! Atlantik provides employment for refugees and this is sometimes shown in the excellent cooking, although it can naturally make it a little more disorganised at times. The drinks selection is altogether pretty decent too, with enough variation to keep one amused, although craft beer fans may find it a little last-gen, because the focus is on domestic wares and traditional German styles. With a fantastic atmosphere and ease to the place that you can experience day or night, this is a must visit for anyone who doesn't turn their noses up at a scuzzy dive bar. (Added March 2024)

name: Cafe Movie - Freiburg im Breisgau
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
A good range of drinks with the emphasis on covering bases rather than specialising. Fanboys of Tannenzapfle Pils may like to know the bar has a good reputation for its tapped Rothaus bier.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
The name delivers - movie posters used almost like wallpaper here including on the ceilings. A corner bar in a niche by the Schwabentor, among Freiburg's most notable landmarks. Advertised as a reggae bar and there is some evidence of that inside. A typically German happy-go-lucky absence of tastefulness to be found on the signage. Colourful furniture.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Social inside with plenty of niches and booths even in a relatively smaller space. Chatty in the afternoon while the tempo picks up later on. The smoke inevitably has an effect.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Snacks, smoking permitted, TV, jukebox
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Fair value for the location and wares.
description: One of the central late night hangouts in Freiburg, but it is sad to report that due to complaints from residents about the noise, they are due to vacate the premises in 2025. Who would live right next to a bar and complain about the noise?

Anyway, for the time being there's fun to be had here at this movie and reggae music themed kneipe, a smokey, social hangout, colourful and unpretentious in the extreme, not exactly the kind of bar you expect right next to one of the focal points of a city. 

Good local reports of the quality of the Rothaus Tannenzapfle pils may cause certain craft beer fans ears to prick up, while affordable mixers and cocktails should keep everyone happy, aside of those hoping to get home without their clothes stinking of smoke!

If that doesn't bother you so much, then it's one to mark down for your visit. 

(Added March 2024)

name: Litfass
description:
EBG Rating:: 9
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
A reasonable bar given its size, but focusing on covering the basics rather than specialising. 
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A one room affair that has been going for almost 50 years, simple chunky furniture and a naturally social space with table sharing, with a small bar. Walls decorated with small mementos of previous performances at the venue. 
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Superb venue with a genius loci you can feel regardless of whether it's a performance night or not. The social setup naturally invites crosschat and conversation, while the atmosphere in the room is the height of conviviality, warmth, friendliness and cosiness.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, live music, events, smoking permitted
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Familiar pricing for the city centre. 
description: A superb venue est. 1976 hosting music and live events in its tiny 35 square metre one room setup. A Rauch/Muzikkneipe par excellence, with a genius loci you can feel regardless of whether it's a performance night or not. The social setup naturally invites crosschat and conversation, while the atmosphere in the room is the height of conviviality, warmth, friendliness and cosiness. This isn't one of those scuzzy places however, the surroundings are almost closer to a Spanish tapas bar than a Berlin punk dive, and that explains why there's a good spread and cross-section of people here. For those who can't abide or tolerate smoke, it may be too much to handle, for everyone else, this is evidence without a doubt one of the finest bars in Europe. (Added March 2024)

name: Vahe Bar
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.7
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Excellent selection of wines and beers with a European slant.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Historic interior left to shine with exposed brick and wooden beams. The rest is muted but at least sympathetic enough
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Natural character and a sense of hiding in plain sight to it among the tourist crowds.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Snacks, games, occasional events
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Typical for the area.
description: A bar that conjures up the Bruges experience with its exposed beams and brickwork, and a superb selection of beers from a European slant. Natural character makes it a nice place to be, even if the furnishings could be a little more sympathetic, but the intimate space and sense that the bar is hiding in plain sight from the tourist trail makes this not exactly a hidden gem but an understated jewel. (Added March 2024)

name: Augustiner Bräu Mülln
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.6
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Their own brewery beers served 'vom Holzfass', a wooden barrel into the classic steinkrug (stone mug). Welcome to Austria, you've arrived.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Astounding venue which begins by approaching a brewery complex then entering a relatively modest kiosk where glasses are picked up, drinks are paid for and beer is tapped. Then you enter the true beer halls, vast spaces capable of seating thousands, each with a subtly different, yet familiar appearance. The scale surpasses even the grandest German affairs.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
The Schwemme, you either like it or you don't. That big beer hall murmur of laughter and song and discourse cascading off high ceilings and hard surroundings. The experience can be dialled down to a small scale conversation between close friends or a huge singalong and party without the two even necessarily crossing paths.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food, outdoor seating, snacks, self-service, private events
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A fair price for the beer from the barrel. Marzen and a seasonal special is available for much less than you'd pay at some Bierstuben in the city centre.
description: One of the most famous beer halls in the world, a trip to Salzburg without a trip to this cavern, cathedral, and shrine to beer and socialising is to somewhat miss the point.

The scale of the place, even by the standards of lustily sized beer halls like Fruh, Augustiner and Hofbrauhaus is something to behold, and on a busy evening you could easily be convinced the entire city's residents have decamped here.

On arriva,l fetch your 0.5l or  1l stoneware mug from the shelves, and rinse it in the fountain by the cash-desk. This ensures it is clean and cool enough. Then pay for your beer, and you'll receive a voucher, which you hand over with your stein at the beer counter, and the stein is returned to you, full and foaming. Then take your place among the many rooms which flank a long food court where canteen dishes help soak up the booze. Beer is served direct from the wooden barrel and designed to be smooth and highly attenuated - that is to say, drinkable.

Highly unusually, food can be brought in. Thus people have always brought wooden cutting boards for the food, cutlery, napkins, bacon, cheese and pickles in  picnic baskets. This is a complex with a close connection to the Benedictine order of monks who converted the venue from an army barracks in the 19th century. 5,000 square metres floor space is considered the largest establishment of its kind in Austria. A grand total of 2,400 seats in divided into five large halls, three smaller rooms and the splendid beer garden with its magnificent chestnut trees – a welcome source off shade for guests during the summer.

Speaking of halls: in 2017, a new hall was added to the heritage-protected Augustiner Bräustübl: the Abt-Nicolaus-Saal. If it looks familiar, you are not dreaming: it is in fact the historic marble hall of Salzburg's main railway station, which was actually moved from there to Mülln.

The Bräustübl has an average of over 600,000 visitors a year, and is also home to over 240 Stammtische [tables for regulars].

What is dangerous about the place is that your entire trip to Salzburg could be consumed coming here again and again.

It is an interesting juxtaposition, the huge Schwemme and gregarious atmosphere against the refined, high arts on display in Salzburg centre, and shows that there are earthier delights to Austrian life. 

Simply unmissable. (Added April 2024)

name: Zipfer Bierhaus
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A broad range of Zipfer beers with some seasonal specials and a beer of the month (sometimes bottled) outside that range. Simple back bar and good wine options.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Situated in one of the oldest buildings in Salzburg, records dating back to the 1300s. The Zipfer operation has operated for only a fraction of that, but still for an impressive 120+ years. These days little imprint of the historic building remains on first glances but traces of historical layers can be glimpsed if you explore the premises. Two medium sized bar rooms and an ausschenk mean this is no cavernous beer hall but a decently sized pubs.  

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A clear sense of institution and a homely atmosphere with a sense of shelter from the outdoors is perhaps the strongest suit of this place.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
City centre prices, reasonably high
description: Situated in one of the oldest buildings in Salzburg, records dating back to the 1300s. The Zipfer operation has operated for only a fraction of that, but still for an impressive 120+ years. These days little imprint of the historic building remains on first glances but traces of historical layers can be glimpsed if you explore the premises. Today's operation is of a simple, straightforward Inn where drinking is not discouraged, nor is dining, the two sitting together absent of pressure. There is also an ausschenk, albeit fairly plain, opposite the taps for the most casual drinkers. Two rooms, including a slightly more formal room to the rear offer some variety. It is all rather patrician but in a reassuring, rather than cold way. They tap several Zipfer beers, never the best brews, but the variety compensates somewhat, and the experience feels somewhat like being cradled in the bosom of Salzburg itself. (Added April 2024)

name: Whiskey Lounge
description:
EBG Rating:: 8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
 A good range of Irish and Scottish whiskies, a few beyond the norm of what you can find in central Europe, but isn't obsessed to the detriment of other options such as beer, where the typical ex-pat range is complimented with some decent Austrian lagers too.

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A small venue set in historic cellars, fitted with wooden cabinets and pub ephemera. Some of the décor slides a little too much towards generica but the overall effect combining the natural space with the fittings is very, very good indeed.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Cosy, clandestine and immediately welcoming, a space which hosts real life with its trials and tribulations without social climbing, peacocking, and all of that.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Snacks, live music, events
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Though not cheap, reasonable given the location.
description: Oh, no, not an Irish bar! We don't really do Irish bars outside Ireland as a general rule, but do make exceptions for venues that go beyond the norm - this is certainly one of them.

Irish owned and run, the venue already stood a better chance than some ersatz recreation.

What is intriguing about this is the blend of typical pubbiness with the historic cellar surroundings, arches and nooks. The combination of the two is where the magic comes from here.

The bar doesn't let the side down with a good range of Irish and Scottish whiskies, a few beyond the norm of what you can find in central Europe, but isn't obsessed to the detriment of other options such as beer, where the typical ex-pat range is complimented with some decent Austrian lagers too.

Live music events and other community activities help tie together Salzburg locals with Anglosphere ex-paths.

A reliable late bar (outside Sunday and Mondays of course) gives ever more reason to end up in here for a nightcap.

But it is really that lovely welcome, the golden glow and the sense of harmony to the place that pulls us back. 

In 2025 rechristened "Whiskey Lounge"

(Added April 2024, updated January 2025)

name: Zeche14 Musikkneipe
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.7
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Limited tap options but a decent fridge concentrating on German beers from different styles, including some local options. Cocktail menu and competent back bar.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Historic premises with attractive vaulted ceilings, curved archway. Decorated with Bochum football club memorabilia and rock music nik naks. A smallish venue with a main room and back room.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Casual and reasonably intimate, this is for socialising and letting your hair down, and works whether busy or quiet.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food, music, board games, TV
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Fair value for the offerings.
description: Passau centre is almost infamous for its lack of nightlife, so just across the river, the annexed town of Innstadt picks up the slack. This is a casual, likeable kneipe which has an easy familiarity supplemented with some attractive historic interior fittings and personalised decor - rather surprisingly - from Bochum football club. That doesn't dominate though, and the Muzik part of the kneipe also plays its part. Drinks are relatively perfunctory across a broad menu, but the fridge compensates for the shortfall in good tap options. It is good value too, especially if you want a no-frills light meal cooking. A vital service to the community given the shortage of other available options. (Added April 2024)

name: Pivovar Čejetice
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.4
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A small brewing operation covering a range of styles, with 4/5 taps, some permanent, and others seasonal rotations. All have a quite distinctive quality.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Simple farmhouse kitchen interior, with exposed beams, a steam heater and rustic surroundings that are very pleasant. Communal tables and a classic hospoda feel. A wide yard out front for summer days.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
It feels at the heart of rural/small-town Czechia in its rhythms, but an engaging owner and his wife, along with their friends will make you feel welcome, and if you can speak any Czech at all, even better.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Beer shop, snacks, outdoor seating, fireplace, musical instruments
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Very fair value for money for what's on offer.
description: An intriguing operation, their flash website is quite a departure from an endearing humble rustic taproom. A 5 minute train ride from Strakonice drops you in this hamlet, walking past beautiful farm houses and streams to the brewery. As you enter a wide yard, the taproom is across the other end. Be sure to check the timings online before your visit as this place is not open all-day-every-day. The taproom itself is set up like a humble hospoda. A steam heater, fully kitten out taps and basic furnishings that feel like being in someone's pantry. This is at the core of the appeal. As you sit sipping the owner and brewmaster David's creations, you will feel truly off the beaten path. As you may expect, your journey there may produce some friendly questioning! As afternoon turns into evening just remember to keep your eye on those trains back to Strakonice or Pisek!

name: Restaurace U Tomáše
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Pivovar Strakonice beers, including a Polotmavy, Klostermann permanently on tap. In good condition, overall not the typical dive bar options, which help it to stand out.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
Simple backstreet one-storey building with a back garden, a home turned pub, if you like. One room interior with darts playing and a small compact bar. 
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Very much a local's drinking den and one that may well intimidate some who prefer more genteel settings. Genteel this is not. Ordinary chat and banter, darts in a bunker type environment that's better visited by those who have spent time initiating themselves in such places.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, outdoor seating, darts, TV
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Fair value for money for everything concerned, it is deliberately set up to cater for that end of the market.
description: Strictly for those who enjoy the atmosphere of a thriving 'Pajzl'. Not somewhere you'd take your partner out to dinner, but there is a charm to its endurance and an stubbornness to be enjoyed in its utter refusal to bend to the latest whim. As usual, you'll find a host of characters who may look a bit scary, but are all there for a chat and a laugh. Knowing a few Czech phrases will serve you very well in such places! Just as the country is well known for its breweries and big city beer halls, a pub like this couldn't be more typical and couldn't give you more of a flavour of working class pub going in the country. Fair value for basic goods, darts and a fully laid back hangout. It squeaks onto our guide. (Added April 2024)

name: Hospoda u Hada
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Their own brew, Had'ak 11, with some more familiar Strakonice beers and big names as alternatives.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
Simple basement hospoda with taps by the entrance an a lounge room partitioned with mock conservatory tiling. Simple rustic setup, nothing to dislike, nothing much standing out.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmospheric as afternoon turns to evening, particularly on music nights. Simple and social, a fixture of town nightlife with various gossip to catch up on. Naturally social and casual.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
PET bottle shop, snacks, music nights
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Very fair value for what's on offer.
description: A pub connected to what was formerly claimed to be the smallest commercial brewery in the country, cooking their single beer, an 11 degree light lager from a small 50l pot. Operations have expanded to a bigger kit, and the venue as a pub is alive and well! A simple, unspoilt hangout where groups of friends assemble to chat and musicians may appear for their weekly get-togethers. Service is stolid and reliable, and the prices are very fair. With the closure of some of Strakonice's best pubs, this has to accordingly step up. Well worth a visit, and don't be deterred by an absence of online profile. (Added April 2024)

name: Hostinec U Jiřího z Poděbrad
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.7
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Platan 10 and 11 on tap. Previously not our favourites at all, but we are closer to the source at Protivin, and the owners here know how to pour a beer. Simple stripped back list of alternatives.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
First Republic vibes both from the exterior and the small taproom as you enter. A bench opposite the taps and leaning table gives a classic 'knajpa' appearance, while a partition leads to a lounge area. 
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️
Very much dependent on trade, but certainly worth trying when it's busier. Could use a broader clientele.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️
Snacks, TV. The absence of adornments is almost a seilling point in this case.
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
We won't undersell this part - it has among the cheapest good beers in the entire country. 
description: A charmingly unspoilt hospoda, you wonder how this place is still here. Content to turn up, and grind it out week after week, the simplicity of the setup belies the turbulent times we live in, and perhaps that helps the operation feel like everything is ok. They could use the support of a broader clientele, but let's focus on the positives. The knajpa style taproom on entry is a glorious throwback, and the beer you'll be poured, Platan from Protivin is presented pristinely, for a price that competes among the lowest in the entire country. The elderly tapster knows a thing or two about how to pour a beer, let's just say that. Through a partition is the lounge which has a relaxed atmosphere during the day, but is certainly worth exploring later to see if it picks up pace. As such a survivor, it is well-worth checking out while in Pisek and more charming than some of the modernised places down the road such as Na Sadech. (Added April 2024)

name: Pension ALFA & Whisky Pub
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
The expected Czech beer selection, ably supported by a broad range of approximately 100 largely good Irish, Scottish and US whiskies, with otherwise standard back bar including some cocktails. There is also a wine cellar.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
US saloon bar décor in a dark, moodily lit interior. A natural bar space at the entrance is the focal point with rear room up steps to the side.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Very much local life plus a few guests, with the stamgasti assembling at the bar area and additional customers filling out the space as the evening goes on.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Guesthouse, outdoor seating, food, snacks, music
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Good, but not outstanding value.
description: Set in the heart of Tabor's historic core in a 16th century building which now operates as a guesthouse as well as a pub. Penzion Alfa offers something which Tabor doesn't have, a casual down to earth saloon type bar with extensive whisky selection, a point of difference that is welcome for a town of this size. The interior is shadily lit and feels like a nice place to hangout in the evening whether busy or quiet. It ticks a number of boxes as well as being superior for a provincial Czech pub, meaning you should take note for your visit. (Added April 2024)

name: malý pivo
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.7
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A compact roster of great beers from small independent Czech breweries with large fridge selection for alternatives, predominantly Czech but with some Polish and German presence. Perfunctory alternatives, it is a Pivoteka after all.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
Nothing overly impressive about the interior but it looks like this used to be a Czech hospoda going from the layout and furniture. Approach to find a small/medium-sized taproom with fridges, with a large main pub room through an arch.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere is entirely generated by people here rather than surroundings, but you'll be pleased to learn that the place is vibrant and nearly entirely frequented by locals due to the fact that as of 2024 hardly any tourists have heard of the place, let alone those prepared to travel out to Strasnice/Prague 10.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Snacks, TV, limited outdoor seating, occasional events
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Fairly priced considering the quality of the wares.
description: The phrase 'small beer' travels, it would seem, but this rather self-effacing title shouldn't disguise what is a vibrant and not all that small operation. Based on the corner of what was surely once a typical Czech hospoda, this has been rebooted for the 21st century while still retaining a core pubbyness. Modern beers are the order of the day, which includes faithful, high quality takes on traditional styles. A roster of 5/6 taps is ably supplemented with a row of fridges, you will surely not fail to find something you enjoy drinking. Although the interior is plain and would benefit from some personalising for its own identity, the sheer vibrancy, neighbourhood atmosphere and total departure and absence of tourists makes this at the time of writing somewhat of a hidden gem. The funny thing is it really doesn't take long to get to. Can you sit on a tram for 20 minutes from the centre of town? There you go then. No excuses! (Added April 2024)

name: Restaurace U Kašpárka
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.6
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Pilsner Urquell delivered in typically slavish religious fashion, a tank operation here. Not too many other beers to mention, but a broad range of alternatives.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A truly beautiful bar area you will approach from an entrance hall. Distinctive tiling and nautical ephemera make this, by Czech standards highly unusual. A warren of rooms follows and there is a fair bit to explore. 
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
This far outside Prague you can be assured that there are no tourist crowds, so there's a local feel. A versatile venue that has a big food menu, so during the day the atmosphere does unfortunately centre around that at the expense of drinking, something not helped by overly officious service. They will simply refuse to let you sit in the bar even if it is completely empty of their regulars, which is a big downside. However, the venue itself and the prospect of evening graduation from dining to socialising makes this worth returning to. 
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
TV, food, snacks, jukebox, outdoor seating
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Reasonably mid/high priced given the location
description: U Kašpárka's décor is striking, something you don't often see around in a country more used to either minimalism or convention. They've gone for a nautical theme - the location doesn't give too many clues as to why, but the district Rybnicky, or 'Ponds' is at least one straw to clutch. 

Opened in 1993 it began as a basement operation before expanding to become more of a pub restaurant. It's a big operation these days and pretty forward thinking for an outer Prague pub, the English menus and English speaking more akin to what you'd expect to find in the centre. 

A very distinctive bar begs you to sit down and enjoy it, but unfortunately the server doesn't, and unless you have the ability to plead with them (we didn't), you'll be placed in one of the side rooms, which are not quite as exciting. The key to maximising the experience is to get a drink at the bar, or on the terrace surrounded by mature conker trees

While the stickler service was a real downside, it would be churlish not to acknowledge this is a very impressive venue and perhaps one day we will have enough political capital to be honoured by a place at the bar itself. 

(Added April 2024)

name: Restaurace U Veverky
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A Pilsner Urquell place which does justice to the beer, always very consistent. A typically traditional Czech back bar of alternatives. 
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Corner entrance leads to a rather unexploited taproom which could be seriously improved, however the main pub room is a joy, at least a typical Czech hospoda with its wood panelled walls, chunky tables and communal seating, decorated with old wireless and radio units on shelves around the room.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️
Sadly let down by an unexploited bar/knajpa area which really could enhance the pub as a whole, while the main dining room is really overly food most of the day until the evening approaches. That said, it is a friendly place with good service, the environment is typical and unspoilt.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food, meals, TV, occasional events
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Typically on the mid-high range for operations outside the touristic centre, but good quality.
description: It has taken us several visits to finally acknowledge U Veverky, a pub that has always wandered there or thereabouts an inclusion. It is a Pilsner Urquell pub, but more of a typical hospoda than the likes of U Jelinku with its vibrant taproom. As you enter you will be tempted by the prospect of a casual beer on the stand, but this goes unexploited here, without the furniture or layout to make you feel particularly welcome doing that. A big oversight. But onto the positives - great beer and very reliable consistent classic Czech cuisine - good portions too, enjoyed in what is a very typical hospoda environment of chunky long tables, wood panelled walls and communal seating, although this is supplemented by a mini-museum of old radios and wirelesses, adding to the places character. The pub's name "At the Squirrels" references the horse chestnut trees that line this particular area of Dejvice. (Added April 2024)

name: U Budyho
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.7
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
A couple of beers on tap with a wholly stripped back and perfunctory array of alternatives.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Entrance down a dirt track off the street into some allotments, where you will be presented with some faux-street signage to an entrance lined with trees. The shack appears to be partly constructed of salvage, with the awning featuring anything from old books to bits of plastic tennis racquets. It overlooks clay courts and smallholdings.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A true one-off and hideaway from all things touristic and modern. Somewhere to relax, but also on certain evenings to celebrate art and culture.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Snacks, cultural events, live music, access to tennis courts
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Among the cheapest places for a tapped beer in Prague.
description: A quietly in-the-know collective of old artists, poets and progressives at this shack/krcma/hidaway at the far end of Liben marina area. Accessible via a dirt track and very hidden away.
Ultra low-key, unpretentious and authentic looking spot, perhaps not the friendliest welcome for outsiders, but surely worth a try for anyone with some Czech pleasantries.

Entrance down a dirt track off the street into some allotments, where you will be presented with some faux-street signage to an entrance lined with trees. The shack appears to be partly constructed of salvage, with the awning featuring anything from old books to bits of plastic tennis racquets. It overlooks clay courts and smallholdings.

It is amazing to think the place is still holding out in its craggy way while Liben marina has been turned into one of Prague's most ultra-modern districts.

On our first attempt to visit we neglected to check the opening hours - these are published on their Facebook page! Check before visiting.

Second time around, we made it. Excellent place. (Added April 2024)

name: Drapal Restaurant
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.6
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Pilsner Urquell disciples with some alternatives, including the Volba Sladku, Prazdroj's monthly special creation on tap. Typical back bar.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
L-shaped Pilsner Urquell Original restaurant with raised areas decorated with heritage signage from the brewery and historic merchandise. Furnished with the usual dark wood tables, but lacking any social bench seats, and there are quite a lot of high tables.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A very popular social hub which drives the atmosphere score higher, naturally. Something of an institution which counts in its favour.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, TV
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
A little higher than average which can be typical with such places, but nothing any Westerner would flinch at.
description: For a few years we have to admit we were a little sniffy about including Pilsner Urquell Original Restaurants on the guide given so many are cut from the same cloth. We missed out on this one which shows a little more flair and originality than some as well as having dedicated drinking space, which overall makes it feel like more of a social venue than a restaurant. The L-shape on different levels helps, with high tables opposite the bar. Pilsner is of course presented and poured immaculately and service is also decent. The decoration is familiar but well executed with historic Plzensky Prazdroj (Pilsner brewery) signage and branding. You can't say much more than well done, well-executed and if you have the time to go here for a beer, do so. (Added April 2024)

name: Na Božence
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.4
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Poutnik, one of the greatest Czech lagers available in unfiltered (Spinavy) or filtered form. A very familiar set of back bar options covering central European classics.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
A neighbourhood pub in a building that looks half like a shack, while on entry rather brightly coloured geometric panels decorate the walls, not exactly typical. A long bar with communal tables opposite and further room at the rear.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A frankly brilliant social neighbourhood pub that sets the atmosphere poised on excitable, friendly, chatty and vibrant. It's completely off the usual radar and even Brno residents may not venture near it due to its location in Kralovo-Pole. A mixed crowd young, old and everything in between.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Snacks, games, books, TV, outdoor seating
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Excellent value for beers and good value all-round. 
description: Fans of Poutnik may be well aware of U Poutnika, the eponymous pub in Brno centre, but there are two pubs elsewhere that should certainly be on your radar. One is U Vsech Svatych south east of the city centre, and this is the other, a short tram ride to Brno's Kralovo-Pole, a new build extension to the city. Located near Zbrojvka Brno's new stadium, there can be days where the fans go here before or after. Outside of that it operates as a friendly, casual neighbourhood pub. This isn't a diner or a pub restaurant but somewhere to meet friends, socialise, relax and let your hair down, something it does wonderfully well. The atmosphere at the bar is vibrant and even on your first visit you can enjoy being ensconced among the crowd. Poutnik Nefiltrovany on tap for pennies - bring it on! Even with stiff competition this has comfortably entered our Top 10 Brno pubs. Go here. (Added May 2024)

name: Hostimil
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.2
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Zavis, a safe bet of a Czech pilsner if there ever is one, with a few alternatives and an array of perfunctory back bar choices.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Basement venue. The style? Well, a squat? Something along those lines. Ad hoc with a main bar/lounge and rooms around it which have been, let's just say...personalised.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Part of Brno's underground scene, this is a love-or-hate venue with a punk/drop-out attitude and aesthetic.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Toasties, snacks, smoking permitted, games
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Entirely fair value.
description: One of Brno's cult venues - love-or-hate, but when you read those that love the place, you begin to respect the sense of the appeal. People threatening to leave the city if it closes down generally grab your attention. Similar in vibe to underground venues like Mydlo and Blues Bar, as soon as you walk in you feel like you've left normal life and whatever rules and jurisdictions no longer apply - and not just because of the smoke! Despite all this, the young server will churn out toasties to keep punters happy, pour pretty respectable Zavis 12 beer and set the scene for drop out lounging, smoking, tomfoolery and whatever else you might imagine goes on in a punk/alternative pub. Take a look around and it's clear this has never graduated from being an alternative bar to a tourist destination, and very probably never will, even with our recommendation hung around its neck! (Added May 2024)

name: Sklenena Louka
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.9
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A reasonably well-stocked back bar, with the beer options typically Brnoese - that is to say non-standard. 
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Eye-catching exterior signage which appears to lead to a tea room upstairs, instead dive (dive being the operative word) to a basement with mosaic tiling and small raised area to the back of the room.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
The place retains a truly underground feel as well as simply being a basement bar. The minimal decor helps with that, it feels a bit like a storage area no-one was really ever meant to go in. A host of regulars crowd the bar, but the atmosphere is very casual and chatty.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Table football, snacks, upstairs tea room.
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
description: GO DOWN TO THE BASEMENT, NOT UPSTAIRS

Now that's out of the way, the description, Meaning 'Glass Meadow', Sklelena Louka is a confusing venue with an upstairs tearoom which seems prim and proper, with the other side of the telescope downstairs in the basement, an alternative, counter-cultural dive bar for clandestine hangouts, chats at the bar, table football at the backroom. It shows once more the diversity of Brno's scene that such places can still survive outside of the typical corporate templates. While the place would benefit from a little further decoration, the feeling of being off-grid here compensates adequately. Even the beer options, normally a weak point for such places, are pretty good! (Added May 2024)

name: Desert
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.1
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A broad back bar covering many basis, supplemented by several superior tap options featuring beers you historically would never find in such a venue.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Basement venue with nouveau inspired detailing with tiles and patterns that immediately catch the eye. The layout is to allow for performance space that also can be turned into lounge space when there isn't live music on. Plenty to explore or fixate on, even in the toilets.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A late bar which has long been a smokey den, which is something still quite typical among Brno's late evening scene. Young and lively, with a naturally different atmosphere during live music events.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Live music, cultural events, snacks, games
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Very fair pricing given the area.
description: A long-standing club that has been around so long that even the point where it was called a cult venue is in the distant past. A basement venue opening from early evenings onwards that morphs from cool, funky and distinctively different bar to live music venue depending on the time of day and week. The drinks offering has been fiercely upgraded since the early days and you can find several very good beers - at good prices too, along with a versatile back bar.  At each point you look, there's something good about it. Maybe it might be passé these days to local residents but most will have some fun tales to tell about the nights spent in this place, while it is still likely to impress newcomers. (Added May 2024)

name: F. A. Bar - ORANŽOVÁ
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Beer specialists with an impressive roster of craft-focused tap options and a wall of fridges and shelves if somehow that isn't enough. Limited alternatives, but it does what it sets out to accomplish.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Almost like a British micropub, a retail unit on a high street that has become a pub. Inside the orange hinted at in the title comes to fruition in the choice of wall paint, but it isn't too garish, in fact it goes reasonably well with the breweriana which decorates the place. A small bar with seating by the entrance and limited space at the bar itself.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A neighbourhood atmosphere which reflects its distance from Brno centre. It feels like a town that's been strapped on to a city rather than the suburbs itself, but inside the pub you'll find a calm, relaxed and social atmosphere.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Snacks, TV, tap takeovers, limited outdoor seating
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
Among the more expensive options in Brno. Given the location there are not many concessions here even for basic lager, but it won't scare off most Western tourists. 
description: Getting the tram out to the terminus in Lisen feels a little like Prague's pilgrimage to Prvni Pivni Tramway. It's an easy connection to take at the train station and you'll be whisked up here reasonably quickly, after which it's barely a couple of minutes walk to the pub. Set on a high street with a distinctly micropub type feel, this bar specialises in Czech craft ales from small independent brewers, with at least 8 on tap at any one time. A wall of fridges and shelves are stocked with alternatives should they not suffice. The environment is reasonably pubby with the warm terra cotta/orange walls decorated with brewing signage, and the TVs and general social atmosphere remains casual, a place to relax. Service is kind and helpful. If this all sounds like your kind of thing don't discount it just because it's a tram ride away. Getting to the pub and back to Brno is very simple with regular trams well into the evening. (Added April 2024)

name: U Jelena
description:
EBG Rating:: 8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
As well as superb well-treated Slavkovsky beer, you'll find a well-stocked back bar for alternatives, everything from Negronis to non-alcoholic options.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A truly tiny venue, much of which is taken up by the bar itself which juts out well over half-way into the space. Crowd around the bar or take a leaning post by the shelf. The design in the interior is personalised, warm with some individuality and character, as well as a more feminine side than many Czech places, overall alternative going on post-grad.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Lively, friendly and social, it doesn't take much to get things going in such a small place, which has a natural energy to it.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Snacks, books, games
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Scrupulously fairly priced.
description: Great little bar along a grand thoroughfare, space inside that might fit a maximum of about 20 people crowded, but Jelena has a nice atmosphere, friendly staff and a alternative/post-grad crowd. Slavkovsky beers are well treated and fairly priced, it's somewhere you can go to hangout and relax, meet someone new. The format is also quite unusual for Brno, which has a diverse bar scene but nothing quite like this. Keep it in your back pocket! (Added May 2024)

name: Café In The Ghetto
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.7
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Café style offerings, but this is Czech Republic so that also includes high quality tapped lager and a backbar of various spirits.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
A simple vintage interior, plainly decorated with antique furnishings, however this is supplemented by the Kaznice complex it is connected too, a former penitentiary whose grounds you can explore.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A place where the Roma and Czech population gather together, giving it a distinctly different flavour from traditional pubs nearby.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, outdoor seating, cultural events, musical instruments
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Very fair value for money.
description: Attached to Kaznice, a former penitentiary on the other side of the street, there is a quasi-ruin bar feel to this area of town, as the outdoors plays host and there is a freedom to wander and explore. Regular cultural events as well as instruments in the café itself give it a vibrancy in warmer months that should be experienced. Good beer from independent breweries can be found here along with the typical Czech back bar, while the atmosphere is also distinctive. Set in what is known as Brno Bronx, this is a rare example of the population mixing with the Roma community in a pub setting. The operation is also very purposefully welcoming and liberal to people of all backgrounds. It isn't quite like anywhere else in the city, and comes recommend. (Added April 2024)

name: Grasel Pub
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.7
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
4/5 taps from Grasel, whose brewery is located in a village a way west of Prague. The bar acts as a satellite brewery tap.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Attractive basement vaults with a compact bar and some interesting use of the niches and space around. Relatively plain design but the exposed brick is a plus.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️
Reliant on trade to build atmosphere, as is the problem with many basement venues, but service is friendly and if you pick your moment you can get a better experience out of it.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Simple meals, snacks, occasional events
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Entirely fair value for money.
description: Beers from Český Rudolec west of Brno in a satellite taproom set in basement vaults. A small warren of rooms and niches which are characterful makes this an appealing space, but still one that requires custom to get the best out of. The location in a courtyard becomes even more clandestine as you descend the stairs into the little cellar. Grasel Pub has friendly service, entirely fair prices and is all-in-all a superior city centre destination for a beer than many other, much-vaunted alternatives. We recommend aiming your visit for early/mid-evening as the crowd is getting going. (Added April 2024)

name: Super Panda Circus
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.6
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Bespoke cocktails designed to fit in with a theme which morphs every half hour into something else.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Nothing much off the street or in the waiting room, but as you are led into the bar you'll be struck by a fairly big budget, high concept visuals with the screens at the bar. The space is almost like a stage with a raised area looking down onto a long bar.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️
Despite the money poured into it, the space doesn't quite have the atmosphere they evidently hoped, which is not to say it is bad, but the secret changing world concept is more ambitious than the space is able to do justice to. Still, if you're with friends you'll find it's interesting, low-lit and fun.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, concept menu
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
Not extortionate but certainly on the higher end for the city.
description: Super Panda Circus has been going in Brno for many years now, the concept originally relatively novel but will be familiar to those who explore cocktail bars across Europe. On entry you are invited into a concept which is a changing world - so every half hour or so the menu changes, new drinks become available and the colour scheme/theme shifts accordingly. This is mainly executed on screens while the space itself remains fairly static, a low lit, stage like space with a long bar. The cocktails are bespoke and adventurous, some are big hits, others less so, but it's about the novel experience. It's a must-visit for cocktail lovers in the city, although those seeking less artifice will prefer Air Café nearby. (Added April 2024)

name: Tradiční výčep U Václava
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.6
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A Pilsner Urquell pub where everything is religiously around the condition and tapping of the nectar. Traditional Czech back bar options
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Deliberately traditional in character, a one-room Hospoda set on a corner with chunky wooden tables, yellow walls and First Republic influenced detailing.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️
A pub that is in its infancy, still searching for its core audience and developing a cast of regulars. The concept is deliberately aimed to be like the well-known U Blahovky, and there is potential there.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Meals, snacks, limited outdoor seating, TV
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Within the expected bracket for the wares but not particularly cheap for this district of Prague.
description: The success of U Blahovky becoming a cult pub with near national status in Czechia has inspired other operations to create other similar operations. Deliberately marketed as a 'traditional tap', this and sister pub U Vodicku are social and drinks focused, meaning while they do serve food, the emphasis is on neighbourhood social life. Of the three mentioned above, this one is still bedding in, but has plenty of potential. Purposefully retro in a First Republic style, there is genteel detail in an otherwise minimalist setup with chunky tables and a knajpa feel around the bar. It reminded us quite a lot of the 'Fish Restaurant' pubs in Helsinki that cover off a number of bases well, but definitely require custom to prop up a slight shortfall in natural atmosphere.

The Pilsner Urquell is treated as religiously as those places too, and this can be relied upon for that. It will be interesting to return at different times and in the years to come to see if it has fulfilled its potential. In the meantime, if you are seeking to go somewhere off the normal trail of Brno-stred/Veveri/Kralovo Pole this will fit the bill.

(Added April 2024)

name: U Čolka
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A range of beers from small independent Czech brewers and fridge for alternatives, including PET bottles. Decent but stripped back array of alternatives.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Classic half-step basement hospoda, simply but warmly furnished with chunky tables. A series of nooks. Looks relatively new so potential for it to be personalised and gain character.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Looks relatively new so potential for it to be personalised and gain character, but the atmosphere is pleasant and convivial, neighbourly with a hint of city flavour to it, which reflects its position geographically. Popular with 20s through to 40 somethings.

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Czech pub food, snacks, TV, takeouts, limited outdoor seating
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Fair value but relatively on par with the going rate.
description: Two visits was enough to firmly include U Čolka as a guide entry. Out in the district of Žabovřesky and among a street which is fast becoming a competitor to the likes of Traubka, Veveri, Lidicka and the city centre for nightlife. Tábor boasts 4 pubs which are mostly going after a similar audience of young post-grads up to 40-somethings and becomes a lively spot. In typical Czech fashion this is set in a half-step basement with the street semi viewable from the windows. Inside is totally social focused with a series of niches and nooks, all simply furnished. It's a place to hang out with friends first and foremost, but check out the tap options and fridge and you'll find a good range of beer from independent Czech brewers. There's seating out front and a TV if you fancy whiling away the hours that way. Being where it is, you won't find many, if any tourists or ex-pats in the place, yet it does feel relevant and while not the height of cosmopolitan, a friendly adjacent acquaintance to it. (Added April 2024)

name: Mezi Vraty
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A roster of beers from smaller, independent breweries, albeit mainly light lagers most of the time.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
A genteel interior that leans towards that slightly faded distressed shabby chic chalet look, maybe a little too twee, but different to the typical Czech hospoda, and will begin to improve in the evenings.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Village life with some passing cyclists, tourists and sports clubs, people coming and going from the garden in better weather, with occasional singalongs and games in the evening.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, musical instruments, outdoor seating
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Entirely fair value for money.
description: A short train ride from Mikulov (or Breclav), Mezi Vraty is worth hopping off at Sedlec station for. Set in the grounds of a large historic building, with a spacious garden and playground, this is a rural, genteel destination to be enjoyed particularly in spring and summer. Inside, the genteel aspects continue, perhaps slightly to its detriment, but at least it is a little more personalised and distinctive than the average Czech Hospoda - you won't find beer brand tablecloths etc here. A roster of beers mainly from small breweries, and amenities like chess and musical instruments provide a social, casual and community setting, somewhere to hangout rather than have big lunches or dinners, which is to its credit also. The superb reviews are testament to its success. (Added April 2024)

name: Pivovar Mamut
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Superb bottom fermented Czech lagers, unpasteurised and unfiltered available from the tap, with PET bottles also. A spontaneous fermentation side project called Little Creatures adds to an already impressive roster. Seasonal specials available. 
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
The brewery's yard itself. There is a covered table that can be considered the domain of the stamgasti, but can be used if quiet, and outdoor tables in the yard. 
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A small town atmosphere, relaxed and convivial, somewhat ad hoc, but there are efforts to make it more than just a taproom in a yard as well.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Snacks, outdoor seating, takeaway/shop/merch
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Fair value for nearly everything on sale.
description: A mammoth logo but not a mammoth operation, this small brewery in the wine producing town of Mikulov is further proof of Czech's love of the land and what springs from it. The venue itself is little more than a yard with taps and tables built into it, thrown open on pleasant afternoons so you can drink their beers straight from the source. There are some fabulous beers too, from the seasonal specials to their spontaneous fermentation projects under the name Wild Creatures. The atmosphere is that of a town operation, most coming and going seem to know each other, but it is a tourist destination and there are visitors passing by too. An opportunity to experience some personal service and beer direct from the source in a deliberately raw, unvarnished environment is one to savour. (Added April 2024)

name: Pivnice U devatero řemesel
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.9
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Multitap offerings of lagers and occasional ales from independent Czech brewers. Decent back bar for alternatives, particularly rum and whiskies.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A rustic interior with a stables theme, sounds familiar but it's in the execution that it stands out as tastefully done. 
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
One of the hubs of social activity in the town and a particularly pleasant, convivial atmosphere to spend an hour or two in the evening.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Jukebox, courtyard, snacks
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
