description: A small town like Mikulov where wine dominates is perhaps not where you'd expect to find casual beer-focused pubs, but despite the influx of tourism and demographics connected to wine drinking, a lovely pub like this is still carving out a niche for itself. An atmospheric taproom blends traditional and modern with aplomb, offering a decent range of beers across different independent breweries. The place really is somewhere casual to hangout and socialise, a very pleasant spot indeed. (Added April 2024)

name: Enoteka
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
120+ wines available from samplers 
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
Historic premises of an old city brewery, with a terrace overlooking grand vistas of the wine valleys and river, as well as the historic buildings of Znojmo. The interior is plain to neutral, a large space set up for the sampler machines and high tables.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️
Whitewashed interior doesn't bring out the history of the site, sadly, but the terrace is magnificent and ably compensates.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, shop, outdoor seating
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Fair value for money, in fact significantly cheaper than you'll pay only a few miles away in Austria.
description: Normally our guide focuses on the experience rather than purely epicureanism, but here is a venue where both go hand in hand. Situated within the old city brewery's complex, Enoteka's unique selling point is 120+ wines available to try by the glass from a sampler. Collect a swipe card, put however much money you're willing to part with, then go exploring the vault of wines. You can try anything from a dribble to half a small glass, and this is a great primer for exploring the regions wine - mainly dry to semi-sweet, with a number of grape varieties and styles which will be unfamiliar to Western eyes. Their terrace, overlooking the Thaya valley and Znojmo's iconic central church is a superb setting on spring days or balmy late summer evenings. Don't overlook this place. (Added April 2024)

name: The Huntsman
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.7
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A superior range of cask ales for a rural pub with rotating guest ales. Keg and back-bar are more ordinary.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A somewhat tired exterior leads into a charming and unspoilt stone Inn. Stretching across a wide room with an additional games room to the rear. Carpeted with simple traditional pub furniture. Low beams and hunting/sporting memorabilia.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Social and chatty as opposed to a dining pub, this is somewhere to have a drink and a chat, pleasingly casual.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, Thai food night, local honey for sale, pool, darts, outdoor seating, books, instruments, open mic night and other community events
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Good and fair value for the offer.
description: An increasingly rare find, The Huntsman's emphasis is on community and social bonding despite its semi-rural location, offering a plethora of amenities from its food, snacks, Thai food night, local honey for sale, pool, darts, outdoor seating, books, instruments, open mic night and other community events to give people every chance to come here for a drink. The drinks are good too if you enjoy cask ales, with several on rotation, mainly at very affordable prices. The interior is worn in, but homely with musical instruments and memorabilia relating to hunting and local sports teams. The effort put into the place should be highly commended in an environment that is causing such venues to close at an alarming rate. (Added April 2024)

name: The Joiners Arms
description:
EBG Rating:: 8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A good range of 5/6 traditional handpump cask ales which span local to some more famous names. Competent back bar, the keg options probably the only shortfall.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Set in a row of terraces at the foot of a hill, standing out clearly on the street. Inside you'll find a lounge to your left and a raised step to a narrow bar, leading to the pool room at the back. Traditionally furnished including a working fireplace.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Social, homely and welcoming feel with friendly staff and a sense of a place to hangout. 
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Pool, bar billiards, snacks, TV, darts, games machine, limited outdoor seating, community events, quiz night, open mic, etc.
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Entirely fair value.
description: A lovely backstreet neighbourhood pub just outside Lincoln's historic core but perfectly easy to reach by foot. The operation has a social focus and a comfortably homely interior that invites a longer visit, particularly during colder months with the two fireplaces crackling. They keep the place as a traditional pub with bar billiards, darts and a pool room with several cask ales to enjoy from independent breweries both local and more well-known. Add to that quiz nights and open mic and you have a pub that is serving its community fantastically well. (Added April 2024)

name: Sunset Jazz Club
description:
EBG Rating:: 8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A typical lounge bar menu of cocktails augmented with a house vermouth and perfunctory beer selection. Competent back bar too.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A stylish bar of two rooms, the first by the entrance slightly set up for dining or at least wining, with the performance space in the backroom being slightly more casual. Reds and soft furnishings, candle light.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Friendly service puts you at ease even if the format may be uncertain initially, and the peak is undoubtedly during live performances, but even on quiet days there is a relaxing, organic feeling ambience that invites you to dwell there to soak up the atmosphere - and the booze.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, live events, limited outdoor space
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
Reasonably high but corresponding to the quality. 
description: A popular jazz club, the atmosphere comes from the live performances and brooding candlelight, even if the interior itself is furnished in a little  loungey. A stylish bar of two rooms, the first by the entrance slightly set up for dining or at least wining, with the performance space in the backroom being slightly more casual. Reds and soft furnishings, candle light. Friendly service puts you at ease even if the format may be uncertain initially, and the peak is undoubtedly during live performances, but even on quiet days there is a relaxing, organic feeling ambience that invites you to dwell there to soak up the atmosphere - and the booze. Home made vermouth is well worth a try, as is a perusal at the cocktail menu. (Added June 2024)

name: La Pedra
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.7
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
While keg options are basic, a fridge full of craft cans - several from Catalonia is a welcome sight in a tapas bar. 
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
A compact one-room bar in the core of Girona's historic centre, a small terrace outside leads to exposed stonework and simple furnishings inside, with the bar somewhat personalised.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
As one of the very few good options for beer in central Girona, and due to its diminutive size, it fills up quickly, leading to a typically casual atmosphere inside. The service is a little gruff but its values are pretty sound, when you look into them.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Tapas, snacks, limited outdoor seating
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
Slightly higher than average for both food and drink, but they just about correspond to the quality.
description: La Pedra's excellent online reviews are spoilt only by the interference of some dubious remarks by Spaniards objecting the the fact their menu is in Catalan / English only. Ignore those and pay attention to the rest. A small bar with a punky attitude that pumps out simple tapas and offers craft cans from a fridge by the bar. Simple stonework is accentuated by the general atmosphere of being at the heart of the historic core of Girona. Lively evenings to be enjoyed with interest local beers. As one of Girona's very limited array of outstanding bars it deserves your attention. (Added June 2024)

name: L' Elixir
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A bottleshop which gets beer deliveries so fresh that on occasion they are canned on the exact same day they go on sale in this store. Local brews supplemented with regional and nationals with some very limited alternatives.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
The bar, if you can call it that, is the owners upstairs room and balcony looking out over the  Onyar river. This features a little bird in a cage and a shelf of books. 
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
The atmosphere is of the kind of casual lack-of-barriers approach that has largely vanished from hospitality. Being invited to drink upstairs in a store is another level of casual format you won't have normally experienced. 
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Deli counter, books, pet, limited outdoor seating, tasting events
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Value corresponds to the quality, while not being dirt cheap either.
description: On initial appearances L'Elixir looks like an opportunistic venture designed to snare some tourists en route to Girona old town, but things begin to change as you take a closer look. With a deli counter and array of beers that are so fresh some of them were canned on the very day they went on sale, and an owner who will invite you to enjoy them in his upstairs room or on the terrace, this is a venture very much designed to keep locals onside too. You don't know who will be out there with you on the balcony overlooking the Anyar, but its a great place for a drink - particularly such a fresh one. For quality and for quirkiness, this must be experienced. (Added June 2024)

name: Bar Bodega Carol
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.7
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Wines and vermouths by the barrel, and basic beers - beer not the strong point here.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Historic corner bodega a step down from street level, with rows of old barrels and dramatic collection of keyrings festooned on the rafters. A roughly wedge shaped room with bar to the right and assortment of tables.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Not only characterful due to the history and interior, but vibrant and relevant feeling with an energetic duo working the bar, kitchen producing plate after plate of food, and superbly social, buzzy atmosphere even during the afternoons with a mixed crowd including many younger people.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Tapas, snacks, game machine, outdoor "seating"
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Fair value across the board.
description: One of Barcelona's historic Bodegas that belongs to a list inscribed as part of the city's intangible cultural heritage. But this ain't no museum (Although it remains interesting to look at that way), but a bar that is vibrant, relevant and exudes the kind of energy, conviviality and values you're looking for in a neighbourhood boozer. Due to the location in El Clot, you won't find this place overrun with tourists but instead there's a healthier blend - mainly locals and a few foreign residents with the odd tourist tagging along. What's the bar all about then? Well, order a plate or two of tapas and grab a beer of vermouth (or wine) to enjoy these with. Everything is set up simply and straightforwardly, commanded by a duo of assertive but engaging and friendly women. For some reason even the presence of an arcade machine slap bang in the middle of the bar alters nothing of the experience or character of the place. If you've been peering at some old grainy photos online of a quiet Bodega from back in 2011 or something, think again and prepare yourself for one of the city's finest buzziest bar experiences. (Added May 2024)

name: La Confitería
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.2
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A very good standard of cocktails with a broad, near comprehensive back bar for alternatives. Some wines/beer available too.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A former patisserie, the name references in the venues title, the interior is a blend of preserved interior features dating back to the 1910s and recovered signage which has been carefully fitted in the 1990s and again in the mid 2010s so as to blend sympathetically with the ensemble. A wide bar with fittings and ornate framing, with open windows and a terrace leading street side. Around the side of the bar is a long, loungey backroom with a hint of gentleman's study about it. Somewhat familiar but well executed and superior.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
There is always a sprinkling of stardust about a venue with preserved fittings and the natural character does a lot of heavy lifting here. Simply being in or around the bar feels like partaking in a time-honoured ritual. The energy increases as evening approached, before which there is a more café bar feel to it. The table service adds a little bit of an unnecessary formality, although some will enjoy the special treatment. 
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, outdoor seating, books
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Considering the history, the location and the popularity, there are some entirely reasonably priced drinks on offer, while you can also splurge if you wish to.
description: One of Barcelona's special places, a historic building with use dating back even before the 1900s patisserie which this cocktail operation is named after and who inherited many of its fine fixtures and fittings. What meets the eye isn't all original though, but a carefully curated ensemble of original fittings and recovered items which date from around the era it was constructed. A wide bar off a terrace instantly makes a good impression with its beautiful carved wood, after which you will be shown to a table. A compact menu of their house cocktails will help focus your mind, each of which produced with a satisfactory degree of élan without going over the top. The service does make this place more formal than usual for Spain, but among the bar space itself the atmosphere is chatty rather than private. The energy and thus the conviviality increases as evening progresses, turning a café atmosphere into a late bar. Along with the cocktails a kitchen produces some interesting stuff. Highly recommended. (Added May 2024)

name: Gran Bodega Saltó
description:
EBG Rating:: 8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
A diverse offering to satisfy but you won't find too many standouts among them.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A historic bodega given a macabre makeover in 2002 into something quite unusual, without extinguishing the venue's previous character either. Enter past a row of giant barrels into a space with seating at the rear and a balcony overlooking the bar. The makeover is - slightly hard to describe, but colourful, kitch and twisted in its own way, in a Latin style. 
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
The decoration lends a lot of character from the outset, but this Poble-Sec district institution is popular and lively, most of all on evenings with live music. At quieter times you'll find a cast of regulars and folk coming and going - casual, informal, and mixed. 
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Tapas, takeaway, live music
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Fair value overall without being a standout.
description: Formerly a wholesaler and traditional Bodega, new owners renovated the place to become almost a carnival, one long celebration of Barcelona's culture. This has produced a vibrant, slightly twisted but certainly relevant feeling venue which hosts live music in the evenings and a truly mixed crowd enjoying its casual informality. Huge vats, a balcony and that macabre design, all carefully lit provides a highly distinctive setting to enjoy some drinks and tapas. A must-visit venue in the city. (Added May 2024)

name: Vermuteria del Tano
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.9
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
A familiar trad selection of Spanish staples (wine, vermouth, lager) from a tiny bar.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A corner bar with small interior and café furniture, with distinctive and characterful interior, that classic combination of cream walls, old barrels, family photographs and tiling.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Extremely popular and frequently oversubscribed venue which is all about that hyper-social dynamic in Spanish bars. You need to make your presence felt, don't worry about personal space, for there is little to be had here! Once sorted you can enjoy the atmosphere and conviviality of a truly authentic, popular and relevant venue.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Tapas, snacks, limited outdoor space
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Fair value for what's on offer
description: A Vermuteria, corner bar, neighbourhood pub where you grab a couple of their little dishes (mainly fishy) to enjoy with a Vermut, wine or lager. A very popular operation which revolves around two bar staff and two servers working their socks off to keep demands satisfied, drinks produced and served, old plates and tables cleaned for the next set of visitors. Hyper-informal and all about being among the throng. A characterful little venue with a familiar Bodega appearance and sense of community and historic value. There is very little to dislike unless you aren't a fan of seafood tapas, but those of you with a nervous disposition and a problem with personal space should probably look elsewhere. (Added May 2024)

name: Casa Almirall
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.9
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A broad selection of drinks with tapped beer the predictable shortcomings, however there are plenty of decent options overall. The Oliveta, house vermouth is a historic tradition, while Absinth is also served.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Founded in 1860 with fittings dating back to the Belle-Epoque, elegant curved wood carvings on the fixtures and fittings. The bar area remains very well preserved, while the loungier backroom is the victim of a 1970s renovation.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
The interior ensures a vitality and ambience even while quiet (which isn't often). This is a bar which opens in the early evening until the late hours, so spending time here you can feel the atmosphere evolving around you.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Tapas, Snacks, books, games
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
City centre prices
description: Among the surviving clutch of historic city centre bars, Casa Almirall has also preserved its 19th century Modernisme facade and interior. Situated on a corner, enter to find a wonderful time capsule of a bar with elegant curved wood, marble table tops and muted lighting. Opened circa 1860, not much has changed inside except a 1970s refit of the rear room. Famous for the Oliveta vermouth and offering Absinth, typical of such places like this and Marsella in the Raval, you can momentarily slip off the space time continuum and enjoy a drink in this bohemian destination. One can only hope it can survive another 150+ years. (Added May 2024)

name: Bar Leo
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Basic tapas bar wares with a familiar setup.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A small streetside tapas bar in the heart of Barceloneta's grid pattern. Inside you'll find cuttings and photos of the singer Bambino in a small café with basic canteen style seating at the back and a highly personalised bar at the front.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Busy, buzzing and gregarious, with stretching room and personal space at an absolute premium, but that's not the point. Get stuck in and get outside your comfort zone. Spilling out onto the street due to its size, it is a bundle of passion and energy, much like its owner.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, limited outdoor seating.
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Fair value.
description: Nothing short of a cult pub, the diminutive Señora Leo is its beloved emblem, and she can be found much as she has for years, passing through crowds of people with drinks and plates of tapas. An old port district bar that has had a lot of life and vibrancy pumped into it. Firstly, the shrine to singer 'Bambino' which can be seen decked around the bar and walls, the Flamenco on all-day-every-day and the hordes of people old and young who assemble, often spilling out onto the street. Don't expect anything flash from behind the counter to consume, but if it is energy and life you are seeking, you'll find it here in abundance. (Added April 2024)

name: Mesón del Cafè 1909
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.6
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Typical broad but not deep café bar fare.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Founded 1909. The establishment occupies the entire width of a narrow plot of land where a ground-floor, five-storey building faces Carrer de la Llibreteria . The facade  stands out for structure that imitates the capcer of a farmhouse, with rustic cladding painted white and topped by a gabled roof. The access portal is centered with a eaves of tables, above which there are two windows that advertise the typical products of the establishment and, above, a wooden board announcing the name of the place. 

The interior has two distinct spaces: the bar's own space with small marble tables and a separate room inside. It retains the original furniture, such as the wine cabinet that extends along the wall behind the counter and a cabinet for the old coffee machine. On the left wall is a ceiling-high wooden trellis with framed pictorial motifs.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
The historic character gained over time and its situation right in the heart of Barcelona's old centre gives the place a pleasant feel, partly aided by the sense of surprise something like this can still be here. While ostensibly a café, the dark wood, alcohol and lively staff, along with pub seating to the rear of the bar make it feel more like a tavern.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, limited outdoor space, newspapers
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
City centre prices
description: The sense of surprise that such a business could still be here in the heart of Barri Gotic in the modern era, with all its commercial pressures and fashion whims is a positive feeling that is sustained once you're sat inside, with its dark wood, mirrors, preserved fittings and tavern like character elevating what is ostensibly a café into a bar. The backroom with its partitions and communal seating are handy for plotting, while grabbing the slimline tables at the front is a good place to people watch. With lively staff and a sense somehow that it hasn't become oversubscribed or ruined by tourists - the latter being almost miraculous, it sustains a clear recommendation from us. (Added May 2024)

name: La Bodegueta de Cal Pep
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.6
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A very good choice of wines and vermouths is the focus, with perfunctory alternatives.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
A one room narrow bodega with a high ceiling and long bar, opposite which are rows of tables. The Bodega wine barrels are still present at the back and there are some preserved features on show dating back to 1927.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A social, pleasant hangout spot without the throng and bustle of many of the tiny operations around the city, but still pretty convivial.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, limited outdoor seating
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
Central Barcelona prices, although for reasonable wares.
description: One of at least 3 Cal Pep's, be sure to distinguish between them before setting off for either. In Gràcia, you'll find an old drinks focused bodega (Carrer de Verdi, 141). Cal Pep in Born is a famous seafood restaurant (Plaça de les Olles, 8).

Here in Sants, this Bodegueta (small bodega) offers a revamped take on the traditional format, marrying tradition in appearance with relevant food and drinks. This is largely successful, an operation that you could find yourself going to a lot if you were lucky enough to live in the neighbourhood. We hope they will retain and perhaps even accentuate the original features and atmosphere more, as further modernising would not help it retain its character. (Added May 2024)

name: La Bona Pinta
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
8 taps, always featuring a good lager, Spanish craft and interesting stuff from overseas including occasionally some lambic. Several fridges if that isn't enough.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
A small corner bar with shop front type bar room and seating to the rear. Done in a familiar ramshackle industrial style.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
The rear room does lack a focal point without a bar, but the bar area is quite good, and when busier it works as a venue anywhere you're sat.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Shop, snacks, outdoor seating
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
A craft beer bar in central Barcelona near La Sagrada Familia, so I'll leave you to work out what the prices will be like.
description: The gap between the Spanish bodega and the craft beer scene shows no sign of narrowing, the former still persevering with 1 or 2 taps of basic lager, the latter still aggressively partitioning a certain demographic. Very few Spanish bars manage to bridge the gap of providing product and a distinctive venue. A few manage to be distinctive in their own right however, and this goes for La Bona Pinta, a neighbourhood corner craft beer bar with a good range for its compact size, a casual, and fairly unpretentious approach and enough space to allow it to fill up and generate atmosphere. There are clearly ways it could improve but for what it is bringing to the table, it deserves an inclusion. (Added May 2024)

name: El Celler d'en Frank Peterssein (Bodega Armando)
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.6
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A large back bar up a high ceiling indicates the breadth of drinks options available to you. Wine, vermouth and beer are the most common, all of which are serviceable, but the better of these is the wines and vermouth.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
An unassuming facade which still retains the appearance of a wine store rather than a bar, with boxes on display, enter to find these stacked up the walls along with the typical bodega barrels. An attractive bar is adjacent to the entrance in a small square room, to the outside of which tables are placed.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
The usual applies in respect of the history of the place. 
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️
Snacks, basic tapas of meat, cheese, olives and bread.
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Decent value for the area.
description: Low-key, friendly and uninterested in the latest trends, this bodega is interested in making you feel at ease, pouring their home made vermouth and providing a base for socialising in a historic environment. Many bodegas have lost the sense of the shop, their previous function, but this one still feels like you could imagine suppliers coming and going, the bar element placed over it yet not fully replacing it. The drink can be enjoyed with classic Mediterranean platters of cured meat, cheese and olive with fresh bread. This isn't a show-stopper by comparison to others in terms of its visuals or late night atmosphere, but for authenticity and legitimacy, it ranks high up. (Added May 2024)

name: Bar Colombia
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Basic café bar wares, covering bases without distinction.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
An interesting venue, tight entrance where you are greeted immediately by the bar with a tiny kitchen to your left, then a wedge shape widens to a small café area with pubby lounge to the rear. Lived in and worn-in, decorated with heritage photographs and festival/cultural posters. There is also a mezzanine overlooking the bar. 
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Characterful interior, and you can sense the distance between where you're sat and the next tourist miles away in the city centre. Local ritual and sound, albeit with an international flavour, this is certainly not a patrician Catalans-only place. Loungey pace but relaxing and welcoming.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, takeaways, newspapers, books
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Fair value for pretty much everything
description: Bar Colòmbia opened in 1913 and is still run by the family that founded it, now in its third generation. Originally called Kiosko, the bar changed its name to Hispano in the 1950s. It was renamed during the Franco era. An 'early bar', the focus is on breakfast/brunch food and morning til siesta lounging. It closes at 4 or 5pm every day, so this is no night spot. It is however, one of Barcelona's best examples of preserved heritage, and the service, ritual and lounge to the rear feel sufficiently pubby to be included. Certainly if you placed the bar somewhere like the Balkans it would be one of the more pubby places you'd encounter.  Fair value for food and drink, so long as you're not after anything too fancy you'll enjoy the strong sense of place, the identity brought to it by the staff and its operation, and the loyalty of its regulars. (Added May 2024)

name: The Tetley
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.9
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
6 cask beers, 8 craft keg lines, Kirkstall Brewery plus some guests, mainly from the Yorkshire area.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A repurposed venue, formerly Tetley Brewery's head office before their parent company closed down the site. This was reopened around 2012 by a joint venture and turned into a gallery, museum and cafe. The current operation has inherited much of that but redesigned it with the typical Kirkstall Brewery design style of recovered Breweriana festooned on the walls. 
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A heritage building in itself, with areas to explore, albeit slightly sterilised by the period where it was partly serving as a gallery. The new decor has elevated the natural character of the building, while on summer days the exterior is a sun trap and atmospheric place to be.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, books, heritage venue, outdoor seating, live events
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
Typically unrelenting Leeds pricing more expensive than the beers are sold in many places outside Leeds.
description: A repurposed venue, formerly Tetley Brewery's head office before their parent company closed down the site. This was reopened around 2012 by a joint venture and turned into a gallery, museum and cafe. The current operation beginning April 2024 has followed Kirkstall Brewery's takeover, and they have inherited much of that but redesigned it with the typical Kirkstall Brewery design style of recovered Breweriana festooned on the walls. There is a clear improvement on the interior decor, the general atmosphere as well as the range of food and drinks. When summer comes along the terrace will no doubt be heaving. A tad predictable, but nonetheless a successful resurrection. (Added May 2024)

name: God's Own Junkyard
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.9
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A cocktail menu is the only notable thing pushing their offerings beyond the norm, and this is the focus. It is a pity the bar is near two breweries yet sells beer from neither of them.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A warehouse of active neons and hoardings, you will never tire of exploring the pieces exploding from every inch of the building. Really quite something. 
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Characterful and atmospheric by virtue of its interior decoration alone, but it is certainly a novel and unusual experience altogether.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, outdoor seating, shop, gallery
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Fair value considering what's on offer and the museum is currently free of charge.
description: Marcus, Matthew and Max Bracey are inheritors of a neon lineage that has been passed through the generations, and have turned their warehouse of neons for carnivals, businesses and advertising into an eye-popping museum and café. Free to enter, but certainly you should think of making a donation or buying a drink, you can lounge among the hoardings and signage, among the most distinctive places you'll visit anywhere on Earth. What's more, as part of Ravenswood Industrial estate, the terrace is shared with two breweries and street food vendors, meaning on summer days there is a carnival atmosphere where each business feels like it bleeds into one. They prepare cocktails which is a plus, but the beers could use a revamp, it is incredible it is sighted near two brewers and serves beer from neither. Nevertheless, an essential visit. (Added June 2024)

name: Café De Pieter
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.9
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Haacht dominated taps, but there are plenty of them, with a good range of styles to choose from, with classic lowlands Pilsner from Leew, to Belgian ales, to IPAs. Competent back bar.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Typical Dutch brown café with some faint Parisien and seafaring leanings to the many artworks fastened to the walls. A small establishment with a terrace on summer days, the main room offers a small selection of tables in a traditional, but bordering on cosmopolitan setting.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Social, friendly and relevant during the day, and calmer too. The evening picks up the pace but this is still not one for a trashy night out, more one for a drink and a chat as afternoon slides into evening.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, outdoor seating, music, games, live music
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
Typical city centre Dutch pricing.
description: Set in the Jerkerkwartier, a more quiet and leafy part of Maastricht, the afternoon ambience in De Pieter is a blend of French-influence with classical Dutch brown café atmosphere. As chanson plays in the background and you gaze at the Parisien scenes on the wall, you feel oddly completely at ease yet unmoored. A quick survey of the wider scene will anchor you. A small bar with gregarious bartenders and plenty of beer taps (albeit mainly Haacht) churning out the good - and not so good- stuff to all and sundry. Order a vaasje or fluitje of Leew as a classic, or chance your arm at one of the Belgian beers or Dutch IPAs available. A busy social hub with a touch of class, something Maastricht distinctly lacks despite all its money, as any attendees at Carnival will attest to. A superior, understated option to enjoy. (Added May 2024)

name: In de Karkol
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.9
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️
Very basic options from Brand, with a well-used back bar for liqueurs.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A small one room bar with front room and narrow side area, with the bar itself in the centre. Red paint, wood strip and a fun Snail diagram on the wall. However you'll largely only notice the throng of human heads.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Your dream, your nightmare or a quirky change of speed. This is a singing café, which over here means pack yourself in as tightly as possible, get sipping and munching (mind your elbows) and party.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Snacks, limited outdoor space
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
Typical central Maastricht prices
description: In the 37 square metres that encompass this pub, many tales have been told of the nights out here, singing oneself hoarse, drinking oneself senseless, and more besides. The Burgundy Snail is duly painted in rich red, with its diagram taking up the wall space adjacent to the bar, in case you needed to know what the name meant. A famous, award-winning historic venue with a line in bustling singalongs and a lack of personal space usually reserved for popular tapas bars in Seville. Yes, if you dislike either of those, I would steer clear. For the rest however, it is worth joining the throng for an atmosphere entirely unlike you'll find somewhere like England, either because you're into that, or because the novelty value is sky high. Sip on little beers and munch on plates of Dutch tapas (beige buffet) trying not to clatter into people as the surge of song and good cheer rides through the pub like a wave. Apparently there are quieter times too? Well, who'd have thunk it! (Added June 2024)

name: Grotesque Absinthe Bar Aachen
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A strong selection of absinth that covers most bases of styles and emphasis. Without being totally exhaustive, it will be one of the larger lists you'll have seen. Ample alternatives albeit with a limited beer selection.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
HP Lovecraft inspired interior decked out like a Victorian study. Missing one star only for the execution which is more theme bar than the potential it could reach. A small venue with plush seating around 5 or 6 spots.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
The novelty, sense of experience and surroundings propels this into being interesting, atmospheric and characterful.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Snacks, books, musical instruments, occasional events.
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
More expensive than average but not extortionate.
description: The 'Green Fairy' awning out the front stands out in Aachen's altstadt where you are more expecting to see Gothic script and a Wirtshaus than an Absinth bar, but as it turns out, this is one of the cities most distinctive venues. Inspired by the tales of HP Lovecraft, the interior - if a tinge too 'theme bar' does a good job of placing you in the environment of a Victorian study. The waiter will approach and guide you to an absinth of your choosing. Generally they slide towards tasting more like Pastis or more like bitter wormwood. The water decanter will be set up, and you are left enjoying the drink in a rather opulent, hedonistic and ever so slightly macabre scene. Just as they intended then! Well, the execution is not flawless but it's still very good, and we can comfortably recommend a visit. (Added June 2024)

name: La Maison Du Peket
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Pekets, a Walloon take on Jenever, available in 30+ varieties. A backbar of typical alternatives.

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Historic townhouse with natural brickwork, recovered signage and largely tasteful decor. A large building with the bar acting as a natural focal point but siderooms for overspill.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Lively, upbeat and somewhere to go in the middle/towards the end of an evening out.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, outdoor seating, taster trays
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
description: It isn't often you encounter a brand new drink, but in Wallonia, they have their own take on Jenever, Pekets, something which must have slipped towards the more obscure corner of the liqueur library. Unlike Dutch Jenever, Pekets are mixed a little differently, resulting in a slightly longer drink. Like Jenever, this can be adulterated to virtually any flavour under the sun. But what about the venue? Set in a characterful old townhouse, the pubby bar area is very much set up for drinking and socialising with an increasingly young vibe as the night progresses. The interior is kept reasonably in keeping with the natural environment of the building with exposed brickwork and suitable signage, which leans on its history somewhat, without ever becoming staid. Are there times where this may become a little bit too towny? Probably, but this is the nature of the beast. Lastly, do not be confused by the restaurant  Amon Nanesse that shares the building and is in effect the same operation. (Added June 2024)

name: Le Volcan
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.3
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
BIO/Organic wines from the region (and beyond) selected by the owner. At least 30% of the stock at any given time is 'natural wine'.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Eye-catching frontage evokes 1970s psychedelia with its wobbly bright yellow text, and makes you wonder what's inside. You'll find a tiny little drinking den with leaning posts, highly personalised, with the décor largely mementos and presents, while shelves and cases of wines are present too. A small bar at the back is used for the owner to dive back and forth with the latest bottle.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Extremely intimate and personal, to the extent that it almost feels like bordering on gatecrashing if you aren't a regular. However, you are welcome, or at least tolerated and the experience is of a kind of bar barely existing anymore, particularly in the heart of a major city.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️
Wine for sale, snacks
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Entirely fair value given the quality and location.
description: Le Volcan is the passion project of Eric Desouches, a throwback bar with a 1970s feel, little more than a shop that has been highly personalised. The loud frontage with its psychedelic title screams at you to give it a try. The passion is for natural wines, and a recommendation is very easy to acquire. You'll be drinking in a tiny, personalised bunker, a shrine to wine, if you like. It feels like it has been open since forever but is actually a product of the late 00s. The venue acquired notoriety for hosting parties long into the night, even operating without a bar license (it was technically a shop), allowed smoking, among other fights with the authorities. Set in the now buzzing Rue des Filatiers, it could hardly accept sole responsibility for noise pollution given virtually every business on the street is turning into a bar or eatery. For French flair of an old-school variety, here is the place to go. If you associate wine with social climbing, to be seen and be seen, or have any pretense in that regard, steer well clear, so the rest of us can enjoy this idiosyncratic, grumpy old survivor. (Added June 2024)

name: Nabuchodonosor
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.4
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Natural wines, approximately 4 white, 4 red, and a few orange/roses. These can be from France, Slovenia or anywhere else so long as they fit the criteria. 
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A one room bar with old nouveau fittings, small tables along the wall opposite the bar and lounge furniture to the rear. Pastel shades, with candels. Attractive bar area.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Supremely atmospheric among candlelight, a bar with both poise and verve, neither screamingly pretentious nor shabby, it is pitched at a bohemian level, and the service is extremely friendly, welcoming and helpful.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, games, piano, limited outdoor seating
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Entirely fair value for what's on offer. Wine drinkers in the UK will double-take at what can be acquired at these prices.
description: Although it looks like the kind of place that could have been conjured up in the 00s, Nabuchodonosor has been around since the 1980s, acquiring an almost mythical status in the decades that have followed. It wears that relatively lightly, content to flow with the tide rather than self-mythologise (at least so long as you avoid social media accounts). The place is superbly understated, lacking the pretense and social-climbing generica of many wine bars that people like us find off-putting.  It is a place to meet up, relax, socialise and prefers to set the environment to an informal, atmospheric setting. The place is decorated in a stripped back, bohemian way, a one-room joint with a little space to mill about on the front. Their speciality is natural wines, and the menu is pared back, making a decision easier, and emphasising quality over quantity. Typically French with a cross section of people counting from students, amateur philosophers, artists, romantic couples and anyone else looking to enjoy a spectacularly good wine for a nice price in an environment that oozes charm and atmosphere. (Added June 2024)

name: Le Bar ( Belfort )
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.2
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Far superior to the average corner café. Local craft beers as well as a cheapo lager are the main event but there are the typical French backbar offerings too.

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A corner café on a square, fitted with a colourful pastel Art Deco bar and sympathetic furnishings, with movie posters on the wall and some recovered antiques on the shelves. The bar itself and the shelf adjacent are eye-catching, immediately elevating this beyond the norm. A small backroom with faux-leather banquette is another unexpected feature.

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
The effort in the decoration makes this a winner from the outset, but genuine local life, rather than simply the domain of the in-crowd makes this a more intriguing venue as a result. Everyone from your old granny, to young lovers, to excitable groups, to station wastrels and everyone in between pop by during the course of the day.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Snacks, live music, occasional events, Happy Hour, books, limited outdoor seating
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Considering the location and wares, reasonably priced.
description: One of the nicer surprises on our journey, this venue was very much inked as a long shot when we researched the city, but what a delight to find such a distinctive bar with good beers, fair prices and a neighbourhood life that means it virtually owns the square it is situated on. Close to the train station, the annoyingly anonymous sounding 'Le Bar' is anything but when you arrive. With a 1950s influence, this corner café is fitted with a colourful pastel Art Deco bar and sympathetic furnishings, with movie posters on the wall and some recovered antiques on the shelves. The bar itself and the shelf adjacent are eye-catching, immediately elevating this beyond the norm. Local beers as well as a cheapo lager are the main event but there are the typical French backbar offerings too. The crowd around here is different from Place de la Trinite or Les Chalet, being close to the train station, giving it a genuinely broad, democratic audience rather than just being the home of the see-and-be-seen crowd. Interested yet? Well, you ought to be. (Added June 2024)

name: DAda
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.2
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A bar range covering a diverse range of bases well. If you want local beer, vermouth, cocktails, gins, wine, they'll rustle it up. The diversity rather than depth is what earns it the marks.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Dadaism influences the bar, an alternative reaction to the mainstream, so you'll find recovered equipment, musical instruments, antique nik-naks fixed around a single room space, low-lit with a dusky feel in the afternoon before coming into its own in the evening. Imagine a Kazimierz antique bar with some French flavour and you've got it.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Characterful even when quiet due to the artistic surroundings, but the loungey space and rear garden change character during the evening adding further atmosphere to proceedings.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Meals, snacks, music, occasional events, outdoor seating
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Fair pricing, and Happy Hour deals.
description: DAda clearly taking inspiration from some of the best 'antique bars' around Europe, particularly Kazimierz, but rather than evoking a particular era, this is used more to create an artistic statement, as its name would suggest. Whether that's a bit too pretentious for you or not, it doesn't really matter, you've made it to France already, so get used to it! Stripping back the bar to essentials, they offer a broad range of food and drinks to satisfy virtually everyone while Happy Hour deals are pretty reasonable too. With some live music and a nice back garden this is a place that methodically ticks almost all the boxes while being rather distinctive too. Hence, it's included on our guide. (Added June 2024)

name: l'Echanson
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.1
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Quirky selection rather than comprehensive. Paulaner Zwickl, yes, Picon, yes, but lacking in some areas too.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
On a square, the frontage of l'Echanson is beautiful with ornate wrought iron balconies, art nouveau detail and a narrow frontage that draws the eye towards all that detail. As you're stood in the square, triangular with a fountain as a centrepiece, it really feels like the place to be. We haven't even talked about the bar inside, yet! There's a rustic interior with exposed beams, yellow/brown walls and a mezzanine overlooking the bar itself. It's relatively understated with minimal retro style decoration, and a few tables furnishing a bench opposite the bar.

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A sense of significance due to dominating a square and being almost always busy. Friendly service and a fixture on the social scene. Terrace atmosphere outside, characterful, if small, inside.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Snacks, outdoor seating
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
A little higher than average for what's on offer.
description: On a square there is often a bar/restaurant that 'owns' the square, a focal point of social life, and this is it on Place de la Trinité, an area between Carmes and Esquirol metro stations which has become the place to go in Toulouse in the evening. The frontage of l'Echanson is beautiful with ornate wrought iron balconies, art nouveau detail and a narrow frontage that draws the eye towards all that detail. As you're stood in the square, triangular with a fountain as a centrepiece, it really feels like the place to be. We haven't even talked about the bar inside, yet! There's a rustic interior with exposed beams, yellow/brown walls and a mezzanine overlooking the bar itself. It's relatively understated with minimal retro style decoration, and a few tables furnishing a bench opposite the bar. Due to the limited space, 90% of people are outside, but it does make it easier to get a seat. Drinks offering are quirky rather than replete, but there is enough to explore to keep one occupied. Service is busy, but friendly and it deserves a higher rating than currently received online. (Added June 2024)

name: La Tireuse Beer Rock Café
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.1
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A high quality beer range that is a match for anything in the city, covering local and continental across a long line of taps. Perfunctory alternatives.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
The bar is decorated with panels from old beer crates which is quite effective. A long narrow room with chunky furnishings that leads up a step to a further backroom, plainly furnished but quite homely rather than arch-craft/modern.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A nice casual place to hang out, escape from the heat (or occasional rain) and an easy informality. While the relative lack of high powered beer bars in Toulouse lends it a sense of importance that might veer into superciliousness with certain members of staff, it largely stays the right side of the line.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Small plates, snacks, board gamers, events, limited outdoor seating
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Fair pricing relative to its location, quality, etc.
description: Toulouse has a sense of élan which can be found in bars across the city, which gives it a distinctive identity, but there are times when you just want to unwind in a homely environment with a nice beer. La Tireuse is a superior beer bars with a strong range across 15+ taps including local produce and some ciders. These are enjoyed in a narrow bar with a step up to a further backroom. Enjoy a charcuterie plate, maybe a board game, and relax with friends. (Added June 2024)

name: Bradley's Spanish Bar
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.3
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
description:

name: The Vines The Big House
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.2
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A strong cask ale selection with options from independent brewers along with familiar, trusty brands. A well stocked back bar for alternatives.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
One of Liverpool's most opulent pub interiors restored and brought back to life. The pub which was rebuilt in 1907 as a Cains house is one of the great show pubs of the country, and is on the Campaign for Real Ale's National Inventory of Historic Pub Interiors. Plasterwork, on the theme of "Harvest", in the smoke-room of the pub was created by sculptor Walter Gilbert 1908. Plasterwork and glass in the other rooms are the work of Henry Gustave Hiller.

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
The surroundings are enough to appeal whether it's quiet (rare) or bustling, but the central location inevitably means this is a grand pub for the masses, not somewhere to go for contemplation over a quiet pint.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Pies, snacks, TV, limited outdoor space
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Fair considering the central location.
description: Aptly known by Liverpool locals as 'The Big House', this grand city tavern is an astounding venue keeping the flame burning for the kind of lavish, elaborate and opulent pubs breweries were financing at the time. Well preserved, a series of grand rooms each offer artistry and atmosphere of their own, from the stained glass ceiling of the billiard room, to the baroque cherubs in marble relief in the lounge, to the hunting lodge kitsch of the main bar. Unlike local competitiors this pub has not been dragged down into chain-pub territory either, with some very decent beers from independent breweries and a sense of identity it has retained, a singularity rather than feeling subsumed into part of one template conglomerate. To put it more simply, it's a damn fine place to go for a drink! (Added July 2024)

name: Hobo Kiosk
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Local independent craft keg ales, good gin selection and bases are covered for alternatives.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A basement bar with a 'dive' feel, but far too colourful and quirky to ever be described as one. A labour of love with salvage, memorabilia and nik-naks lovingly curated on the shelves around this one room pub. A small bar in the centre of the room acts as a bit of a soapbox.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Friendly, welcoming and all-round lovable, you are made to feel comfortable and belonging to the bar, conversation is easy between strangers and owners, a good place to meet new people, but also a good place to relax in an environment unlike any alternatives.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Live music, events, merchandise
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Fair value considering the quality of produce and operation.
description: A former shop, crowdfunded into a bar, the brainchild of Delia and Tristan Brady-Jacobs, you can safely state there is nothing else quite like it in the city, or indeed for miles around. Set in a shallow basement (think Czech style) you will be greeted with an interior that is an eclectic labour of love, one of those bars you can sit in for hours and find something new to look at. A friendly greeting and farewell is always provided to those who visit the venue in the spirit with which it has been established. Unashamedly quirky with a personal touch that quite obviously sets it apart from more commercial operations. What about the drinks? Well, a small bar focusing on local independent brewers. Beers are all keg rather than cask, but this works perfectly well for the operation and its intentions, while there are bases covered for alternatives. In such a quirky, colourful bunker conversation naturally flows, pinging from table to bar to table, each group sharing why they ended up here today, what they're up to and where they're heading next. A community focused venue with musical and artistic leanings, so you can find gigs and events here at an all-round lovable and distinctive bar we hope will be around for many, many years, indeed generations to come. (Added July 2024)

name: Kazimier Garden
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.2
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A decent range of keg ales superior for an events venue of this kind.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Set in a vacant spot in a row of city blocks, a courtyard that looks like it may have formerly been a car park. Semi-covered with booths and a balcony above the bar, not a fully fledged 'Ruin Pub' but something moving very close towards it. Large indoor events venue adjacent.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A very nice change from the usual Northern venues, a sense of ease and atmospheric surroundings added to be the untethered feeling of being able to explore and the live music.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Snacks, live music, events, outdoor seating
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
As could be expected for a central bar, not cheap but no ripoffs.
description: A spinoff from its original venue, now in its own right a Liverpool destination, Kazimier Garden applies the Budapest ruin bar template and shows it can work in another city, in another part of Europe. Semi-covered courtyards with greenery, booths, live music and a sense of ease, that you can wander round untethered helps create a friendly, semi-carnival atmosphere. The drinks are decent, perhaps not what they were a few years ago but superior for a venue of its nature, and you can be assured of variety in what you're going to witness when you arrive. (Added July 2024)

name: The Grapes
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.6
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
9 cask pumps featuring local and regional smaller breweries among high quality national brands. One pump now regularly serves a real cider. Extensive selection of rums. 

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
Warm, colourful interior with a tribal/ethnic/hippy decor splashed across the bare bones of a traditional pub. It is fairly inoffensive despite that description, but might not be a traditionalist's cup of tea. A corner bar with chunky furniture and lounge space to the rear and upstairs.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A neighbourhood local, but being on the fringes of the city centre, it also has a city-ish feel too. Some regulars, some passing trade, and a feeling of quiet confidence to the place.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Snacks, outdoor seating, live music
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Fair value overall considering what's available
description: An 1804 corner local with some remaining features and layout, but subject to an extensive refurbishment. No longer any kind of traditional pub in its decoration, but the bare bones will still have a familiar ring.. Known as the 'Little Grapes', but an extension has expanded it. Stairs now lead to a partly sheltered patio area, atop the extension. Community events and live jazz every Sunday make it a great choice for couples, groups of post-grad types, bohemians, artists and so on. A little soft for Liverpool, but that kind of variety is a good thing. (Added July 2024)

name: The Red Lion
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
3/4 cask ales, focusing on local independent breweries. Strong gin selection and competent back bar.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A retro vision bringing back a war era terrace pub. Globe lamps, print wallpaper, signage and advertising of the era, and comfortable bench seating. A small ground floor with rear outdoor seating area, and further space upstairs. Exposed floorboards. 
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A naturally characterful venue, although perhaps lacking a particular corner or focal point of socialising which would  elevate it beyond a richly enjoyable curio to a true regular hangout spot, but that is due to the layout and building they've chosen.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, TV, outdoor seating, games
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Similar pricing to anywhere else in the vicinity.
description: To look at the place, you'd think it had been a local pub since the 1930s, but this is an adventurous and ambitious conversion from a terraced house to a retro-traditional pub. Inside is a thin cosy space well fitted with globe lamps, wood fittings and signage of the era. It is nice to see a vision brought to life with this level of panache. However, it isn't simply a museum, with TV, outdoor space, meals, modern beers and enough amenities to draw in different crowds. This must explain the great reviews. Definitely one to keep in mind as it conveniently links the city centre with the Baltic Triangle or Georgia quarter if you are doing a pub crawl. (Added July 2024)

name: Doctor Duncan's
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.6
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A decent range of cask ales and well stocked back bar.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Housed in an insurance building dating from 1901, repurposed to become Cain Brewery's flagship pub, the grand exterior hints at the opulence to be found inside, although this won't greet you straight away in the bar room other than an impressive cabinet by the entrance. Instead, walk across the bar to the tiled room, where a staggeringly beautiful and intricate arched, tiled room with a high ceiling greets you. The theme is more muted in the loungier backrooms but consistent overall with the ensemble.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Some intrinsic character by virtue of the unusually lavish surroundings, but this is a pub with a varied layout and different corners with their own feel and atmosphere.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Meals, TV, snacks
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Typical city centre prices.
description: Even if you haven't time for a drink, the elaborate tiling at Doctor Duncan's is worth popping your head through the door to look at, one of Liverpool's architectural gems, even in a city with more than a few. Varied rooms with a more workaday hustle at the bar and loungier back room space provide a degree of versatility, but the high ceilings and sense of institution put this firmly in the bracket of 'city tavern'. Drink options are decent with a well stocked back bar and range of cask and keg which include independent brewers. A heritage venue with some relevance, not without flaws but with true quality as well. It should be on your to-do list. (Added July 2024)

name: Cafe de las Horas
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Broad menu of drinks options with beer selection the only real shortcoming, however ably compensated by alternatives.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Baroque, Moorish, hints of the Belle Epoque and good old kitsch style this one room café with plush reds and blues, café furniture and portraiture on the walls.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A place with an excitable feel owing to the novelty factor and, at night, the feeling of grabbing a table inside. It morphs over the day from café to evening bar, but really comes alive later at night as the sense of the outdoors reduces, and the feeling that this is the only place in the world increases.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, outdoor seating, takeaway options, occasional themed events
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
City centre prices, but not extortionate.
description: Along with Casa Montana, Cafe de las Horas is a bar famous not only in Valencia but more widely in Europe.

Hugely distinctive, its baroque interior with lavish decoration and furnishings of rich blues + reds, with Moorish style star-studded ceiling is an eye catching ensemble that tells of a venue working much, more harder than average to provide something out of the ordinary. In a society where bars are largely regarded as an aluminium counter and some canteen furniture especially.

While it takes inspiration from history, it is only a middle-aged venue, established more than thirty years ago, inspired by the idea of literary café bars, (which Valencia didn't have an abundance of), making its reputation in the present rather than the past.

Famous for its pitchers of the citric and lethal Agua de Valencia, there is a broad versatile menu covering everything from breakfast needs to late night cocktails. It opens at 10am and shuts at 1:30am, giving the place a sense of permanence and ubiquity. 

Yes, as years go by it will be obvious, passé even to some, but unless Valencia expands its bar range to put it in the shade, you'll be hearing more and more about it. (Added July 2024)

name: Café Infanta
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
A versatile, broad range of drinks lacking true quality in the beer department, but a well-stocked back bar.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
The owner is apparently an enthusiast of Spanish filmmaking and an art collector, with the bar reflecting those tastes. Old time retro furnishings in warmly lit space across several rooms of exposed sandstone brick walls. A long bar without focal point joins those together, with further room on the terrace, a shell-shaped square with historic links to the old Moorish defensive walls. Neon-signage out-front.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A truly atmospheric venue, particularly early evenings onwards. Somewhat suave and upright with table service, but there is a casual bohemian and friendly nature to it as well.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, outdoor seating, occasional events.
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
City centre prices, but not extortionate.
description: Opened in 1992 in the heart of Valencia's old centre, you'll find this café on a square that used to be the site of the Moorish defensive walls to the city. Unlike many Spanish bars, the exuberance on the street extends to a wonderfully atmospheric interior sprawling across several rooms. While the position of the bar means it someone lacks a focal point, this is ably compensated by the decoration and atmosphere in the rooms adjacent, offering a bohemian, old-time yet still relevant feeling of ease and timelessness. A touristic venue, admittedly, and there are obviously things which accompany that, but with a broad and versatile menu and different spaces to enjoy socialising, food and soaking up the atmosphere, it really is a must visit for a first timer to Valencia. (Added July 2024)

name: Cafè Sant Jaume
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.7
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Only the most basic beers, but there is a competent back bar for wines, vermouth, cocktails and the local Agua de Valencia which adheres to the original recipe.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Beautiful pharmacy fittings in a small converted bar, carved wood, converted cabinets and a showpiece ceiling intricate enough to belong to the Silk Exchange nearby. Plenty of patio seating to compensate for the compact space inside.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Characterful by virtue of the craft of the interior, but also through the sense of institution, the permanence and fixture of the place. Long opening hours accentuate this further, as it feels like this is umbilically connected to Valencia's identity.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️
Snacks, outdoor seating
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
City centre prices, although not extortionate.
description: Among central Valencia's most famous bars, the site of a beautiful 19th century former pharmacy, with the cabinet fittings and floor still intact. The bar has been operating since the mid-90s and its compact size means there is a natural patio extension as its identity spills out onto the street. A firm feeling of institution to the service tells of its cultural significance. The small showpiece bar has only two tables for seating, but a backroom is itself elegant and has a certain atmosphere and allure even when quiet. Versatile, you can find people enjoying their morning coffee, to cocktail drinkers in the typically blurred lines that not so much demarcate as embody Spanish bar culture. (Added July 2024)

name: L'Ermità Café
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A broad range of drinks but more thought than usual applied to the beer range which has some craft bottles from Antiga alongside the mainstream selection.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Beautiful golds, reds and natural wood decorate a warm and welcoming feeling bar. L-shaped with a slightly cavern entrance.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Immediately atmospheric interior whether quiet or busy, stepping up a notch during shows and cultural events, but somewhere you could always choose in virtually any situation.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Live events, instruments, books, snacks
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Fair considering the area.
description: One of central Valencia's best venues, those seeking to swerve  touristic venues without travelling too far outside the historic core would do well to make a note of this place. Beautiful golds, reds and natural wood decorate a warm and welcoming feeling bar. L-shaped with a slightly cavern entrance. and exposed stonework inside. Immediately atmospheric interior whether quiet or busy, stepping up a notch during shows and cultural events, but somewhere you could always choose in virtually any situation. By the extremely stunted standards of non-craft beer bars in Spain, there is a decent selection of beer bottles including local craft to accompany the typical Spanish staples. One of those places that really grabs you straight away. (Added July 2024)

name: Bodega Filà El Labrador
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A large wine selection (this is a bodega) with basis beers and typical Spanish selection of sherries and spirits. Valencian cider available.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A one room bodega with bar to the right of the entrance, a long room with seats opposite by shelves of wine, leading out to a rear terrace. Large wooden vats on show in the typical bodega fashion. Cream walls and a slightly dog eared, but characterful interior, where only the front signage has been modernised.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A truly terrific, characterful bodega from its casual atmosphere to its unabashed nature, dedicated shamelessly to consumption and good times, while the double act serving is a performance in itself to enjoy.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Shop, food, snacks, outdoor seating
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Entirely fair value for what's on offer, perhaps not quite as cheap as Hermanos nearby but well under what you'd expect to pay in the historic centre.
description: One of the most characterful bars in Valencia and the region, Labrador shows that sometimes the variables that combine to make a bar create something beyond the sum of its parts. An old Bodega with the typical hulking wine barrels adjacent to the bar, and long shelf of bottles speaks to its shop/takeaway format, but this is a social meeting hub, not only for mealtimes but any time either side of siesta. A characterful and ultra non-bullshit double act work the front, an organised, snappy and lithe woman (who seems to be doing more than her fare share in all honest) and a shambling, but nonetheless willing portly gent who looks like he sleeps under the barrels after work. There is no menu, and that is where things get interesting. Unfortunately as often happens in Spain, you find out what is available by asking, not always easy if your Spanish stops at jamon, queso, cerveza. Hang on, wait - in all honesty that is probably enough. They largely deal with meat, cheese and bread, which is pretty much ideal to go with the wines and a few bottles of beer. However, if you're in a group you can order hot dishes - on our last visit a cauldron of bubbling snails was produced for the gents sitting next to us. This isn't half the story though - this is a full on balls to the wall boozer with single guys draining carafes of wine straight into their mouth, couples chatting noisily between mouthfuls and a certain something to the atmosphere. Let's say, a shameless dedication to consumption and socialising that lifts it way beyond most of their local rivals, something you won't find at the more touristy, middle-class venues. (Added July 2024)

name: Bodega Valero
description:
EBG Rating:: 8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Typically plain and behind the times beer selection, but a decent wine and back bar selection.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A small neighbourhood corner pub with homely and lived-in interior. Wine barrels behind the bar and a wall with photos of all the good times and gigs here over the years.  
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A truly local neighbourhood pub off the usual tourist trail to its benefit. A lively social scene and musical connection, so the soundtrack (often rock & blues) is part of the identity of the place.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Tapas, snacks, live music, outdoor seating
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Not the cheapest nor the most expensive; it corresponds.
description: One of Valencia's last traditional bodegas still operating, but taken over with a musical twist. The wine barrels and bar remain in place, but the venue has been personalised to reflect the live music and good times experienced here. It's a little place with outdoor seating, the atmosphere spilling out of the pub onto the streets. Local and entirely shorn of pretense, this is a great choice for something rough and ready. (Added July 2024)

name: Bodega Baltasar Seguí
description:
EBG Rating:: 8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
7/8 reds and 7/8 whites offered by the glass at any one time, usually regional, with the usual beer pump and a cider or two. A shelf full of interesting beers which can be bought and consumed on the premises adds to what is a clearly superior offering. The only traditional bodega in the city that keeps the wines in orri.

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A narrow shop with shelves of wine, beer, spirits etc to the left of the entrance and the bar with its barrels and tapas counter to the right. Stools at the bar furnished with upturned barrels and high tables to the back of the room. Traditional in style.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
While traditional, there is a feeling of both relevance and authenticity, a combination that is usually the hallmark of something special. Perhaps there is just a feeling the shop slightly overtakes the bar element, but that is to be extremely picky. Local life, almost exclusively.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Shop, tastings, tapas, snacks
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Fair value for the wares on offer.
description: Established 1957, Benimaclet's primary Bodega is a rarity not only in the neighbourhood but the city in general. The format has remained true to its origins, fully operating as a wine shop as well as a bar. However, with a very decent selection of beers on the shelves there are more strings to its bow for groceries. As a bar, visitors to the likes of Bodega Nadal in Barcelona will be familiar with the setup. Upturned barrels, high tables and a seating area near the rear for drinking wines alongside cold plates of tapas. Service is friendly and welcoming, usually 7/8 reds and 7/8 whites offered by the glass at any one time, with the usual beer pump and a cider or two. Quality and/or local produce is the emphasis but there is much to explore. A traditional setup with character and personality from the surroundings, fixtures and fittings to the staff at the bar. Really a distinctive, superb place. (Added July 2024)

name: Bar Lapaca
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.9
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Typical tapas bar fare - wines, sherries, homemade vermouth with the one lager tap and familiar industrial lager bottles. Ask them to dig around though, they may have 1 or 2 non-standard options.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
An artful place with the emphasis on music and religious iconography. A small terrace out front leading to a small room with eclectic furniture and bench niches, chequered floor and a busy, cluttered bar.

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Instantly friendly, welcoming and appealing even to a first-time visitor. It has kept its neighbourly character while embracing a diverse clientele and passing trade.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Tapas, outdoor seating, occasional music
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, books, 
description: Owners Javier and Laia Llorca started this bar with Javier’s grandmother as their inspiration: LAPACA (painted on the wall, as seen above). She lived close by and when she passed Javier sold his abuela’s house and opened this place. There is even furniture from his grandmother still in the bar. An artful place with the emphasis on music and religious iconography (this is Spain, after all), and a casual informality that is instantly appealing. Only a short walk from the beach, the El Cabanyal neighbourhood has a similar feel to somewhere like Barceloneta, where the streets feel a little sandy and the buildings sun-bleached, the atmosphere laid back and casual, both afternoon and evening. Service is friendly and welcoming, while their tortillas are tempting, portions are very good and taste delicious. In a neighbourhood where the nightlife is perhaps a little overstated (not so much in activity, but certainly the quality of venues), this was the clear standout. (Added July 2024)

name: La Vitti
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.9
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
One of the few non explicitly craft beer venues in Valencia to have an IPA or anything non-lager related on keg, which is itself a hint to their audience. A reasonably compact menu of café bar style alternatives.

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Loungey with some ad hoc, personalised nature taking it beyond any kind of coffee place type mundanity. Overlooking a square, there are usually people sat out, but dive in to a casual, homely and loungey interior with musical instruments in the corner and a long bar to the right with a hatch for window service.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
The place is so casual and low slung it could almost be horizontal. For jazz evenings or stylish, but not showy hangouts, La Vitti ticks the box, but comes to life and adds that all important dimension when busier.

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Live music, food, snacks, instruments, books, outdoor seating.
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Typical value for the wares and the area of the city.
description: A 'piano bar' known for its casual and intimate concerts, but a neighbourhood hangout spot in its own right. One of the few non explicitly craft beer venues in Valencia to have an IPA or anything non-lager related on keg, which is itself a hint to their audience. Overlooking a square, there are usually people sat out, but dive in to a casual, homely and loungey interior with musical instruments in the corner and a long bar to the right with a hatch for window service. The place is so casual and low slung it could almost be horizontal. For jazz evenings or stylish, but not showy hangouts, La Vitti ticks the box, but comes to life and adds that all important dimension when busier. (Added July 2024)

name: Taberna la Samorra
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.7
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Wine focused with 50 reds, 20 whites, most from the region. Typical Spanish taberna options, so short on good beers but well stocked for alternatives.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A rare example of a traditional bar in Valencia centre. Tiled walls and purposefully homely feeling interior. A small terrace obscures a step into a tidy space, carefully curated with niches for seating and a mezzanine area overlooking a traditional bar. Religious iconography decorates the space, in keeping with the nearby churches, cathedral and religious functionary buildings.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A characterful and well put together space with a local crowd despite the central location, mixing with occasional tourists. Casual at the bar and on the terrace while the seating is mainly for dining.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️
Traditional tapas with some seafood focus, outdoor seating
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
City centre prices, but not extortionate.
description: A Taberna normally indicates a restaurant, but this pocket sized and intimate tapas bar feels more casual than that. Maximising space with niches and a mezzanine area, it simply feels pubby, added to by a homely interior, characterful tiling and some interesting religious artwork.
