Its focus is deliberately to show off the region and tradition, a counterpoint to other changes in the historic core, so one of the few bars in the centre anything like what you'd expect to find. Service is open handed and ready to help, and you can either while away the team with a lovely vermouth, wine or cana of beer on the terrace or at the bar, or settle in for some drinks and tapas in the pubby niches that still offer views onto the activity and nightlife on the street. A must visit for the city. (Added July 2024)

name: The Market Craft Beer
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A clearly superior range of beers by Valencia's still overall modest standards, a selection usually covering a range of styles well.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
A corner bar with lived-in, going on ramshackle interior that doesn't know if it is trying to be an English pub or a Cuban cantina.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Popular central hangout which sees groups of people moving in and out of the place like the tides. The small interior means it can go from quiet, dusky and relaxed to gregarious very quickly.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Tapas, snacks, outdoor seating
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
City centre prices but not extortionate.
description: The Market serves an important function in a city that has a thousand bars but at a rough estimate, fewer than 25 offering any good beer on tap. That isn't itself good enough reason to include it on our guide - you only have to look at some of the other craft beer places which are pretty drab or uninspired venues. The Market has a knockabout casual nature, not interested in copying craft templates, instead focusing on its role as a social meeting space. A small, lived-in, going on ramshackle interior is a cosy bolthole that can go from a peaceful place to contemplate over a nice beer, to a gregarious meeting spot very quickly as groups enter and leave like the tides. The beer range is well thought out with a good spread of styles. In another city there would not necessarily be reason to jump up and down about the place, but it comfortably etches a spot on our guide as a recommendation for beer lovers in Valencia. (Added July 2024)

name: Bodega La Peseta
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Typical Spanish tapas bar fare - good wines, whiskies and café bar fare, but a lack of decent beers. 
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Nautical theme in this spruced up, but tastefully complimentary reboot of a Bodega-turned-bar. A single room with tiles and barrels, leading to further room at the rear.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A busy and energetic trade during the day, with nice surroundings, an appealing place to be.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, outdoor seating.
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
Not the cheapest such bar around the city, to be honest, but at least the tortilla portions are suitably enormous to make up for it.
description: La Peseta has rubbed up locals the wrong way in recent years with some tourist concessions and climbing prices, but as a venue to visit it remains appealing. A reboot of a traditional Bodega with some nautical nik-naks and murals complimenting the more familiar tiles and barrels. Tortilla specialists, the portions are large (expensive) and absolutely delicious, to be enjoyed with a vermouth or other concoction. Cabanyal's nightlife is perhaps overstated - more activity than there is quality, for sure, but this is a good option and a bolthole to keep in mind. (Added July 2024)

name: BODEGA LOS HERMANOS
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A strong selection of wines with typical Spanish tapas bar alternatives (vermouth, sherries, etc)
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
The 1970s call with its ochre tiling and bar top, pastel shades alongside a simply furnished space. Wooden tables along the bar with a small rear room.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
An authentic honest operation, this is where to go to separate yourself from corporate trappings and globalised sameyness. Neighbourhood friends and family for the most part, but welcoming enough that no heads will turn, it must be said that is not a huge risk in Spanish bars anyway which tend to be welcoming, but it is notable in an obscure place how that was not a factor at all.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, takeaway, newspapers
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
In an expensive city this is one of the truly fairly priced and honest operations where you can eat and drink well for an affordable price.
description: A traditional family-run winery that's stuck in the 1970s so vehemently it has swung from out of fashion to so out of time it's a fashionable and quite charming curio. A Bodega in name and in deed, this is somewhere you can purchase wine for home consumption, and they do takeaways for fans of their food too. Cold plates of tapas and all manner of nuts, beans, etc are on offer to enjoy alongside the many wines on offer in the bar. A neighbourhood crowd of families and friends keep the show on the road, but there is a feeling that outside of the family rituals it doesn't see as much young custom as it could, compared to the likes of El Labrador down the road. That is a damn shame, but at least we're here to sing its praises. Oh, and while we're at it, the place is superbly good value. (Added July 2024)

name: Casa Montaña
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
They boast a cellar of 500 wines meaning no wine drinker is going to want for much, but what is more interesting is they are mainly available by the glass, which is pretty special. Typical Spanish fortified wines, vermouth etc available, but a limited beer selection.

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Its exterior is a real beauty with a carved Art Nouveau style wooden door making a striking first impression. Enter the main bar room to a picturesque scene. All the typical signature traditional Spanish bar motifs are there - sherry barrels, tiles, high tables, busy bar counter.

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
 it is more restrained than your typical tapas place, in line with the fact this is a foodier destination. You may by all means enjoy a drink on the high tables or at the bar - there are no rigid rules, but the crowd and the service feels a little more geared up for meals, evidence of which can be seen in the rear room. Still, owing to its history there is an excitable atmosphere of people pleased to be at one of the fashionable venues.

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, option to takeaway, limited outdoor seating
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
One of the more expensive options outside the city centre.
description: Dating from 1836, here is one Valencia bodega that does have a long history to shout about. These days there is a patrician feel you often find with such institutions. Its exterior is a real beauty with a carved Art Nouveau style wooden door making a striking first impression. Enter the main bar room to a picturesque scene.  All the typical signature traditional Spanish bar motifs are there - sherry barrels, tiles, high tables, busy bar counter, but it is more restrained than your typical tapas place, in line with the fact this is a foodier destination. You may by all means enjoy a drink on the high tables or at the bar - there are no rigid rules, but the crowd and the service feels a little more geared up for meals, evidence of which can be seen in the rear room. Note the fixed bar counter which you still have to crouch under to access (similar to De La Ardosa in Madrid). They boast a cellar of 500 wines meaning no wine drinker is going to want for much, but what is more interesting is they are mainly available by the glass, which is pretty special. I often find plenty to criticise about wonderful places that have been slightly spoiled by commercialising, as this has - the boastful promotional material about balancing tradition and modernity in harmony is a little self-satisfied and doesn't ring true entirely.  However, it is important to balance those disappointments against the quality that is there. There is no doubt it is among the best venues in the city, even if it is drifting towards haute-bourgeoisie and tourism in its approach. (Added July 2024)

name: Old Dairy Taproom
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.3
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Impressive range, with cask from their own brewery,  as well as a long list of varied keg options. Bottle shop on site.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
It is an old dairy, so as you'd expect, a large corrugated iron roof, but on entry you find only a small pub-café, which at first seems to be the taproom, before ducking right into a large event space with long bar and stage to the rear which has been colourfully decorated.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Local life across the age ranges gather here, unsurprisingly. It's a quirky venue which helps add a certain something to the atmosphere, particularly in the evenings.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, shop, live events, TV, outdoor seating
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Fair value for their own brewed beer, and standard pricing for the rest. 
description: A quirky find, a brewery and large event space set in an old dairy with its big corrugated iron roof, colourfully decorated inside to help make the space more personalised and intimate. As well as the brewery's own wares you'll find a large selection to enjoy, a turn-up in a town like Tenterden. Whether it's the small pub-café by the entrance or large bar it's a distinctive place not quite like anything you'll have been to before, with evening atmosphere accentuated in summer or for live events in autumn and winter. A real must-see while in town. (Added October 2024)

name: Ye Olde Thirsty Pig
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Local Kentish ales on tap and some decent European keg and bottle.

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Timber framed pub, a handsome building, with pub rooms across different rickety levels. Unfortunately some quite tacky decor choices related to the operation running the place which don't really work.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Down-to-earth and occasionally in your face, a no airs and graces type boozer which tries to focus on fun. 
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Snacks, jukebox, events, TV
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Fair/normal value for the products on offer. 
description: Timber-framed pub with  local Kentish ales on tap and some decent European keg and bottle.

Suitably rickety and old inside, let down by a few tacky and garish touches here and there, but this is a local boozer, down-to-earth, rather than a heritage inn, and so this is to be expected. 

Nevertheless, there is enough of interest here to warrant a recommendation.

(Added July 2024)

name: Blythe Hill Tavern
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.2
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
description:

name: The Faltering Fullback
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.4
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
description:

name: Tulsa Café
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
An Okay range, lacking much specialism, so broad rather than deep.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A lived-in performance venue and saloon bar, colourful and casual, a little dog-eared and purposefully that way.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Welcoming, inclusive and friendly with a diverse clientele of locals, touring musicians, occasional visitors and the odd tourist popping by.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Live music, tapas, snacks, limited outdoor seating, books, TV, darts
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Fair prices corresponding with the quality of wares.
description: Warm, welcoming and diverse are the three adjectives that get used about Tulsa a lot. You'll no doubt experience the same on your visit. A casual, homely kind of bar, lived-in, perhaps a little dog-eared in places too, but the atmosphere and surroundings are comfortable and relaxed. Their reason for being is hosting live music, often acoustic sets where the bar comes into its own. Outside of the music, you'll find a saloon bar type feel more similar to a casual pub than anything sophisticated, but that is how it is meant to be. Drinks are decent and fairly priced, but also lacking much in terms of specialism. But this is about adding colour, flavour and dynamism to a neighbourhood, something to experience. (Added July 2024)

name: Trooper Rock Bar
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
A reasonable selection of beers by Croatia's standards when factoring in the fridge options. Mainstream back bar for alternatives.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Unusual place for old town Zadar, straight off the stone into a small bar with a raised area at the back for further seating. Green walls decorated with classic rock n' roll/heavy metal ephemera.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A clear 'alternative' space for those who aren't quite down with the otherwise mainstream coastal bar going options in old town Zadar. As a result, there are some locals here even in peak season. While difficult to believe given the place is hardly Szimpla Kert, there really is nothing much else like it in the city.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Occasional music, snacks, limited outdoor seating, smoking permitted.
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Fair value given the central location.
description: Raw, smokey and local despite the old town location, there is a fair bit of charm to this place that is made more stark by the absence of anything even remotely similar to it around the city. A classic rock bar in some respects with the usual memorabilia and music decor, A small bar room with seating in a raised area to the back which still attracts residents as well as tourists, possibly on account of the unpretentious surroundings and fair value overall. It isn't entirely a loss when it comes to drinks either, with Pivovara Medvedgrad bottles alongside the more mainstream fare. If you are in any way inclined towards the alternative then this is the place you need to check out while in Zadar. (Added August 2024)

name: Rak Winery
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.9
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Homemade winery produced to very high standards, with some liqueurs/brandy available too.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
A homely feel, stepping into someone's back yard at first (literally) then into a large homestead. There is a bar/counter to the left of the door and indoor dining/seating areas. Low key, well appointed with natural wood/brick.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Fantastic hospitality from the family who will explain their background, the process, the production and so on, making the experience feel similar to that of a Zoiglstube where those serving are delighted to welcome you and show off their wares. Calm and relaxing at quieter times up on the plateau outside Sibenik, with a gregarious family feel when bigger groups arrive.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Tastings, food, snacks, shop, outdoor seating.
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Tastings are poured generously and the food platter is similarly vast, ample for two people.
description: Possible to travel by bus to the stop near this winery from Sibenik itself. A family operation based in a plateau the other side of Sibenik's hills while overshadowed by larger slopes inland. The wine is made in the surrounding areas, red, white, sparking and rose - the latter two not traditionally Dalmatian. The operation combines a modern approach of quality over quantity, with traditional values of hospitality in a homely setting. The owners lavish you with information alongside generous pours, letting their enthusiasm out. The food platters feature food made or prepared themselves - fresh bread and olives, home-cured prsut (prosciutto), with some specialist cheeses brought in. While the upfront cost for a 6 wine wasting and a food platter, may provide pause for thought, the satisfaction afterwards certainly leads one to conclude it was worth every penny. The hospitality is similar to that of a German Zoiglstube where the passion shines, but the surroundings remain humble, relaxed and all about enjoying the good things in life, without the need for artifice. (Added August 2024)

name: BAR BASKET
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.6
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Several taps offering Croatian craft beer from independent breweries, alongside better known offerings like Ozujsko and Pilsner Urquell. Considerably better than average. Typical Caffe Bar fare when it comes to alternatives.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A surviving woodstrip bar divided between a lower floor you step down to off the street and a mezzanine/balcony floor with old school Vienna café style furnishings and decoration. Highly personalised main bar with some 70s and 80s relics such as a popcorn machine and old vinyl records. Cartoons across the wall on the stairwell. Small groundfloor room to the other side of the entrance nearer the toilets popular with dog owners, a bit of an overspill area.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Hugely characterful, an immediate sense not only of institution but thriving social scene, a broad clientele across age and class, however it remains a smokey venue which is something you must bear in mind.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Snacks, TV, books, outdoor seating.
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Entirely fair value for money, indeed almost pointedly cheap for some of the offerings.
description: Dating from 1973, Basket is rightly known as the coziest bar in town. Formerly a hangout for local journalists, it is easy to see why, at a venue which is pitched somewhere between a Viennese café and a dive bar. Wood panelling, Neapolitan hues and café furnishings in a bar that is shaped more like something you'd find in the scuzzier parts of Manhattan's dive scene.

It is worth reinforcing over and over again that pubs and bars of this format simply do not exist in Croatia, or are such an endangered species that they can technically be described as extinct.

Wood panelling out front hints at the continuing theme inside. A step down to a dive bar counter with TV and popcorn machine to the left, and a busy, cluttered, homely and artful bar area, some of which appears unchanged for decades. We must inevitably mention the fogbank of smoke - yes, that is another element of the past kept alive here.

It isn't all nostalgia though, the bar offers an up to date selection of beers including Croatian craft beer from independent breweries, there's a TV which normally shows Hajduk Split games and this remains very much a cultural hub with a broad clientele.

The upstairs lounge is permanently popular for people hanging out at a more leisurely pace, and you'll notice the stairwell has been subject to hundreds of comic art pieces.

Those with dogs tend to choose the side room near the toilets which is a little bit of an overspill area, but quite characterful in itself, with dust motes suspended in the light and cig fumes cascading into the room.

Vinyl records appear on the walls, and you'll often hear classic rock in the background (not too loud thankfully).

Just to add to the list of upsides to coo over, it's worth pointing out just how fairly priced the drinks are here, at least 15-25% cheaper than what you can pay in the old town, despite the fact this is a popular place. 

It is difficult to understate just how much better this bar is than pretty much everything else in the city. (Added August 2024)

name: Marvlvs Library Jazz Bar
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A good quality back bar kitted out for wines, whisky, aperitivo, mixers, cocktails and liqueurs. Basic beers though.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Situated in a 15th century building, the Palaca Marulic said to have been the birthplace of the eponymous Croatian literary legend. The bar lets the natural character do the heavy lifting, a wise choice. Subtly lit with a cosy small main bar and long room to the rear that almost feels like a separate business.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Loungey and purposefully low-key, you can escape the sometimes claustrophobic chaos of the old town by coming here. The bar lets the natural character do the heavy lifting, a wise choice. Subtly lit with a cosy small main bar and long room to the rear that almost feels like a separate business.

Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Library, readings, occasional live music, snacks
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
Higher than average but not extortionate.
description: Tastefully exploiting the historic preserved environments of a 15th century palace, there is an inherited genius loci to this building which they have carefully built upon, an ambience that is a refreshing, cosy, and calming escape from the sometimes stifling crowds in Split old town. Live music and readings can be experienced here, as you'd expect from the title, but on other days there is a relaxed soundtrack in what is a deliberately low key place for a romantic evening, or quiet plotting with a friend or two. Be sure to explore the surroundings too. It is, and already many years ago became a central institution. (Added August 2024)

name: Paloma Nera Cocktail Bar
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.9
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Bespoke cocktails off a purposefully restrained menu are delicious and they will accept alternatives if they have the ingredients in stock to work with.

There are alternatives to cocktails listed on the wall adjacent to the bar.

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A one room bar dominated by the corner bar itself which occupies most of the space with seating at the bar and around the sides. A warm glow greets you on approach, reds and golds with varnished wood panelling somewhat of a rarity and standout for Croatia. Famous artwork prints on the wall are suitable, if not very inspired.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Treading that fine line between a casual drop in venue to meet friends and catch up with staff and an intimate, special feeling space to enjoy a special drink. That is a big compliment, as so many do not even try to achieve that. Although we prefer proper seating, the stools and high chairs add to that here and encourage conversation and cross-chat.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️
Snacks, smoking permitted
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Reasonably priced all-round.
description: A rare example where we take a trip abroad and visit a venue that has only just opened. This happened in August 2024 where we found Paloma Nera. According to the staff this bar used to be a den of iniquity, and you can kind of see why that would be, positioned next door to a strip club. It is unclear if the wood fittings date to that era but they have endowed Paloma Nera with a very distinctive character.

Ordinarily, cocktail bars do not have the feeling that you can walk straight up off the street and sit on the corner with the ease of a tapas bar, but you can do that here. All the while, there is an intimacy due to the small size, rich red hues and lighting that make you forget it throws its doors open to welcome the public.

Bespoke cocktails off a purposefully restrained menu are delicious and they will accept alternatives if they have the ingredients in stock to work with.

There are alternatives to cocktails and while sitting at the bar it is easy to begin conversing with friendly staff who are of course multilingual.

Taking some of the finer points of the best cocktail bars while maintaining the ease of welcome and local character is a skill and one not many achieve (or even try to achieve).

It is striking just how different this place is as well as just how needed it was too, and it comes highly recommended. (Added August 2024)

name: Bar Sistema
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A cocktail bar primarily with an extensive back bar, but more neatly packaged array of bespoke menu options. Limited alternatives.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
While the building itself is not without charm, the headline act is the attention grabbing backlit backbar, replete with the now quite common ladder to emphasis size and space. The drinks wall is the main decorative feature other than some fairly tastefully lit walls with natural brickwork and structure exposed.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️
A see and be seen kind of place, but not so much as to feel stuffy or overly exclusive. Your money is as good as anyone's here, but perhaps don't walk in in flip flops and board shorts. It feels spacious but lively and social with it.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️
Snacks 
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
Not the cheapest, nor extortionate.
description: Cocktails are a good way to get a different experience from Croatia's bar scene, bogged down as it is in Caffe Bar/terrace culture. Finding places that tread the right path between trashy and overly stuffy and preening is difficult, but one Sistema has managed. While the bar itself is executed immaculately with its showpiece backlit back bar immediately grabbing your attention (more impressive still when the staff are sliding along the ladder) there remains an easy affability and welcome to the place, helped by the spaciousness and temperature in the interior. Yes, this isn't a tiki shack and you should probably change out of your beach gear, but it isn't somewhere you'll be kicked out of if you are wearing any reasonable casual clothes. The cocktails are made to a good standard with some local twists leaning on the herbs and spices of the land, and it's an all-round high quality option to consider for a change. (Added August 2024)

name: Caffe bar La Linea
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Typical Croatian caffe bar fare livened up with cocktail options.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Based on a small square in a characterful old town Split building. Exposed brick inside and fairly pubby feeling by local standards too.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Lively, unrestrained with a good deal of pace and atmosphere, helped by a mixture of locals with tourists.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Snacks, outdoor seating, smoking permitted, TV
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Among the best value options in Split old town for drinks.
description: Known as one of the remaining few honestly priced operations in the old town, finding La Linea can be a challenge in itself, set down a warren of narrow streets on a small square in Split's historic core. This is a pleasingly pubby venue that compensates for the lack of finesse to its cheap honest fare with a lively and vibrant atmosphere. One to keep up your sleeve as it is still frequented by a mixture of tourists and locals. (Added August 2024)

name: Leopolds Craft Beer Bar
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Own brewed beer from Mandrill brewery and good Croatian craft beer selection in the fridge
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
A step down from the previous location, more backpackery appearance. A small bar with niches and ad hoc furnishings. Cushions on the steps outside however are a nice touch and give the place a much needed element.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Old town atmosphere out on the steps certainly adds a lot, undeniably, while the backpackery nature does give it a friendly feel, along with the friendly service of the host. It simply isn't what it used to be in the old location though.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, TV, books
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
Undeniably expensive and not clearly priced either.
description: Back in 2018, Leopold's Delicatessen on the fringes of the old town was a must-visit venue with a distinctive interior and cutting edge beers. Time moves on inexorably however and the sands have shifted. You'll find the bar in the centre of the old town now, among the maze of streets which undeniably lends it a certain atmosphere, but is attracting nearly all tourists rather than locals, a decision I'm sure they made in full knowledge that would be the case. The venue interior is a big step down too. It isn't all disappointing though, as service from the owner's wife is friendly and helpful, they have their own brewing operations and the general selection of drinks is strong. As you'll be exploring the alleyways of beautiful Split old town, a place like this is handy to have up your sleeve. Bittersweet though, like an IPA. (Added August 2024)

name: Golden Rule
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.3
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
Cask ales from Robinson Brewery's stable, the usual limited allowances for guests ales however. Simple, familiar alternatives.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Centuries old stone cottage up a narrow lane. Inside there are several rooms leading off from the bar area, with simple homely furnishings, warm hues, red upholstery and whitewashed walls decorated with local artwork and photography covering hiking, farming, etc. Bookshelves, games area, fireplaces. Look out for the tables with OS maps on them.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Pleasingly unspoilt at the time of writing. Robinsons ownership always gives cause for tension given their habit of greywashing characterful pubs, but a long standing tenant has most likely helped avert that. The one true 'boozer' in Ambleside which is about socialising in a cosy, casual environment. Great atmosphere doing so in the typically Cumbrian surroundings, particularly when visitors mingle and cross-chat between groups. 
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Pies, scotch eggs, snacks, outdoor seating, books, games, real fires
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
Typical tourist Lake District prices, but not extortionate.
description: The Golden Rule was created in part from stone scavenged from the nearby Galava Roman Fort in the 16th century. It was originally the brewery house for Ambleside Hall before an 18th century conversion to a pub.

The current licensee has run the pub for over 30 years and with their experience comes a commitment to maintaining an unspoilt hiker's pub with a social focus. 

The interior is a web of different rooms, all of which are comfortably furnished with natural character from the buildings accented by photographs and artwork of the Lake District, hiking and mountaineering over the decades.

There are fireplaces, shelves heaving with books and a few games to keep larger groups occupied. 

Food is restricted to pub snacks, pies etc rather than full meals, which sets it apart from everywhere else in town. 

The mixture of people who come to Ambleside always delivers interesting combinations and conversations which this pub at its best stokes and brings to life. Those who have visited The Fat Cat in Sheffield may notice a distinct similarity in atmosphere and format, although the two have no relationship, there are detectably similar attitudes on show. 

Robinson's Brewery have a nasty habit of sterilising some of their heritage pubs (though there are noticeable exceptions), so it is nice to see that so far, they have not been tempted to do so here.

By far and a way Ambleside's best pub and one of the pub highlights of Cumbria itself too. 

(Added August 2024)

name: Badger Bar
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.6
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A selection of regional cask ales, good gins and whiskies the highlight alongside more familiar hotel bar style alternatives.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A compact down-to-earth bar with a country feel. Chunky furnishings in a traditional environment. Unsurprisingly Badgers feature in the decor though it is not overdone. Large beer garden by a rock formation which actually features within the building itself (try the toilets). Parts of the bar and dining room reportedly date as far back as the 17th Century.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A popular spot for those enjoying the lake or returning from hikes, a friendly vibe given most people are here for recreation and to relax.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, outdoor seating, wifi, hotel rooms, webcam for live Badger watching, books, board games, log fires
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
Typical Lake District pricing.
description: Based in the traditional Glen Rothay hotel, Badger Bar is a pleasingly unspoilt place for drink and relaxation with country comforts that haven't veered anywhere close to the kind of sterilised dining room makeovers that have ruined hundreds of rural pubs across the country. Badger Bar is so named for the colony who exist on the grounds and can be viewed on webcam via the bar's website. The bar itself has plenty of Badger related ephemera whilst not being overblown. A pretty beer garden by the rock formation (which actually bleeds into the building itself - see the toilets) is a lovely place to sit out in the sun, whilst log fires and regional ales do the business for the colder/wetter times of year, of which there are plenty in this part of England. (Added August 2024)

name: Rowells Drinking Emporium
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
6 cask ales served on gravity direct from the casks hoisted on racks in a cool room by the bar, so you'll never see the pouring itself take place. Keg options are more prosaic but there are a reasonable list of café bar alternatives.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A former Draper's, the bar has won an award for its successful conversion which retains some of the original fittings including the counter and shelving. A long airy room with bar top to the right, shelves to the left and a controlled cool room where casks of ale are kept. Some stained glass, Victorian artefacts and World War era ephemera to cement the olde-world appearance. 
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A market town ale house feel, perhaps missing the hook that would open the business up to a younger crowd, but nevertheless busy and social.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Live music on weekends, snacks and café fare.
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Normal for the area.
description: Rowell's, a former Drapers was turned into a retro ale house. Somewhat bittersweet, as the former business had been operating for 100 years and was iconic in the market town of Long Eaton. Shelving, cabinets and counters from the business have been retained and the bar has also been fitted with reclaimed sympathetic fittings such as the floor and cabinets. Decorated with World War era ephemera, with other features like stained glass, mangles and flags (perhaps a few too many, actually), there is plenty to look at. An ever changing selection of cask ales served on gravity from a cold room is superb and the combination of these factors is alone enough to warrant a visit. The atmosphere is typical market town stuff, bordering on café like so  therefore there's food for thought as to how to broaden its appeal. Outside of music on Friday evenings and weekends this could attract a broader audience. (Added August 2024)

name: The Royal Oak
description:
EBG Rating:: 8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A Bass stronghold, one of the few remaining, with 4 guest lines. Simple, slightly old fashioned selection of alternatives.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A 3-star heritage pub interior that has been used as a public house since 1865. The bar area and snug in particular have that timewarp quality, but it is slightly misleading. The bar counter used to be positioned elsewhere and a new bar was added in 1993, a low counter by modern standards without much of a barrier between customer and server. Sizeable grounds with a drive and gazebo to the front, and a path to a 'sensory garden' adjacent.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Aside of the appeal as a heritage venue, which itself provides considerable character, the pub has been run by the same family for the last 60 years or more, meaning the operation has that very singular quality. This is particularly accentuated during mid-weeks when there is a mid-afternoon closing. A friendly welcome and low key, relaxed feel on quiet afternoons, but it can up the pace when there are events on.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, outdoor seating, garden, live music, events, pub games, 
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Beers are typical price for the area but some of the meals are fairly priced.
description: A semi-rural Midlands classic, the large Bass hoarding at the front is a signal of what to expect inside, with its mid 20th century feel kept very well intact. The format may now seem unfamiliar to some which gives it a quirkiness and character. Kept in the same family for 60+ years, giving it a distinct identity to its service and hospitality. It isn't all about a Museum-like timewarp though, as guest ales, live events and two gardens help togive it a sense of life and relevance. While it looks isolated on a map, the pub can be reached relatively easily for anyone of modern fitness via a bus link between Derby and Nottingham, and a walk either up through Borrowash (20-25 minutes) or via Spondon, where another nice pub awaits. Don't think twice, go! (Added August 2024)

name: The Vat & Fiddle
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Castle Rock Brewery’s tap. 13 of their beers on cask with guest beers, as well as award-winning  cider selection. 6 craft keg lines, alongside a slightly more prosaic selection of alternatives.

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Art Deco era building, purpose built as a pub, with the typical flowing lines. A long bar set up for busy days does nevertheless feature reasonably cosy cushioned niches opposite and a bar room adjacent. Large outdoor seating area.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️
A workmanlike atmosphere which seems to accompany the brewery setting. Best atmosphere in the pub room as the long bar is naturally absent of a focal point. With the Deco design there is an element of liminal space, whether intentional or otherwise that makes it not quite as cosy and comfortable as it could be.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Outdoor seating, food, snacks, games, books, The Old Cold Store event space next door.
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Fair value for money for most of what's on offer.
description: An Art Deco brewery tap located only a few minutes walk from Nottingham train station. Easy access and large outdoor seating to the rear under the tower of Castle Rock brewery makes it a fixture for weekend crowds, sports/comedy/music lovers, and groups, particularly in better weather. The 1930s design was bespoke, formerly The Grove and undergoing many changes of ownership since, the interior has survived fairly well considering all that. A long bar showcasing over a dozen of the breweries beers with bar room adjacent and niches opposite, this is a workmanlike venue during the day where the cold Deco surfaces don't quite provide the comfort and homeliness you may wish for. Nevertheless, it is stylish and you can't knock it for drinks and amenities; it deserves its inscription. (Added August 2024)

name: King William IV
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.2
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A strong selection of regional cask ales, ciders and perries mark this as a standout for specialists. Some decent craft keg. Room for improvement in lagers and gins but the quality ale and cider warrants the full five stars.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A heritage pub dating pre-Victorian, but other than the structure of the building (itself altered), you'll find a familiar traditional ale house inside with a central bar around which three rooms seat customers. Today's decoration is a personalised and quirky curation of kitsch and heritage ephemera which works very well in the wooden, matchboxy surroundings of the ground floor. The lounge is more spacious and slightly less peculiar, while there's a roof terrace, somewhat of a surprise. The terrace is not particularly beautiful with astroturf and a bit of wear and tear.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A time honoured format rebooted without losing its essence or charm. The array of events and amenities draw in a broad audience from folk musicians, dog lovers, rock fans, real ale and cider fanatics, alternative groups and the every day Joe looking for a good environment to enjoy a drink and relax. 
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Outdoor seating, pies & rolls, evening street food, live music, events, TV
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Fair pricing for what's on offer, though not much particularly outstanding.
description: The King William IV, known since forever as King Billy, has more or less graduated formally to being called the latter, something which suits the informal nature of the place. A cider and real ale haven with smaller independent producers on show on cask and keg. Situated near the Sneinton Market regeneration area, this is a part of Nottingham that is burgeoning for independent businesses. King Billy has an astute offering that draws in a wide range of people without diluting its essence, as well as a distinctive identity, swaddled in kitsch and heritage artwork and nik naks fastened to the walls. Whether it's scrumptious vegan rolls (try them and disagree with me) or street food, live music and folk nights, or basic sport and beers, they do it, and unsurprisingly that explains why it's so well loved. (Added August 2024)

name: The Gladstone
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
A tied pub, so cask ale selection veers towards a "Best Of" selection of well known national brands rather than regional, smaller independents, but it's a decent range nevertheless. Alternatives veer towards the middle/lower end.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A classic two-room pub with bar opening out into both sides. Comfortable upholstered communal bench seating along the walls. The lounge features original brass work and is decorated with local heritage and the eponymous 19th century Prime Minister William Gladstone. Beer garden to the rear which competes in local floral display competitions. Dart board and TV in the bar room.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Very much a neighbourhood pub, and not the big mock tudor coaching inn type, but a side-street boozer with a casual, cosy and welcoming feel. Social and informal, somewhere you could get chatting to your neighbour fairly easily. Perhaps missing a few tricks to pull in a younger crowd, but being a tied pub, this may not be the licensees fault.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Outdoor seating, TV, darts, books, quiz, snacks
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Neither cheap nor extortionately expensive.
description: The Gladstone is an appealing, low-key neighbourhood pub that remains alive and vibrant feeling. A classic Victorian two-room set up with bar and lounge either side of a double facing bar, you'll find the typical dart board and telly in the bar, while there's comfortable seating in both rooms, a little more restful in the lounge though. Named after the eponymous politician William Gladstone, it feels every bit as durable as that titan of Victorian politics. Classic, albeit unimaginative cask ales are well kept, the selection restricted by virtue of the tied pub ownership. This is not a free house so its future and any changes are unfortunately in the hands of an unscrupulous and unreliable pub company. (Added August 2024)

name: The Pillar Box
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.6
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Gin specialists with 100 varieties, and a range of two dozen cocktails dominates the selection, but they also serve draft beer, from a rather peculiar (and mediocre) selection.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A small converted retail unit on the high street with eclectic decor. Some lavish touches, some antique, some golden era and some out of leftfield. 
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Late opening hours mean there is quite a mixed crowd here beyond simply gin drinkers. 
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Deli boards, chess, snacks, limited outdoor seating
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Typical pricing that will not surprise positively or negatively.
description: Sherwood's bar options broadened in the last few years with a bonafide craft beer bar/bottle shop in Kraft Works and The Pillar Box, ostensibly a gin bar but in practise, somewhere to hangout later in the evenings. The compact size and overall budget means this was never going to manage to  pull of a sophisticated upper end bar. Instead you get a quite appealing blend of things. Neighbourly friendliness, eclectic and sometimes quite distracting décor, intimate space but of a sort that encourages cross conversation. It's rather effective. If you don't enjoy gin don't worry as there's an ably stocked back bar and a few draft beers available too. Don't overlook it as an evening hangout if you're in the area. (Added August 2024)

name: Hop Rocket
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.7
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Beers are unsurprisingly a strong suit with 8 cask lines, a row of keg options and fridge full of bottles and cans. Alternatives are decent but not a standout.

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Hop Rocket is a one-room setup with raised area to the rear and bar to the left of the entrance. Painted in greens and reds with the now fairly common recovered breweriana and hoardings which always proves quite effective. Small terrace out front.

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️
Suburban ale house feel that perhaps lacks a natural focal point due to layout, but improves when busier, particularly sunnier days on the terrace.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Beer related events and takeovers, sandwiches & rolls, snacks, merchandise, shop, outdoor seating
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Reasonable overall but not outstanding.
description: Opening in early 2024, adding an ale house to Unthank Road which has slowly and surely become a more happening suburb, albeit from the perspective of affluence. A former bookshop and cocktail bar, now owned and run by Brewery Tap in NR3, Hop Rocket is a one-room setup with raised area to the rear and bar to the left of the entrance. Painted in greens and reds with the now fairly common recovered breweriana and hoardings which always proves quite effective. Drinks are unsurprisingly a strong suit with 8 cask lines, a row of keg options and fridge full of beers in case they don't suit. A clearly superior suburban choice that compares favourably with strong equivalents like The Hillary Step in Manchester. (Added August 2024)

name: The Alexandra Tavern
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.9
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
The focus is 4-5 cask ales on rotation with an emphasis on regional and local independent brewers. A well stocked but more familiar back bar of alternatives.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A corner pub with diminutive frontage, enter to find an immediately appealing space with traditional furnishings, heritage signage and artwork on the walls and a long bar leading to the kitchen door at the rear. There is a lounge room opposite as part of the double facing bar. 

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Friendly, comfortable, cosy and welcoming with a true community feel, the kind of pub that should be everywhere but for whatever reason, just isn't. Rare.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, outdoor seating, community events, books, board games, TV
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Good value for food and drinks overall considering what's on offer.
description: Rarely do pubs make such an endearing and lasting first impression, but that was the case on our first visit here in 2024. A corner pub with diminutive frontage, enter to find an immediately appealing lounge space with traditional furnishings, heritage signage and artwork on the walls and a long bar leading to the kitchen door at the rear. There is a lounge room opposite as part of the double facing bar. The welcome is friendly and the hospitality as good as if you had been visiting as a regular for years, a great tribute to the efforts and attitude of the staff. A Free House, with a range of regional and local cask ales the highlight, while a creative kitchen knocks out dishes that you wouldn't often find on restaurant menus in England, let alone pubs. These are designed to be hearty, often one-pot affairs, allowing you to get good portions at a fair price, with the options ever changing - vegetarians, vegans and those seeking gluten free options are all catered for, although some dishes are 'gone when they're gone. Sat among comfortable seating, it's clear the place has it, the genius loci that makes us keep exploring and keep loving pubs. There is plenty else to add - the community events, books, games, TV etc, but it is best to emphasise the welcome, the comfort, the good food and ales, the good value option and the knowledge that yes, pubs really can still be this good. (Added August 2024)

name: Arboretum
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Bespoke cocktails created to match customer preference - in reality this seems to involve the same dozen or so being produced, but it's fun while it lasts. Bottles of beer and occasional cask of ale have previously featured.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Boarded up shopfront leading to an antiques/bric-a-brac strewn study, a converted front room with a narrow bar behind it and ramshackle/bohemian outdoor area. Dimly lit, with books, shelves, bunting, lamps and vintage furniture.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
An immensely characterful and atmospheric venue, the kind that arises from an inspired but also ad hoc approach rather than corporate financing and demographic/template led design. 
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Snacks, outdoor seating, books, items for sale
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
A fixed price for cocktails, not cheap but not extortionate.
description: Almost the definition of a love-or-hate place. If the idea of a tiny, cramped, ramshackle high concept cocktail bar unmarked from the street where they make drinks loosely in accordance with your tastes sounds, good, terrible, or somewhere in between, there is really only one way to find out. Of course, we really liked it.

Don't be deterred by its unmarked exterior deliberately designed to appear like a boarded-up shop.

An antique shop as well as a bar, they claim you can put a bid in on any of the artefacts strewn around the place. Formerly hosted a dog that would prowl around, but that passed away. Service is very friendly and places you at ease in the setting, and it's a special atmosphere, a non-corporate setting you'd never find somewhere in a city like Leeds where every new bar is big budget and sculpted to within an inch of its life. This really isn't like that, for better or for worse. We think there's a gem of a bar here. Lastly, please note that the owner is looking to sell the business but will keep running it until 2027 unless no buyer is found. (Added August 2024)

name: Golden Star
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.7
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Greene King stable beers complimented by guest ales, some of which are from regional independent brewers. A solid back bar of alternatives.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
L-shaped pub in 17th century building that has served as a pub since Victorian times. With bar at the entrance and backroom with further seating and billiards table. Traditional furniture with personalised decorations and events posters. The rear hosted a small microbrewery in the 1970s and 1980s no longer in operation.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A genuinely characterful pub with a genteel nature but an assertive identity, not least due to the operation running it. A far cry from the preconceptions of a Greene King pub. Busy on event nights with tables reserved for quiz teams worth watching out for.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Quiz, bar billiards, snacks, limited outdoor seating, newspapers, live music
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Reasonable value considering the pubco tie.
description: Despite being a tied pub, you will find plenty of personality about Golden Star. The Greene King awning out front is normally a prompt for shoulders to slump, but don't be deterred. Inside you'll find an L-shaped compact pub with traditional fixtures and fittings, comfortable furniture and a personalised interior, with plenty of signs of community involvement. Regular events such as pub quiz, live music, billiards league draws in a loyal following, and it's a friendly crowd too - typical for Norwich but nevertheless notable. The Greene King involvement slightly hampers the drinks selection and pricing for obvious reasons, but they do select guest ales, some of which are from regional independent brewers. We can firmly recommend a visit. (Added August 2024)

name: The Leopard
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.7
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
The beer selection is very strong here on cask, keg and bottles, competing with most places across Norwich. A well stocked bar for alternatives.

Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Among many pubs to be opened out in the 1970s, a corner local with seating around a central bar. Furnished with mid/light brown wood bench seating and decorated with hops and sparsely arranged retro signage. The Leopard signage is unmissable on approach. Terrace/patio in the back yard. 
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️
While there are many things to like about the Leopard, it is perhaps too genteel for its own good and lacks the loungey homeliness of the Alexandra or bunker feel of the White Lion. Still, it is friendly and welcoming with a neighbourly character.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, outdoor seating, events
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Good value for money for the high quality wares on offer.
description: Sold by Bateman's brewery in 2013 and refurbished, there is a light, airy and genteel nature to The Leopard which perhaps arguably moves it into an ale house/café category rather than the neighbourhood corner boozer it was. The beer selection is very strong here on cask, keg and bottles, competing with most places across Norwich. The pub lacks the grab-me factor of the Alexandra, Fat Cat or White Lion but it is friendly, welcoming and neighbourly and still comes firmly recommended. (Added August 2024)

name: Green Dragon
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.7
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
4 changing cask ales from regional brewers to bigger national names. Some specialist spirits.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A 2 star listed building of National Heritage importance. Tudor 14th century building with timber frame, dormer window, large heart and black beams. Opened out to an extent inside but still with the off-centre angles and quirks you'd expect. A door marked "to the Abbey" leads only to a cupboard. High-backed seats with cushions.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Characterful interior and a real fire provides sufficient draw whether busy or quiet. Popular for functions and summer days due to its large beer garden.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Outdoor seating, meals, snacks, occasional events, function room
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Standard pricing for the area.
description: A genuine Tudor building, a slightly scorched survivor of the Great Fire of Wymondham in 1615.

The scene on approach with adjacent church, memorial to Kitt's Rebellion and close proximity to Wymondham Abbey is a beautiful snapshot of genteel Olde England. 

The interior retains a good degree of character but not without alteration as CAMRA Heritage explains:

"The front door leads into a passage and at the rear is the distinct layout of a room split in two by a wooden partition forming settle seating and the tiny snug with a red quarry floor has an inglenook fireplace. There would have been hundreds of these snugs throughout England but the opening-up of the vast majority of them to create one large room makes the Green Dragon snug a remarkable survivor. Here the partition survives to the left and right but the central section which reached the ceiling was ripped out in 1993."

In the colder months the cosy interior and hearth and its black beams create a historic yet homely-feel that draws you in to spending more time there.

If you are in the area this is a must-visit pub. (Added August 2024)

name: The Garrick
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.6
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Typical Irish pub offerings are complimented by an Irish craft beer tap and a good list of German bottled beers. Strong selection of whiskies too, and adequate back bar.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Having won the award for 'Best Kept Small Building' on a number of occasions, you can infer this is a heritage venue. The historical records are inexact, but no later than 1870 a spirit merchants operated here, while the Garrick name began no later than 1892, the suggest being inspiration from London's Garrick Club, though again, that is not clear. A multi-room venue with function room upstairs, you'll note a traditional interior with fireplace and carved woodstrip ceiling, striking in its black paint against warm lamp light. Some modern trappings (jukebox etc) were removed in the mid-00s to have a more intact traditional pub. Fans of barometers will be delighted by the selection in the lounge.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A popular city tavern with bustling trade on evenings and weekends, a pub whose character is for autumn, winter, or just typical Belfast weather. Cosy interior.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Meals, snacks, limited outdoor space, function room, TV, folk music, DJ on weekends
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
Belfast city centre prices, so expensive, although not unusual for the area.
description: A popular city tavern with bustling trade on evenings and weekends, a pub whose character is ideal for Autumn, Winter, or just typical Belfast weather. Welcoming warm and gregarious in a historic venue with Victorian fittings and well preserved features - brass lamps, wood ceiling, fireplaces etc. If you're lucky enough to get a table you can enjoy the dynamic surroundings - some folk musicians in the corner. Given it's a city tavern, it occasionally gives off the feel of a homelier neighbourhood pub, while swinging back around again. Overall, that's an atmosphere that works quite well. Clearly a superior option to consider when visiting Belfast. (Added September 2024)

name: Kelly's Cellars
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A fairly typical south of Ireland leaning array of drinks options, but enough to keep one occupied. One plus point is among the best Guinness in the entire city - often scoffed at, but genuinely true here - it's one of the top 10 we've ever had. 
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
How much of the 1720 edition of this building remains inside the pub is inexact, and like many venues it began life with off-sales of whiskies and gins before graduating, but what can safely be agreed on is it has served the role of public house since the late Victorian era. A traditional 'pokey' interior awaits inside, low vaults with snugs opened out into a bar with side rooms, decorated in rustic fashion. A sizeable outdoor area on the square with decoration on the exterior means the venue projects outwards considerably more than what you'll find downstairs. Upstairs housed the first cocktail bar in the 1950s but these days is - somewhat jankily - incorporated into the same pub.

Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
With live music most days and a rustic village pub feel inside, the atmosphere is how you'd hope and expect. Outside on the terrace is not the usual anonymous fare because the exterior of the pub has been decorated to make the terrace feel incorporated which is to its credit.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Live music, snacks, stew
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
City centre prices, but not out of the ordinary.
description: Trading keenly on being Belfast's oldest pub, the venue has had recent 'listing wars' as the council tried to delist this place among 17 other buildings. How much of the 1720 edition of this building remains inside the pub is inexact, and like many venues it began life with off-sales of whiskies and gins before graduating, but what can safely be agreed on is it has served the role of public house since the late Victorian era. A traditional 'pokey' interior awaits inside, low vaults with snugs opened out into a bar with side rooms, decorated in rustic fashion. A sizeable outdoor area on the square with decoration on the exterior means the venue projects outwards considerably more than what you'll find downstairs. Upstairs housed the first cocktail bar in the 1950s but these days is - somewhat jankily - incorporated into the same pub.

Kelly's has an Irish Nationalist heritage with prominent management in centuries past and housing Nationalist meetings, although these days you can be assured they'll take anyone's money. 

Live music most nights provide a Truman Show sense of perpetuation, and their Irish stew still gets rave reviews.

There is no doubt it is one of Belfast's most distinctive venues and one of its firmest fixtures.

Please note that anyone aged under 18 is not permitted on the premises (which includes the outside) 

(Added September 2024)

name: The Crown Liquor Saloon
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A superior range of beers above the Belfast average. Typical Island of Ireland keg beers are supplemented with cask ales, including Bass which is given a very rare outing for N.I. A broad back bar with good gin selection, otherwise from the Nicholson's/Mitchell & Butler chain range.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A Victorian gin palace given an ornate, lavish restoration in 1885 by Italian craftsmen brought over by boat to refurbish Belfast's churches. Further preservation work by the National Trust in 1978 and a later 2007 working has helped keep it in good condition. A 3* CAMRA National Heritage listing (the top grade) of superb and outstanding interiors.

Wikipedia offers further information:

"The exterior is decorated in polychromatic tiles. This includes a mosaic of a Crown on the floor of the entrance. The interior is also decorated with complex mosaics of tiles. The red granite topped bar is of an altar style, with a heated footrest underneath and is lit by gas lamps on the highly decorative carved ceilings.

The Crown has ten booths, or snugs. Built to accommodate the pub's more reserved customers during the austere Victorian period, the snugs feature the original gun metal plates for striking matches and an antique bell system for alerting staff.

Extra privacy was then afforded by the pub's etched and stained glass windows which feature painted shells, fairies, pineapples, fleurs-de-lys and clowns."

Bear in mind the pub has also been damaged during The Troubles and on a minor level, signs to not damage the wood by carving names and love messages go unheeded.

Its iconic snugs have been the scene of several films and the pub is also the subject of a standalone BBC documentary dedicated to its rich and colourful history.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Some will find the inherently touristic nature unappealing, while the chain ownership forces elements on it which are not necessarily complimentary. However, the downsides really end there. The environment is magnificent and unique, not only a spectacle but a glimpse of social history, kept alive in a similar way. Envious eyes are cast across at those occupying the snugs, but the atmosphere in the main bar area is pleasingly social and drinks focused too. It would be extremely churlish to argue there is not something extra special here even in the face of chain ownership which has a tendency to preserve fixtures but homogenise operations.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Meals, snacks, function suite
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
City centre Belfast prices plus the 'Mitchell & Butlers' tax added on, so not cheap.
description: There is much to say about what is one of the most famous pubs in either the UK or Ireland.

A true survivor through a century of political tumult, changing fashions and pure bad luck, the first impression on entering is nothing short of jaw-dropping.

Met by a panorama of lavish high Victoriana - mosaics, etched glass, faience tiles and old fashioned snugs, operating now as a casual city tavern. You may have seen some of the elements before but there are few drinking holes on Earth that have retained the ensemble as this has. Not only is it aesthetically superb, but it provides a glimpse into social history unlike almost any other. 

There are many interesting historic pubs but the most effective capture a moment in time vividly, as the Crown does.

It is therefore bittersweet that Mitchell & Butler's run this as a Nicholson chain pub. Sweet because they have a good reputation for preserving historic taverns, bitter because their operation, what goes on within the pub, tends to homogenise places which deserve their own distinct character.

Although this 'chain churn' (dinner plates, old glasses, etc) is mildly to its detriment, as is the high pricing, it doesn't dampen proceedings overly. Think of a drink as part of the entrance fee to a living museum.

Being central, bustling and famous usually ends up with the word 'institution' being trotted out, but rarely can that word be better applied than to this place, its daily rhythms as much part of Belfast than any other aspect, including those to cause upset and violence. Films, documentaries, famous criminals, ghosts, ...oh, you name it, The Crown has seen it.

But drop the bluster and nonsense and spend your time there soaking in what's around you.

Most of all it will cause you to notice how fragile beauty is, how special it is when it is exquisite and in doing so, how impressive it is when it endures. 

(Added September 2024)

name: The Spaniard
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.8
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A not too exciting beer range, but a very decent back bar, 
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Tiled frontage in Spanish style, while inside you're presented with a dive bar with music decor - rock/punk/soul/funk all represented on some level. Personalised, and small rooms across 3 floors. The upstairs rooms graduate in style, for instance religious memorabilia.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Very quickly it became a local institution for an evening drink. 2006 now seems like a long time ago. Provides a variety and verve that was much needed.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️
Amenities are naturally pretty limited, but they do a good job with what they have. 
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
Slightly more expensive than typical for central Belfast.
description: Tiled frontage in Spanish style, while inside you're presented with a dive bar with music decor - rock/punk/soul/funk all represented on some level. Personalised, and small rooms across 3 floors. The upstairs rooms graduate in style, for instance religious memorabilia. Very quickly it became a local institution for an atmospheric evening drink. 2006 now seems like a long time ago. Provides a variety and verve that was much needed. A strong selection of rums backs up a cocktail menu with many enticing options.  (Added October 2024)

name: Sunflower Public House
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.4
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A clearly superior range of beers by Belfast standards with independent cask and keg, as well as the usual staples. Decent whisky selection as you'd hope and expect.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Corner pub in an elderly building with bright green frontage and security gate from Troubles era. Inside, a small cosy bar with a living room feel which has nevertheless been fit recently, so is not shabby or worn in yet. 
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
The inside has been tastefully refurbished but is perhaps a little too clean, if we are going on the standards of the best homely Irish pubs. Nevertheless, the atmosphere on events nights and indeed most evenings is great, they have done their best to make the place as welcoming as possible. 
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Street food, outdoor seating, snacks, live music, events, quiz, newspapers, TV
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Usual Belfast city centre pricing.
description: The Sunflower's name is relatively recent - 2012, transferred across from a former demolished pub.  The previous incarnation, The Tavern had itself had been adopted from a former pub - such are the way things go. A corner boozer with telltale security gate at the entrance, with a scary history involving car bombs, Unionist gun battles, and even in 2013 it was vandalised during protests.

If that wasn't enough, the building was nearly demolished in 2015, stayed after a community protest, which unintentionally spawned the American Bar.

These days you'd barely believe there could be trouble at an operation which spills out into garden space, has been modernised and liberalised without losing its essence.

Live music, comedy, street food, and a good range of beers for a change, with cask and keg from independents and good lager too. 

But inside you'll find the same cosy bar room, green leather upholstery and chat.

Perhaps as with many famous pubs the service can sometimes veer towards the self-satisfied, but it is best to focus on the many positives.

This is among Belfast's finest pubs. (Added October 2024)

name: Maddens
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.5
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️
A typical mainstream selection of island of Ireland drinks, albeit the Guinness here is well poured.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Traditionally decorated and personalised with newspaper clippings and Irish Nationalist material. A wood strip interior in an open plan ground floor room with tables and bench seating around the side. Bar to the right of the entrance. Buzz the door for entry. Grills on the windows and CCTV by the bar are evidence of the continuing sectarian hostility.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A friendly welcome to friendly people, put it that way. A tourist (particularly an English tourist) wandering in to an Irish Nationalist pub should be wary about wading into local politics, but if you're here for a good time, to listen to good music and to respect a tradition and a culture, a fine welcome is to be enjoyed. 
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Live music, comedy club, pub quiz, sessions upstairs, snacks, newspapers
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Nothing unusual for central Belfast.
description: For older drinkers Maddens and this area of the city sticks in the mind for a series of bombings outside pubs in the mid-70s during The Troubles, including a car bomb that exploded and damaged the pub. The scars of that and other confrontations can be seen today, if not so much on its lavishly painted exterior, as on the window grills, the bell for entry and the CCTV positioned in almost constant eyeshot of the bar staff. This paints a rather grim picture, whereas today the reality is much different.

Sure, Maddens is an Irish Nationalist pub and uncompromising with that, they are not suddenly about to change their views, their culture or their traditions, much as the Protestants up the road aren't. When you walk towards the entry you will notice the propaganda, the news clippings and clover leafs abounding.

There is a difference between this hard exterior and the welcome and jollity to be found inside.

Known for its Irish music sessions and probably among the most well-reputed establishments in Belfast on that front. 

Although you can commonly find sessions downstairs, a large upstairs is used for cailies, open-mic and comedy shows.

As a result, the clientele straddles old and young, while we found the service entirely welcoming even though we were clearly English.

Be sensible and don't wade into local politics and treat people as who they are, other human beings with their experiences and stories to tell. 

There's a fine pub to enjoy, truly atmospheric and one of Belfast's finest.

(Added October 2024)

name: Kean's Head
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.1
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A vast selection of cask, keg and bottles beers covering traditional to modern, national to world. Decent cider selection and ample back bar for alternatives, with over 200 bottles of gins, rum and whiskies. Owned by Castle Rock brewery whose beer features but doesn't dominate. Bass is also sometimes available.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️
A simple one room ale house setup, wooden furniture and walls decorated with pump clips. Deep bar area which is at the rear of the room.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A pleasant, relaxing atmosphere most of the time, set on a side street so often feels like a nice little den away from the central rush.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, TV, takeaway, books, live events
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Variable, some absolutely fair prices, others head-scratchingly over the top.
description: Beer lovers rejoice! Since the mid 00s this forerunner of the micro/ale-house scene was set up to provide not only a superior selection but vastly superior to most. It is unlikely whatever your tastes that you will fail to find something you desire at the bar here. A simple setup, bordering on genteel, there's perhaps a hint of Belgian café/Estaminet to the one room setup decorated by pump clips and hanging hops. A connection to an adjoining Indian restaurant makes for a very tempting combination. Set in a Grade II listed building and named after a historic 19th century central pub. A must visit in the centre. (Added September 2024)

name: Café du Palais
description:
EBG Rating:: 7.9
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A typical 'Grand Café' type drinks selection, erring towards the mainstream but with some quirkier and unusual options. 
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A café dating from 1930, decorated with kitsch, portraits and fitted with work from the belle epoque - stained glass window, stylised motifs with natural themes. Art Deco makes an appearance in the fixtures and fittings but those elegant lines and curves cannot temper the electicism of the space as a whole. Outside covered terrace with an interior set around a curved bar. Classic reds and golds in the fixtures and furnishings. 
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Grand café interior with the rhythms of service - wisecracking but smartly dresser waiters, and a broad audience reflecting a versatile venue. Brightly lit, and could perhaps benefit from shadier corners in the evening.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, outdoor seating, newspapers, TV
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️
Typical city centre pricing, certainly not cheap.
description: Upon arriving in a French city, one of the venues you hope to find is a historic café or brasserie, something patrician with smart waiters, leather bench seating, and style from the belle epoque, nouveau + Deco to enjoy. Lamp lights, gold trim, stained glass. All this and more can be found at du Palais, which adds to that with a curious kitsch eclecticism. A typical menu is on offer, made interesting with a few non-standard flourishes, and the environment is how you'd expect - wise-cracking servers floating to and fro balancing plates of drinks. The lighting could perhaps be dimmed later in the evening (starkly lit venues do feel unwelcome in the later hours in my view), but aside that, there's a lot to look at soak up and enjoy about this lovely old cafe, a Reims institution. (Added November 2024)

name: Le Clos
description:
EBG Rating:: 9
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
A very wide range of drinks in the interior bar, quite limited outside (just go inside).
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
The layout is not dissimilar to a ruin bar, indeed as you walk through a wide entranceway into a courtyard your first thought (if you've visited Budapest's ruin bar) is just that. This is one of the closest operations outside Hungary to that scene.

At first it may seem an outdoor venue only - there's a bar, terrace, petanque court and some games machines, but there's a sizeable enough interior bar to your right which itself is well worth exploring.

A boudoir of reds and golds with interesting patterned ceiling, whose bar is far more extensive than the limited outdoor options.  
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
The atmosphere is simply superb on weekend evenings and events with a crowd of people without it being choked and cramped. Stylish but casual enough that it can welcome a range of people. 
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Tapas, snacks, outdoor seating, petanque, pinball, live acts - standup comedy / jazz among others.
Value For Money: ❤️❤️
Slightly higher than the average city centre options, but explore the interior bar for wider options. 
description: Set directly opposite fashionable Boulingrin market, the stylish nouveau exterior Le Clos has inherited is a standout in Reims. Le Clos has placed itself at the heart of cultural activities in the city. The layout is not dissimilar to a ruin bar, indeed as you walk through a wide entranceway into a courtyard your first thought (if you've visited Budapest's ruin bar) is just that. This is one of the closest operations outside Hungary to that scene. 

At first it may seem an outdoor venue only - there's a bar, terrace, petanque court and some games machines, but there's a sizeable enough interior bar to your right which itself is well worth exploring.

A boudoir of reds and golds with interesting patterned ceiling, whose bar is far more extensive than the limited outdoor options.  

The atmosphere is simply superb on weekend evenings and events with a crowd of people without it being choked and cramped. Stylish but casual enough that it can welcome a range of people. 

With live music, stand-up comedy, a petanque court, and games machines (tucked out of sight, but they are there), it's a genuine complex, among only a few hundred bars in Europe that can genuinely argue not only that they are one of the best bars in their city, but that they have in themselves improved a city and its appeal. (Added November 2024)

name: L’AXO
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.4
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
Champagne by the glass, bottles from small producers, several taps of independent beers from small brewers and an ample back bar for alternatives including cocktails. In short, excellent.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Although low key, the fact this bar has its own style which does not pinch or copy-paste from existing templates is at the core of its likeability. A one room simple bar with chunky wooden furniture and some wine heritage on the walls, with an unpretentious pubby appearance. Back yard and front terrace extending further.
Atmosphere/Character: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
A very pleasant atmosphere with a young crowd, friendly service and all-round sense of welcome and vibrancy. The sidestreet location gives it an in-the-know feel without the dressiness and pretense that normally accompanies that.
Amenities/Events: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Food, snacks, outdoor seating, books, games, happy hour
Value For Money: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
Scrupulously fair value given the quality of products available, better still in Happy Hour.
description: The reality of wine bars in most of Europe is that they are targeted at a specific audience - there is less of a pub feel because the operations are interested in a certain class, perhaps a certain age group, decorating and positioning their business accordingly. L'AXO is a refreshing antidote to this idea, offering a low key, pubby sidestreet bar which nonetheless has an extensive Champagne menu (this is Reims) alongside a few taps of local beers. The interior is nicely rustic, with its own identity rather than leaning on templates, while outdoor seating extends the atmosphere of the place onto the streets. Meanwhile, service is excellent, and the prices are scrupulously honest considering the quality of goods available. This is why it comes highly recommended to anyone visiting Reims. (Added November 2024)

name: Pub l'Escale
description:
EBG Rating:: 8.1
Choice/Quality of Drinks: ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️
10+ taps of excellent beers with a focus on Belgium and European styles but representing modern craft adequately too, supplemented by a big fridge of bottles. While there is a beer focus, wine is not neglected, with champagne by the glass, and there's a punchbowl on the corner if you feel daring.
Style/Décor: ❤️❤️❤️❤️
